Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Definitions and rules of construction, Code of Virginia, § 1-10 et seq.; authority to codify ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433; maximum penalty for violation of municipal ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1429; punishment for violation of various classes of misdemeanors, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-11. 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Salem, Virginia" and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Salem City Code." 
(Code 1969, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Codification and recodification of ordinances, admission in evidence, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-37.3. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the interpretation and construction of this Code and of all ordinances and resolutions of the city, the following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing with such surety, if any, as the council may direct, shall be sufficient. 
    City. The words "city" or "the city" shall mean the City of Salem in the State of Virginia. 
    Code of Virginia. The term "Code of Virginia" shall mean the Code of Virginia of 1950, as amended from time to time. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 1-13.3, 1-13.3:1. 
    Council. The words "council" or "the council" shall mean the council of the City of Salem, Virginia. 
    County. The words "county" or "the county" shall mean the County of Roanoke in the State of Virginia. 
    Following. The word "following," when used by way of reference to any section, shall be construed to mean next following that section in which such reference is made. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.6. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to corporations as well as males. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.7. 
    Health director. The term "health director" means the director of public health of the county or his authorized representative. 
    In the city. The words "in the city" shall mean any territory the jurisdiction of which for the exercise of its regulatory power has been conferred on the city by public or private law. 
    May. The word "may" shall be permissive. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.13. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; and a word importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.15. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.16. 
    Occupant or tenant. The word "occupant" or "tenant" applied to a building or land shall mean any person who holds a written or oral lease of or actually occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Officers, etc. The title of an officer, department, board or commission shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Salem, Virginia." 
    Official time standard. Whenever particular hours are specified in this Code relating to the time within which any act shall or shall not be performed by any person, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include any individual, corporation, partnership, association, company, business, trust, joint venture or other legal entity. 
    Preceding. The word "preceding," when used by way of reference to any section, shall be construed to mean next preceding that section in which such reference is made. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.23. 
    Property. The word "property" shall mean real, personal or mixed property. 
    Public grounds. The words "public grounds" shall mean the parks and all public lands owned by the city, and those parts of public places which do not form travelled parts of streets. 
    Shall. The word "shall" shall be mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The words "signature" and "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write, his name being written near it and being witnessed by a person who writes his own name as witness. 
    State. The words "state" or "the state" shall mean the State of Virginia. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way or place open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel in the city, including the streets and alleys, and, for law enforcement purposes, the entire width between the boundary lines of all private roads or private streets in the city which have been specifically designated "highways" by an ordinance adopted by the council. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.19. 
    Swear, sworn. The word "swear" or "sworn" shall be equivalent to the word "affirm" or "affirmed" in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.28. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense may include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written, in writing. The words "written" and "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
(Code 1969, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.32. 
Sec. 1-3. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1969, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-17.1. 
Sec. 1-4. - Provisions of Code construed as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are in substance the same as those of the Code of the City of Salem, Virginia of 1969, and all ordinances adopted subsequent thereto and included in this Code, shall be construed as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1969, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - How Code divided. 
    The ordinances comprising this Code are classified according to subject matter and placed under appropriate chapter headings. Chapters of this Code are, in some instances, further divided into articles and articles are sometimes divided into divisions. In a few instances, subdivisions have been used. Each chapter, article, division and subdivision is composed of individual sections of similar subject matter. 
(Code 1969, § 1-4.1) 
Sec. 1-6. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1969, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.9. 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing offenses. 
(a)  Misdemeanors are classified, for the purposes of fines or imprisonment, into four classes, as follows: 
(1)  Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(2)  Class 2 misdemeanor. 
(3)  Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(4)  Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(b)  The authorized punishments for conviction of a misdemeanor are: 
(1)  For class 1 misdemeanors, confinement in jail for not more than 12 months and a fine of not more than $2,500.00, either or both. 
(2)  For class 2 misdemeanors, confinement in jail for not more than six months and a fine of not more than $1,000.00, either or both. 
(3)  For class 3 misdemeanors, a fine of not more than $500.00. 
(4)  For class 4 misdemeanors, a fine of not more than $250.00. 
(c)  Wherever in this Code or any other ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, and no specific penalty is provided for the violation thereof, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(d)  Penalties in this Code or in other ordinances of the city shall not exceed the penalties prescribed by general law for a like offense. 
(e)  Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the city shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. Offenses defined in this Code for which punishment is prescribed without specification as to the class of the offense shall be punished according to the punishment in the section defining the offense. 
(Code 1969, § 9-1) 
Charter reference- Power of municipal corporation relative to penalties for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-901, as adopted by Charter, § 2.2. 
State Law reference- Power of council to prescribe fines or other punishment for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-13; enforcement of ordinances and regulations, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-901 et seq.; penalty for conviction of misdemeanor, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-11; payment of fines and costs on installment basis, etc., Code of Virginia, § 19.2-354 et seq. 
Sec. 1-8. - Corporate seal of city; execution of bonds, etc. 
(a)  The corporate seal of the city shall be a circle 13/4 inches in diameter, and just inside the outer rim of the circle the words "SALEM, VIRGINIA" with the design of a dove of peace carrying an olive branch in the center. On a flag, such seal shall be centered on a field of white with the dove of peace, circle and the words "Salem, Virginia" in gold against a background of royal blue. 
(b)  No other seal than that specified in subsection (a) shall be used as the official seal of the city until such seal shall have been changed by competent authority. Every paper issued by municipal authority requiring the city seal shall have affixed thereto the seal described in subsection (a). All bonds, contracts, deeds and other papers shall be executed in the name of the city by the mayor and the city seal shall be affixed and attested by the city clerk. 
(Code 1969, § 1-6) 
Charter reference- Authority of city with reference to corporate seal, § 1.1. 
Sec. 1-9. - Construction of repeal of former ordinance. 
    No new ordinance shall be construed to repeal a former ordinance, as to any offense committed against the former ordinance, or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred, or any right accrued, or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued, or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect. 
(Code 1969, § 2-14) 
Charter reference- Ordinances and resolutions, ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to state laws, Code of Virginia, § 1-16. 
Sec. 1-10. - Revival of repealed ordinance upon repeal of repealing ordinance. 
    When any ordinance which has repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect, unless the ordinance repealing it is passed during the same session of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-15) 
Sec. 1-11. - Certain provisions saved from repeal. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall repeal the following, when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issue of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any annual tax levy or appropriation ordinance; 
(3)  Any right or franchise conferred by ordinance or resolution of the city on any person or corporation; 
(4)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(5)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
(6)  Any ordinance relating to the salaries of city officers or employees; 
(7)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city; 
(8)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city; 
(9)  Any ordinance relating to the zoning plan map; 
(10)  The schedule of license fees; 
(11)  Any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered prior to the effective date of this Code; 
(12)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
and all such provisions shall remain in full force and effect as if set out fully in this Code. 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by municipal personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them in a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated in the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted in the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-13. - Courthouse security assessment. 
    As authorized by Section 53.1-120, Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, effective November 1, 2002, the clerks of the city's district and circuit courts, respectively, shall assess and collect the sum of $10.00 as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in which the Defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance. Such sums shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the case is heard, remitted to the city treasurer, and be he1d by the treasurer, subject to appropriation by city council to the sheriff's office for the funding of courthouse personnel. 
(Ord. of 10-14-02; Ord. of 7-28-03; Ord. of 6-11-07, eff. July 1, 2007) 
Sec. 1-14. - Fee for inmate processing. 
    Pursuant to authority granted in Code of Virginia § 15.2-1613.1, there is hereby assessed a sum of $25.00 as a part of court costs collected by the clerk of any city court from any individual admitted to the Roanoke County-Salem Jail or the Western Virginia Regional Jail following a conviction. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the case is heard, remitted to the treasurer of the city and shall be used by the sheriff's office to defray the costs of processing arrested persons into the Roanoke County-Salem Jail or the Western Regional Jail. 
(Ord. of 9-13-2010(3), eff. 10-1-2010) 
Sec. 1-15. - Assessment for electronic summons system. 
    Pursuant to authority granted in Section 17.1-279.1 of the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, the clerks of the city's district and circuit courts, respectfully, shall assess and collect the sum of $5.00 as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in which a defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance. This assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, remitted to the treasurer of the city and held by such treasurer subject to disbursements by city council to the city police department solely to fund software, hardware and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
(Ord. of 8-25-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 8-25-2014 shall be in full force and effect on October 1, 2014. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Electrical inspector, § 18-186 et seq.; plumbing inspector, § 18-286 et seq.; license inspector, § 22-56; elections, ch. 26; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; fair housing board, § 42-61 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 46; library, ch. 50; planning, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; taxation, ch. 82; board of real estate tax relief review, § 82-48; powers and duties of school board relative to traffic and parking, § 86-5; utilities, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- The Virginia Freedom of Information Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-340 et seq.; State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-639.1 et seq.; Virginia Public Procurement Act, Code of Virginia, § 11-35 et seq.; liability insurance or self-insurance for officers, employees, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1518; photographing, recording, etc., of records, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1412; purchase of recycled paper, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-938; municipal ordinances generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1427; fiscal year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500; creation of service districts, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2400; fee for bad checks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106; oath of local officers, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1522, 49-1; budget procedures, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500 et seq.; Public Finance Act of 1991, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2600 et seq.; Virginia Public Records Act, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-76 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Purchases in emergency cases; purchases exceeding $500.00. 
    The purchasing agent may, in emergency cases, make purchases in any department of the city government not to exceed $500.00 without specific permission from the council. For any purchases in excess of this amount, an order of the council shall be required. 
(Code 1969, § 2-56) 
Charter reference- City manager as purchasing agent, § 5.2(i). 
Sec. 2-2. - Transportation safety commission. 
    There is hereby created the Salem Transportation Safety Commission which shall consist of six members, one of whom shall be a member of the council of the city. The members shall be appointed for staggered terms of four years. No member shall be appointed for more than two four-year terms. 
(Code 1969, § 2-4.1) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
Secs. 2-3-2-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Election of councilmen, § 3.1; composition of council and terms of councilmen, § 4.1; eligibility for office of councilman, § 4.2; filling of vacancies on council, § 4.3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-36. - When regular meetings held. 
    The regular meetings of the council shall be held on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at 7:30 p.m.; should, however, any Monday on which a regular council meeting is scheduled to be held fall on a day designated as a legal holiday as fixed, defined and set forth in Code of Virginia, § 2.1-21, as amended, such council meeting shall be held on the following Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. of such day. 
(Code 1969, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- Council meetings, quorum, § 4.6. 
Sec. 2-37. - Exercise of power conferred on city; passage of ordinances relative to municipal affairs. 
    The council shall have full power and authority to exercise all the powers conferred upon the city and to pass ordinances relating to its municipal affairs, subject to the Constitution and general laws of the state and of the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-38. - Election, term and powers of vice-chairman. 
    On the July 1 following each regular municipal election, or if such day is a Sunday, then on the day following, the council shall elect one of its members as vice-chairman, who shall be ex officio vice-mayor. He shall be elected for a term of two years and when the mayor is absent or for any reason cannot act or perform such duties as mayor, he shall be invested with all the powers conferred upon the mayor. 
(Code 1969, § 2-3) 
Charter reference- Performance of duties of the mayor, during the absence or disability of the mayor, by another member of the council appointed by the council, § 4.4. 
Sec. 2-39. - Transfer of power in absence of mayor or vice-mayor. 
    In the absence or in case of the disability of both the mayor and vice-mayor, one of the other councilmembers shall be clothed with and shall have all the powers conferred upon the mayor and vice-mayor. 
(Code 1969, § 2-4) 
Secs. 2-40-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES FOR PROCEEDINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of council to determine its own rules of procedure, § 4.8. 

Sec. 2-56. - Order of proceedings at regular meetings of council. 
    At a regular meeting of the council, the order of proceedings shall be as follows: 
(1)  Roll call. 
(2)  Reading and correction, if any, of the minutes of the preceding regular or special meeting or meetings. 
(3)  Reports of city officials. 
(4)  Reports of committees. 
(5)  Unfinished business. 
(6)  Communications and new business. 
(Code 1969, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-57. - Record of proceedings. 
(a)  The clerk of council shall keep a minute book wherein shall be kept a record of the proceedings of the council. The record of the proceedings of the council shall be authenticated by the signature of the presiding officer and the clerk of council. 
(b)  Unless a reading of the minutes of a council meeting is requested by a member of the council, such minutes may be approved without reading if the clerk of council has previously furnished each member with a copy thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 2-6) 
Charter reference- Council to keep a journal of its proceedings, § 4.8. 
Sec. 2-58. - Book for transcription of general and permanent ordinances. 
    The council shall have all ordinances of a general and permanent nature transcribed into a book, which book shall be known as the "General Ordinance Book." 
(Code 1969, § 2-7) 
Sec. 2-59. - Introduction generally and withdrawal. 
    The name of the member of the council offering an ordinance, resolution or proposition to the council shall be recorded in the minute book, if the member so desires. The ordinance, resolution or proposition shall be stated by the chair before being acted on and the ordinance, resolution or proposition may be withdrawn by the mover before amendment or before action is had thereon by the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-8) 
Sec. 2-60. - Majority vote required for passage of ordinance, etc. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the Charter, an affirmative vote of a majority of the members elected to the council shall be necessary to adopt any ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1969, § 2-9) 
Sec. 2-61. - Appeal from decisions of chair. 
    An appeal to the council may be taken from any decision of the chair. Such appeal may be debated and the decision of the chair shall be final unless three-fifths of the members present vote against the decision. 
(Code 1969, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-62. - Compelling attendance of members. 
    Any member of the council may compel the attendance of any absent member at any meeting of the council by serving a written notice upon the absent member to attend at once. The absent member may at the discretion of the council be fined $5.00, which shall be entered on the minutes of the council and be deducted from his salary; or in case there is no salary due him, the penalty may be collected by a suit against him, brought in the name of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-11) 
Charter reference- Power of council to compel attendance of absentees, § 4.6. 
Sec. 2-63. - Unauthorized withdrawal of member from council chamber. 
    No member of the council after being marked "present" shall absent himself from the council chamber or withdraw from such meeting unless a majority of the councilmembers present by actual vote grant him leave to withdraw from the meeting. Any member violating this section shall, in the discretion of a majority of the council, be subject to a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $10.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1969, § 2-12) 
Charter reference- Power of council to compel attendance of absentees, § 4.6. 
Sec. 2-64. - Recordation of ayes and nays. 
    At the request of any member of the council present at a meeting of the council, the ayes and nays on any question shall be recorded upon the minutes of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-13) 
Secs. 2-65-2-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- City officers and employees generally, § 6.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Hindering, obstructing, etc., city officers, etc, § 58-16. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-86. - Causes for removal from office of officer appointed by council. 
    The council may remove from office any officer appointed by it for malfeasance, misfeasance, neglect of duty, incapacity or other good cause. 
(Code 1969, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-87. - Payment of claims against city. 
(a)  Payments by the city shall be made only upon vouchers certified to by the head of the appropriate department or other division of the city government, and by means of warrants on the city treasurer, issued by the appropriate city officer and countersigned by the city manager; except, that when the city manager acts as director of finance, then such warrants shall be issued by the city treasurer and countersigned by the city manager. 
(b)  The director of finance or the city treasurer, if the city manager is acting as director of finance, shall examine all payrolls, bills and other claims and demands against the city and shall issue no warrant for payment unless he finds that the claim is in proper form, correctly computed and duly certified, that it is justly and legally due and payable and that an appropriation has been made therefor which has not been exhausted, or that the payment has been otherwise legally authorized, and that there is money in the city treasury to make payment. He may require any claimant to make oath to the validity of a claim. He may investigate any claim, and for such purpose may examine witnesses under oath and if he finds it is fraudulent, erroneous or otherwise invalid, shall not issue a warrant therefor. 
(Code 1969, § 2-16.1) 
Sec. 2-88. - Disclosure statements required to be filed. 
    In addition to those officials specified in Code of Virginia, § 2.1-639.14, as amended, the following city employees shall file the disclosure statement required in Code of Virginia, § 2.1-639.14: the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 2-16.2) 
Secs. 2-89-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MERIT SYSTEM; DISCRIMINATION AND POLITICAL ACTIVITY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Adoption of powers of municipal corporation as to retirement systems (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-849), § 2.2. 

Sec. 2-111. - Establishment of merit system. 
    In order to establish an equitable and uniform procedure for dealing with personnel matters, and to place municipal employment on a merit basis so that the best qualified persons available shall be brought into the service of the city, a municipal merit system is hereby established. 
(Code 1969, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-112. - Establishment of office of personnel; personnel director as head; responsibilities generally of personnel director. 
(a)  There is hereby established an office of personnel, which office shall be headed by a personnel director. The city manager shall act as personnel director. 
(b)  The personnel director shall be responsible for the following: 
(1)  The administration of all provisions of this division not specifically reserved to council. 
(2)  The performance of all duties essential to the effective administration of the personnel system. 
(3)  The preparation of rules for the consideration of council implementing the personnel system. 
(4)  The administration of such rules. 
(5)  The preparation and revision of a pay plan for the consideration and approval of council, which plan shall constitute the official schedule of compensation for all merit system employees. 
(6)  The certification of payrolls. 
(7)  The maintenance of an official roster of officers and employees and such other records as may be required. 
(Code 1969, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-113. - Application of merit system to city officers and employees. 
(a)  This division shall apply to all persons employed by or connected with the city except the following: 
(1)  Those persons elected to municipal offices and those appointed to fill vacancies in such offices. 
(2)  Those persons occupying positions on appointive boards, commissions and committees. 
(b)  Officers, employees and persons not exempted in subsection (a) shall be under the city merit system; provided, however, that those persons occupying positions created by the Charter and filled by council appointment, department heads and those other employees exempt or partially exempt by the rules adopted pursuant to this division shall be governed by only those provisions of this division which clearly apply to them as interpreted and applied by the rules established under this division. 
(Code 1969, § 2-19) 
Sec. 2-114. - Formulation and adoption by council of procedural rules. 
    In addition to such other matters as may be necessary and proper to carry out the intent and purposes of this division, reasonable rules shall be formulated and adopted by council establishing specific procedures in connection with the following: 
(1)  The preparation and administration of a position classification plan covering all merit system positions. 
(2)  The preparation and administration of a pay plan covering all merit system positions. 
(3)  The announcement of vacancies and the acceptance of applications for employment. 
(4)  The examination of applicants. 
(5)  The appointment of persons to fill vacancies and provisions for temporary appointments. 
(6)  The evaluation and merit rating of employees and provisions for probationary periods. 
(7)  The transfer, promotion, demotion, suspension and reinstatement of employees. 
(8)  The separation of employees through resignation, layoff and dismissal. 
(9)  The establishment of hours of work, attendance and leave regulations, disciplinary measures, working conditions, outside employment and development of employee morale, welfare and training. 
(10)  The maintenance and use of necessary records and forms. 
(Code 1969, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-115. - Appointments to positions of city employment generally. 
    Appointments to positions of city employment shall be of two types: permanent and temporary. Permanent employees shall have tenure as set forth in the rules formulated and adopted as provided in section 2-114, but temporary employees shall have no tenure or other privileges, as set forth in such rules. Appointments shall be made on the basis of merit and in accordance with procedures set forth in such rules. Appointments shall be made by the city manager, or by department heads upon approval of the city manager, as set forth in the provisions of such rules applicable. 
(Code 1969, § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-116. - Discrimination because of political opinion, etc. 
    No employee or person seeking employment with the city shall in any way be favored or discriminated against because of political opinions or affiliations, race, color, religious belief, sex or national origin. 
(Code 1969, § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-117. - Political activity-Generally. 
    Nothing in this Code shall prohibit or restrict the political activity of any city employee, except: 
(1)  Activities restricted under section 2-118 shall continue to be restricted. 
(2)  No fulltime employee shall participate in any political activity during his working hours. 
(3)  No fulltime employee shall participate in any political activity at any time while wearing a distinctive uniform, or other apparel, which is identifiable with the city. 
(4)  Electioneering in any city office, building or premises is prohibited; however, any activity not prohibited by the state election laws on the day of a primary or an election shall not be prohibited at polling places on city property. Also, these restrictions shall not apply to a mass meeting or a committee meeting of a political organization on city property having the permission of the city manager. 
(5)  The display of any political advertising material of any nature at any time in or on any property owned by the city is prohibited. 
(6)  Any fulltime employee shall be required to take a 30-day leave of absence prior to any primary, special or general election in which he is an announced candidate. This 30-day leave of absence may include any authorized leave due such employee. Otherwise, such leave of absence shall be without pay. 
(Code 1969, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-118. - Same-Solicitation of contributions, etc. 
    No fulltime employee, whether under the merit system or not, shall, for any political purpose whatsoever, either directly or indirectly, solicit or receive or be in any manner concerned in soliciting or receiving any assessment, subscription or contribution, whether voluntary or involuntary, from any applicant for city employ or from or for the benefit of any person who may be a candidate for any municipal office, appointive or elective, or who is now occupying such office or who is at present an employee of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-119. - Discharge of officer or employee for violation of division, etc. 
(a)  Any violation of this division or of the rules formulated and adopted under section 2-114 shall be sufficient grounds for the discharge of any officer or employee guilty of such violation. 
(b)  Any person who, by himself or with others, violates the provisions of section 2-117 or 2-118 shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. Any person who is convicted under this section shall for a period of five years be ineligible for appointment to or employment in a position in the city service and shall, if he is an employee of the city, immediately forfeit the position he holds. 
(Code 1969, § 2-31) 
Secs. 2-120-2-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS 

Sec. 2-146. - Creation of certain departments. 
    The following administrative departments of the city are hereby created: 
(1)  Law. 
(2)  Finance. 
(3)  General governmental administration. 
(4)  Judicial administration. 
(5)  Public safety. 
(6)  Public works. 
(7)  Health and welfare. 
(8)  Parks, recreation and cultural. 
(9)  Community development. 
(10)  Public utilities. 
(11)  Engineering. 
(Code 1969, § 2-31.1; Ord. of 11-11-91(2)) 
Sec. 2-147. - Department heads; power of council as to functions, creation and combination of departments. 
(a)  At the head of each department of the city government there shall be a director; provided, that unless and until the city council shall otherwise provide by ordinance, the city manager shall be director of all departments except the department of law. Unless and until otherwise provided by ordinance, the city attorney shall be director of the department of law. 
(b)  The city council shall, by ordinance, determine and prescribe the functions of each department, and may create new departments, combine or abolish existing departments and establish new departments when, in its opinion, the proper administration of the city requires it. 
(c)  Except the directors of the department of law, who shall be appointed by and be immediately responsible to the city council, the director of each department shall be appointed by and be immediately responsible to the city manager for the administration of his department. Each director shall be chosen on the basis of his general executive and administrative experience and ability, and his education, training and experience in the class of work which he is to administer. 
(Code 1969, § 2-31.2; Ord. of 12-14-92(1)) 
Secs. 2-148-2-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- City manager, § 5.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-176. - Duties generally. 
    The duties of the city manager shall be such as are prescribed by the Charter and by the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city applying thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-177. - Duties as to engineering, etc., work. 
    The city manager shall be in charge of all engineering work of the city and shall be responsible to the council for all work done by contract or otherwise. He shall see that all work on its completion is properly inspected and he shall make and present to the council a report showing the location, character and cost of all work done by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-178. - Duties as to violations of Code, etc., and as to encroachments upon streets, etc. 
    The city manager shall take notice of any violation of this Code or other ordinances of the city as well as encroachment of buildings, walls or fences upon the streets, alleys or other public property and report such violations or encroachments to the council for such action as may be proper. 
(Code 1969, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-179. - Duties as to permits and work done pursuant thereto. 
    The city manager, or his duly authorized representative, shall issue and keep a record of all permits for connection with the water mains, sewers and electric light lines and for any other purposes whatever, and shall see that work done under such permits is carried out in a proper manner. 
(Code 1969, § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-180. - Authority to transfer funds. 
    The city manager may make or cause to be made transfers of funds within or between the several departments and divisions set forth in the annual appropriation ordinance. The city manager is further authorized to transfer funds within a department as may be necessary to meet unexpected obligations. 
(Ord. of 11-11-91(1)) 
Sec. 2-181. - Assistant city manager. 
    The office of assistant city manager is hereby created. The assistant city manager shall, during the absence or disability of the city manager, perform all the duties of the office of city manager and more especially shall be invested with the powers and charged with the duties as are set forth in the Charter and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-37) 
Charter reference- Authority of city council to appoint assistant city manager, § 5.1. 
Secs. 2-182-2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE 

Sec. 2-201. - Creation of office; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of the director of finance. The director of finance shall be appointed by and be immediately responsible to the city manager as provided in section 2-147. 
(Code 1969, § 2-37.1; Ord. of 12-14-92(2)) 
Sec. 2-202. - Powers and duties. 
    The director of finance shall have direct supervision over the department of finance and administration of the financial affairs of the city, including the keeping of accounts and financial records, the collection of taxes, special assessments and other revenues, the custody and disbursements of city funds and monies, and shall perform such other duties as the city council may by ordinance provide. 
(Code 1969, § 2-37.2) 
Sec. 2-203. - Purchasing. 
    The director of finance shall, in addition to the duties prescribed in section 2-202, have supervision over the city purchasing agent. 
(Code 1969, § 2-37.3) 
Charter reference- City manager to act as purchasing agent until otherwise provided by city council, § 5.2(i).

Sec. 2-232. - Assistant city attorney.

The assistant city attorney may not only represent the city in all legal matters during the absence or incapacity of the city attorney, but he may also represent the city in conjunction with or at the request of the city attorney or the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-39)

ARTICLE VIII. - CLERK OF COUNCIL[8] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-256. - Minute book for council and book for general and permanent ordinances. 
    It shall be the duty of the clerk of council to keep the general ordinance book, as referred to in section 2-58. It shall be the duty of the clerk of council to provide this book and the minute book with proper indexes. 
(Code 1969, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-257. - Custody of contracts, etc. 
    The clerk of council shall be the custodian of all contracts taken by order of the council, and any papers which are required to be filed or kept by him. 
(Code 1969, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-258. - Issuance of notices. 
    The clerk of council shall issue notices to property owners of contemplated improvements and of hearings before the council or any committee of the council, to be given such owners as provided in the Charter or by law, and shall issue such other notices as the council may direct. 
(Code 1969, § 2-42) 
State Law reference- Notice of assessment for local improvements, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-243 et seq.

ARTICLE IX. - CITY TREASURER 

Sec. 2-286. - Deposit of monies, etc.; depositories. 
    All monies or funds collected by the city treasurer as city treasurer shall be deposited to the credit of the city in the Bank of Shawsville, Central Fidelity Bank, Charter Federal Savings and Loan, Coreast Savings Bank, Crestar Bank, Dominion Bank, First Virginia Bank Roanoke-West, Salem Bank and Trust, Signet Bank, and Virginia First Savings and Loan, which banks are hereby designated as depositories for all funds of the city. In addition, the following are authorized to collect city utility bills under procedures approved by the director of finance: General Electric Employees Federal Credit Union, Roanoke County Schools Employees Federal Credit Union, and Veterans Administration Employees Federal Credit Union. 
(Code 1969, § 2-44) 
Sec. 2-287. - Forms for withdrawal of funds from depositories. 
    All withdrawals of funds of the city from the depositories designated in section 2-286 shall be made by checks, warrants, vouchers or other forms as shall be prescribed by proper resolutions of the council. 
(Code 1969, § 2-45) 
Sec. 2-288. - Execution of warrants, etc. 
    Subject to section 2-87, all checks, warrants, vouchers and other forms for the withdrawal of funds of the city from depositories designated in section 2-286 shall be signed by the city treasurer and countersigned by the city manager, and in the absence of the city manager, such checks, warrants and vouchers shall be countersigned by the mayor or other councilmember. 
(Code 1969, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-289. - Record of disbursements. 
    The city treasurer shall keep a record of all disbursements in a book so ruled as to show, in separate columns: 
(1)  The number of the warrant; 
(2)  Date; 
(3)  Amount; 
(4)  Name of drawee; and 
(5)  From what fund and on what account paid. 
(Code 1969, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-290. - Account of monies received from special assessment. 
    The city treasurer shall keep a separate and distinct account of all monies received by him from special assessments for streets, sidewalks or other purposes. Such account shall show from whom the several amounts are received, when received, for what purpose and on what lot or parcel of land such assessment is paid. 
(Code 1969, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-291. - Books to show condition of bonded and floating debt, etc. 
    The books of the city treasurer shall show: 
(1)  The condition of the funds of the city; 
(2)  The condition and amount of the bonded and floating debt of the city; and 
(3)  Any and all other accounts and statements necessary to a true and correct understanding of the financial condition of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-49) 
Sec. 2-292. - Additional accounts and financial records. 
    In addition to the accounts and financial records otherwise required to be kept by him, the city treasurer shall cause to be kept such other accounts and financial records in relation to the performance of his duties and in such manner as the director of finance may prescribe and as in his judgment may be necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 2-50) 
Sec. 2-293. - Books, accounts, etc., to be subject to inspection. 
    The books and accounts of the city treasurer and all papers relating to the financial transactions of the city shall at all times be subject to the inspection of the city manager or any member of the council or any person whom the council may appoint to examine such books and accounts and papers. 
(Code 1969, § 2-51) 
Sec. 2-294. - Monthly report. 
    The city treasurer shall, at one regular council meeting per month, submit to the council a written report, showing: 
(1)  All receipts and disbursements for the entire preceding month; 
(2)  The balance of monies on hand; and 
(3)  The exact state of the treasury on the last day of the preceding month. 
(Code 1969, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-295. - Annual report. 
    At the last meeting of the council in each fiscal year, the city treasurer shall present to the council an annual report containing a full itemized statement of all receipts and disbursements from the date of the last preceding annual report and showing the precise condition of the treasury. 
(Code 1969, § 2-53) 
Sec. 2-296. - Assistant city treasurer. 
    The office of assistant city treasurer is hereby created. The assistant city treasurer shall, during the absence or disability of the city treasurer, perform all the duties of the office of city treasurer and more especially shall be invested with the powers and charged with the duties as are set forth in the Charter and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 2-54) 
Charter reference- Power of city council to appoint deputies and assistants to city officers, § 6.2. 
Secs. 2-297-2-318. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FEE FOR SERVICES 

Sec. 2-319. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings as set forth in this section, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ambulance shall mean any publicly or privately owned vehicle that is specially designed, constructed or modified and equipped for and is intended to be used for and is maintained or operated to provide immediate medical care to or transport of persons who are sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Emergency shall mean an unforeseen condition or circumstance in which there is a need for immediate medical care in order to prevent loss of life or aggravation of illness or injury. 
    Emergency medical services vehicle shall mean an ambulance, rescue squad vehicle, fire truck or other government owned vehicle which may be used for or is maintained or operated to provide immediate medical care to or transport of persons who are sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Patient shall mean an individual who is sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Permit shall mean a permit issued by the City Manager or his designee, authorizing the operation of an ambulance. 
    Person shall mean an individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, group of individuals acting together for a common purpose, or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-320. - Charges for ambulance services. 
    City council may establish by resolution, upon recommendation of the city manager, reasonable fees for the provision of emergency medical services by all emergency medical service personnel, whether volunteers or paid public employees, and by all private ambulances operating under a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-321. - Permit required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated a private ambulance or emergency medical services vehicle from within the city to any other location within or outside the city, unless such person possesses a permit. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee, is authorized to determine and prescribe the areas of service within which a permit holder may operate within the city so as to assure adequate coverage throughout the geographical area of the city. Further, the number of permits for ambulances or emergency medical service vehicles in the city may be limited to achieve the objectives of this article. 
(c)  No permit shall be required for operation of a private ambulance or emergency medical services vehicle which is: 
(1)  Engaged in the transportation of a person from a point beyond the limits of the city to a location within the city; or 
(2)  Engaged in the transportation of a person through the city. 
(d)  No permit shall be required for operation of a private ambulance or emergency medical services vehicle when used to render assistance, at the request of the city, in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency with which the vehicles which have received a permit to operate in the city are insufficient or unable to cope. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-322. - Volunteer rescue squads and governmental agencies. 
    Volunteer rescue squads and the members thereof who are acting in such capacity and agencies of the city and their employees who are acting in any capacity of emergency services shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-323. - Permit-Application. 
    Any person who desires a permit shall file a sworn application with the city manager, or his designee, on a form prepared and provided for that purpose. The application shall include evidence of compliance with the terms and provisions of this chapter and such other information as the city manager, or his designee, shall require. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-324. - Same-Requirements. 
    No person shall be issued a permit unless he: 
(1)  Furnishes proof that he possesses a valid permit issued by the commonwealth to operate an ambulance or emergency medical services vehicle. 
(2)  Files a schedule of rates to be charged for services rendered under the permit which shall not be less than the charges authorized by section 2-320. 
(3)  Agrees in writing to comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter, other provisions of this Code, any reasonable rules and regulations developed by the city manager or his/her designee for the implementation of this article, and applicable state and federal laws and regulations. 
(4)  Agrees in writing to provide mutual aide assistance, if available, in any emergency situation upon the request of the city. 
(5)  Provides an appropriate certificate of insurance, or certificate of self-insurance where appropriate, indicating the following minimum coverages: motor vehicular liability insurance of $100,000.00 per occurrence and $300,000.00 aggregate and general liability insurance of $100,000.00 per occurrence and $300,000.00 aggregate. The certificate of insurance shall contain a clause obligating the company issuing the same to give 15 days notice in writing to the city manager before the cancellation of such policies. The city shall be named as an additional insured on such policies of insurance as its interests may appear. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-325. - Same-Issuance or denial. 
(a)  The city manager, or his designee, upon consideration of the requirements set forth in this chapter, shall grant or deny the request for permit. The decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be in writing and he/she shall mail a copy thereof to the applicant at the address listed on his/her application. 
(b)  Any person who is denied a permit by a decision of the city manager may appeal the same to city council by written notice filed with the clerk of the council within 30 calendar days of mailing of the city manager's decision. Upon proper filing of such appeal, after such notice and hearing as city council may deem appropriate, the council may affirm, reverse, or modify the city manager's decision, or may remand the matter for further investigation or action. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-326. - Duty to give notice of change of circumstances. 
    The applicant for a permit or, if a permit has been granted, the holder of a permit shall immediately give notice in writing to the city manager of any change in the information set forth in the application for permit, including, without limitation, any change in rates, insurance coverage, or the ownership of 50 percent or more of the common stock of the corporation which has applied for or has received the permit. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-327. - Current holders of certificates of public convenience and necessity. 
    Any person, who, on the effective date of this ordinance, holds a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the city or the commonwealth licensing the operation of an ambulance or vehicle for the transportation of handicapped persons may, for a period of 60 calendar days after the effective date of this article, continue to operate same within the city. Thereafter such person shall be required to have a permit issued by the city manager, or his designee. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-328. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
(a)  Any permit issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the city manager, or his designee, after a hearing, for failure to comply with the provisions of Title 31.2, Chapter 4, Article 2.1 of the Code of Virginia or of this chapter of any other provisions of local, state or federal law or regulation. Such hearing shall be held after ten calendar days prior written notice, mailed to the permit holder at the address listed on his application or any subsequent written notification of change of address. After the hearing, the city manager, or his designee, shall render his decision in writing and shall mail a copy thereof to the permit holder at the address described above. The decision of the city manager, or his designee, shall be effective as of the date established in his decision and shall not be stayed pending the outcome of any appeal. 
(b)  Any permit holder affected by an adverse decision of the city manager may appeal the same to city council by written notice filed with the clerk of the council within 30 calendar days of mailing of the city manager's final decision. Upon proper filing of such appeal, after such notice and hearing as city council may deem appropriate, the council may affirm, reverse, or modify the city manager's decision, or may remand the matter for further investigation or action. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-329. - Sale, assignment, etc. prohibited. 
    No permit granted under this chapter may be sold, assigned, or transferred, nor shall it in any way vest in any person, other than the applicant to whom the permit is granted, any rights or privileges under the permit. For purposes of this section, the transfer of ownership of 50 percent or more of the common stock of a corporation which has been granted a permit shall be deemed to be a transfer of the permit. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-330. - Authorization to provide non-emergency services; response to emergencies permitted under limited conditions. 
(a)  The holder of a permit shall be authorized to respond to requests for non-emergency service. Response to emergencies shall not be permitted unless: 
(1)  A request is made by the patient or by someone on behalf of the patient. 
(2)  A request is made by an authorized representative of the city. 
(3)  A condition is coincidentally observed by the owner or operator of the ambulance which requires immediate attention. 
(b)  A permit holder who provides ambulance or emergency medical service under emergency conditions shall give immediate notice of such response at the time of response to the city's emergency dispatch/E-911 center. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-331. - Operations within the city. 
(a)  As a condition of the permit, the permit holder agrees to provide service throughout the geographic area designated by the permits. 
(b)  No permit holder shall refuse to transport any person in the city to any hospital emergency room, approved by the city manager or his/her designee, in the city or an adjoining city or county without just cause. For purposes of this section, the term "just cause" shall include unavailability of qualified personnel or vehicles and the inability or refusal of the patient to pay for the requested ambulance service. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-332. - Service logs. 
    Every permit holder shall maintain accurate service logs of operations undertaken in accordance with its permit. Such service logs shall include, with regard to each request for ambulance service, the time and date the request was received, the location of the patient on whose behalf the request was made, the time the ambulance arrived at the location, the destination and time of arrival at the destination. If the request was denied, the log shall indicate the reason for such denial. In addition, the service log shall include any other information required by the chief of the fire department or the city manager. Such logs shall be maintained for a period of three years and made available for inspection by authorized representatives of the city upon reasonable request. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Sec. 2-333. - Powers and responsibilities of the city manager. 
    The city manager, or his designee, is hereby authorized to exercise the following powers and responsibilities in order to effectively achieve the purposes of this article, as follows: 
(1)  To enter into contracts with any person for the administration and collection of any fees which are imposed by the city fire department or other city agency, by any volunteer rescue squad or other non-profit organization operating under any permit granted in accordance with this article; 
(2)  To establish reasonable rules and procedures for imposing and collecting authorized fees for the provision of emergency medical services; 
(3)  To write off as uncollectible any accounts which are reasonably deemed to be uncollectible; and 
(4)  To exercise such other reasonable powers and authority as shall be necessary for the proper administration of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-28-04) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; intoxication in public, § 58-27; signs, ch. 66; taxation, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Local option elections, Code of Virginia, § 4-45 et seq.; local ordinances restricted, Code of Virginia, § 4-96; driving under influence of alcoholic beverages, drugs, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-132; determining alcohol or drug content of blood, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-268; incorporation by reference of certain offenses, traffic rules, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313. 

Sec. 6-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted December 9, 1996, deleted § 6-1. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this section be and the same are hereby repealed. Formerly, such section pertained to licenses and derived from Ord. No. 11-24-80, § 14-46. 
Sec. 6-2. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in city parks. 
(a)  If any person in or upon the grounds of any city park shall drink any alcoholic beverage or have in his possession any alcoholic beverage, or any beverage in any container labeled as an alcoholic beverage, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. As used in this section, the term "alcoholic beverage" shall have the meaning set forth in Code of Virginia, § 4-2. 
(b)  This section shall not prevent any person from drinking alcoholic beverages or offering a drink thereof to another in any area approved by the state alcoholic beverage control board in any local public park at an event for which a banquet license or mixed beverage special events license has been issued or prevent, upon authorization of the licensee, any person from drinking his own lawfully acquired alcoholic beverages or tendering a drink thereof to another in approved areas and locations at events for which a coliseum or stadium license has been issued. 
(Code 1969, § 17-14.1) 
State Law reference- Drinking alcoholic beverages, or tendering to another, in public place, Code of Virginia, § 4-78. 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; signs, ch. 66; taxation, ch. 82; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Bingo games and raffles, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.1 et seq.; minors in public places of amusement, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-432; public dancehalls, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-433. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC DANCEHALLS AND TEENAGE DANCEHALLS 

Sec. 10-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public dancehall means any place open to the general public where dancing is permitted; provided, however, that a restaurant licensed under Code of Virginia, §§ 4-98.1 and 4-98.2 to serve food and beverages having a dance floor with an area not exceeding ten percent of the total floor area of the establishment shall not be considered a public dancehall. 
    Teenage dancehall means any place exclusively open to those members of the general public between the ages of 13 and 19 years that is used primarily for dancing and for which an admission fee is charged or for which compensation is in any manner received. 
(Code 1969, § 3-10) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-32. - Certain dances excepted from application of article. 
    This article shall not be construed to apply to dances held for benevolent or charitable purposes or to dances conducted under the auspices of religious, educational, civic or military organizations. 
(Code 1969, § 3-11) 
Sec. 10-33. - Permit for operation, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct a public dancehall or teenage dancehall without a permit, which permit may be obtained from the city manager on satisfactory evidence that the applicant is a proper person to receive the permit. A permit issued to conduct a public dancehall shall not allow the permit holder to conduct or operate a teenage dancehall; nor shall the issuance of a permit to conduct a teenage dancehall authorize or allow the permit holder to conduct or operate a public dancehall. Such permit may be revoked at any time by the city manager upon a finding that the operation of the public dancehall or teenage dancehall contravenes public safety, peace and order, becomes a public nuisance, disturbs the peace, or upon the failure of the permit holder to comply with the requirements of this article. A permit to operate a teenage dancehall shall be valid only during the calendar year in which it is issued. 
(b)  There shall be an appeal to the council both from the action of the city manager in refusing to grant such a permit to the person applying therefor and from the action of the city manager in revoking such a permit after the granting of such permit. The appeal shall be by written application directed to the council and delivered to the clerk of council within ten days from the refusal of the city manager to grant such permit or within ten days from his revocation of such permit, as the case may be. In event of an appeal to the council, the decision of the city manager shall not be reversed unless the council is of the opinion that the city manager acted arbitrarily in the matter or without sufficient or satisfactory evidence. 
(Code 1969, § 3-12) 
Sec. 10-34. - Entry by persons under 18 in public dancehall. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person conducting a public dancehall, not specifically licensed and regulated as a teenage dancehall, to allow any person under the age of 18 years to enter or to remain in such dancehall while dancing is being conducted therein, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, or by a brother or sister over the age of 18 years, except upon the written consent of the parent or legal guardian of such minor, and in such event there shall be a separate and independent written consent for each afternoon or evening such minor enters or remains in such dancehall while dancing is being conducted therein. 
(Code 1969, § 3-13) 
Sec. 10-35. - Teenage dancehalls-Generally. 
    A special category of dancehall is hereby created and designated as a "teenage dancehall." The operation of a teenage dancehall is governed by section 10-36. 
(Code 1969, § 3-10(b)) 
Sec. 10-36. - Same-Regulation. 
(a)  No teenage dancehall shall be operated except as follows: 
(1)  A teenage dancehall may not operate prior to 12:00 noon on any given day, nor shall it operate after 12:00 midnight on any given day. At 12:00 midnight the premises shall be vacated except for registered employees. 
(2)  Persons having reached the age of 20 years or over shall not be allowed to enter a teenage dancehall unless they are an employee or a parent or legal guardian of a person attending such teenage dancehall. 
(3)  An owner or operator of a teenage dancehall may restrict admission on Sundays between the hours of 2:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. to persons age 16 and under after notification of such to the city manager. 
(4)  A copy of this section shall be posted in a prominent location inside the building or premises wherein a teenage dancehall is operated. 
(5)  Any person issued a permit to conduct a teenage dancehall shall be given a copy of this section and shall sign for and acknowledge receipt of such copy. 
(b)  The presence of persons under the influence of alcohol or other self-administered drugs or narcotics on the premises of a teenage dancehall, or the presence of alcohol, drugs or other narcotics or drug paraphernalia on the premises of a teenage dancehall shall be grounds for the automatic and immediate revocation of the permit to conduct or operate a teenage dancehall. Upon the discovery of alcohol, drug paraphernalia, narcotics or drugs or a person under the influence of alcohol, drugs or other self-administered drugs on the premises of a teenage dancehall, the city manager, assistant city manager, chief of police or his agent may cause all persons in the teenage dancehall to vacate the premises and may close the teenage dancehall. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of any permit to operate a teenage dancehall, a background investigation shall be conducted on the applicant of such teenage dancehall. All employees of such teenage dancehall shall likewise be required to have a police background investigation conducted on them. The names of all individuals who have been issued a permit to conduct or operate a teenage dancehall, along with names of all employees of such teenage dancehall, shall be maintained on file with the chief of police. 
(d)  No individual to whom a permit to operate a teenage dancehall has been issued, nor any employee of such teenage dancehall, may in any way hinder any fire prevention or law enforcement officer who wishes to inspect the premises of such teenage dancehall at any time such teenage dancehall is open. 
(Code 1969, § 3-13.1) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 46. 
Sec. 10-37. - When operation of public dancehall prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dancehall where dancing, music or entertainment of any kind is furnished or afforded, after 2:00 a.m. 
(Code 1969, § 3-14) 
Sec. 10-38. - Construction of article with reference to license taxes. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as exempting any public dancehall or teenage dancehall from the payment of a license tax now imposed or which in the future may be imposed, whether such tax is for the purpose of raising revenue or for regulatory purposes. Such license tax shall be $600.00 per annum, not proratable, on the person operating or conducting any such public dancehall or teenage dancehall. 
(Code 1969, § 3-16) 
Cross reference- License for amusements generally, § 22-60. 
Sec. 10-39. - Construction of article with reference to disturbance of the peace, etc. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as permitting any person to so conduct or operate a public dancehall or teenage dancehall as unnecessarily to disturb the peace, comfort and ordinary rest of the citizens generally residing in the neighborhood of such dancehall. 
(Code 1969, § 3-17) 
Sec. 10-40. - Operation in manner other than as is provided for in article to constitute nuisance; violation a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(a)  To conduct or to operate a public dancehall or a teenage dancehall in any manner or mode other than as is provided in this article shall, in addition to being unlawful, constitute a nuisance, and be abatable as such, and this remedy shall be considered a cumulative one, and enforceable by the city in a proper proceeding to be instituted by, and in the discretion of, the council. 
(b)  Violations of this article shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 3-15) 
Secs. 10-41-10-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BINGO GAMES AND RAFFLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Nov. 14, 1994, has been treated as superseding the provisions of former art. III, §§ 10-66-10-70, which pertained to bingo. 

Sec. 10-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Bingo means a specific game of chance played with individual cards having randomly-numbered squares ranging from one to 75, in which prizes are awarded on the basis of designated numbers on such cards conforming to a predetermined pattern of numbers selected at random. Such cards shall have five vertical rows headed respectively by the letters B.I.N.G.O., with each row having five randomly-numbered squares. 
    Building means a structure located on a single lot enclosed by a continuous exterior wall regardless of the configuration of the interior walls. 
    Calendar day means the period of 24 consecutive hours commencing at 12:01 a.m. and concluding the following 12:01 a.m. 
    Calendar week means the period of seven consecutive calendar days (as defined above) commencing at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday and ending at 12:01 a.m. the following Sunday. 
    Instant bingo means a specific game of chance played by the random selection of one or more individuals prepacked cards, with winners being determined by the preprinted appearance of the letters B.I.N.G.O. in any prescribed order on the reverse side of such card. 
    Jackpot means a bingo card played as a part of a bingo game defined in this section in which all numbers on the card are covered, each number being selected at random, and with no more than one free or "wild" number. 
    Landlord means any person or his agent, firm, association, organization, partnership, or corporation, or employee thereof, which owns and leases, or leases any premise devoted in whole or in part to the conduct of bingo games, and any person residing in the same household as a landlord. 
    Organization means any one of the following: 
(1)  A voluntary fire department or a voluntary rescue squad or auxiliary unit thereof which has been recognized by an ordinance or resolution of the city council as being a part of the safety program of the city; 
(2)  An organization operated exclusively for religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes; 
(3)  Association of war veterans or auxiliary units thereof organized in the United States; or 
(4)  A fraternal association operating under the lodge system. 
    Raffle means a lottery in which the prize is won by (i) a random drawing of the name or prearranged number of one or more persons purchasing chances or (ii) a random contest in which the winning name or preassigned number of one or more persons purchasing changes is determined by a race involving inanimate objects floating on a body of water, commonly referred to as a "duck race." However, nothing in this article shall prohibit an organization from using the state lottery department's Pick-3 number as the basis for determining the winner of a lottery. For purposes of this definition, "raffle" shall include determining the winner of a lottery by use of prepackaged pull-tab devices which are devices made completely of paper or paper products with concealed numbers or symbols that must be exposed by the player to determine wins or losses and may include the use of a seal which conceals a number or symbol that has been designated in advance as a prize winner including but not limited to pull-tab devices commonly known as a tip boards or seal cards. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.1. 
Sec. 10-67. - Annual permit required; application and processing fee; form of application. 
(a)  Prior to the commencement of any bingo game or raffle by a qualified organization as defined in this article, the organization shall obtain an annual permit from the commissioner of the revenue. The permit shall only be granted after a reasonable investigation has been conducted by the commissioner of the revenue or his authorized designee to determine that the organization is qualified and that the requirements of this article have been met. 
(b)  The application and processing fees for a bingo permit shall be a total of $200.00. The application and processing fees for a raffle permit shall be a total of $25.00. The application and processing fees for a pull-tab raffle permit shall be $200.00. Application for the permit shall be accompanied by a check in the amount of the application and processing fee payable to the treasurer. The bingo application fee may be waived by city council for those applicants certifying that the permit will be utilized only for conducting a one-day event per calendar year. 
(c)  Application for an annual permit shall be made on a form provided by the commissioner of the revenue. No permit shall be issued without all the information required by the form prescribed by the commissioner of the revenue. The form must be signed by all appropriate parties in the presence of the commissioner of the revenue or his designee. The application shall be a matter of public record. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.2. 
Sec. 10-68. - Requirement of issuance of permit; where valid; duration; permits subject to regulations. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of any permit, the applicant organization shall meet each of the following requirements: 
(1)  Except for recently established volunteer fire and rescue companies or departments, as defined in this article, the organization shall have been in existence and met on a regular basis in the City of Roanoke, City of Salem, or County of Roanoke for a period of at least five years immediately prior to applying for a permit. The organization shall have a membership consisting of at least 50 percent residents of the commonwealth and shall furnish a complete list of its membership, identifying permanent place of residence for each member, in order for the local governing body to ascertain the percentage of state residents. In no case shall be the organization apply for or receive more than one permit. However, this requirement shall not apply (i) to any lodge or chapter of a national or international fraternal order or a national or international civic organization which is exempt under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code and which has a lodge or chapter holding a bingo permit issued in accordance with the Code of Virginia anywhere within this commonwealth, or (ii) where the commission of the revenue provides for the issuance of a bingo or raffle permit for school sponsored activities to booster clubs which have been operating for less than five years, and which have been established solely to raise funds for school-sponsored activities in public schools which are less than five years old. 
(2)  A permit shall be valid only in the city and only at the locations designated in the permit application.
