However, a permit may be issued to an organization which relocates its meeting place on a permanent basis from one jurisdiction to another and complies with the requirements of subsection (1) of this section and provided further that the organization was the holder of a valid permit at the time of its relocation. An organization which has obtained a permit under this article to conduct a raffle may sell raffle tickets both in and out of the city and may conducts its drawing either in the jurisdiction in which a majority of the tickets were sold or in the city, except that pull-tab devices as defined in section 10-66 used as part of a raffle may be sold only upon the premises owned or exclusively leased by such organization and at such times as it is not open to the public, except to members and their guests. 
(3)  The organization shall be operating as a nonprofit organization and shall have always been operated in the past as a nonprofit organization for a period of at least five years immediately prior to seeking a permit as hereinafter provided. 
(4)  Any organization whose gross receipts from all bingo or raffle operations exceed or can be expected to exceed $75,000.00 in any calendar year shall have been granted tax-exempt status pursuant to Section 501C of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
(5)  Any organization which rents or leases property for the purpose of conducting bingo games or raffles must, as a condition of obtaining a permit, obtain as part of their lease permission of the owner of the rental property to the commissioner of the revenue or his designee, or any law enforcement officer to enter the property for an inspection of records and/or to monitor the conduct of the bingo game or raffle pursuant to section 10-71. 
(6)  An organization shall designate an individual who shall be responsible for filing the annual or quarterly financial report required by this article if the organization goes out of business or otherwise ceases to exist. If annual gross receipts at the time of the organization ceasing to exist or going out of business exceed $250,000.00, then this individual shall be responsible for attaching the report of an independent certified public accountant as required in section 10-71(d). 
(b)  All permits shall be issued on a calendar basis and unless otherwise provided shall be valid for one calendar year beginning on January 1. All applications for a permit shall be acted upon by the commissioner of the revenue within 60 days from the filing thereof. 
(c)  Upon completion of the application investigation and compliance by the applicant with this article, and at the discretion of the commissioner of the revenue, an annual permit may be issued. 
(d)  The commissioner of the revenue is authorized to issue regulations, which are not in conflict with the state or city Code, to ensure the public safety and welfare in the operation of bingo games or raffles. 
(e)  As a condition of receiving a permit, an organization shall use, during the annual financial reporting period as set forth in section 10-71, no less than five percent of gross receipts from bingo or raffle operations for (i) those lawful, religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes for which the organization is specifically chartered or organized or (ii) those expenses relating to the acquisition, construction, maintenance, or repair of any interest in real estate involving the operation of the organization and used for lawful, religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes. No less than ten percent of gross receipts averaged for three consecutive annual financial reporting periods, as provided by section 10-71 shall be used for such purposes. 
    If an organization fails to meet the above requirements relating to use of its bingo or raffle gross receipts, it shall not be granted a permit for the next calendar year. The failure to grant a permit for the next calendar year shall not relieve an organization of its responsibility to contribute the minimum percentage. 
    This subsection shall not be applicable to the annual financial reporting period as set forth in section 10-71 that begins October 1, 1994, and to all annual financial report periods thereafter. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.3. 
Sec. 10-69. - Frequency, duration, and conduct of bingo games. 
(a)  No organization shall hold bingo games more frequently than two calendar days in any one calendar week as defined in section 10-66, and further no organization shall hold bingo games or raffles between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on a calendar day as defined in section 10-66. 
(b)  A special permit may be granted at the discretion of the commissioner of the revenue which entitles an organization to conduct more frequent operations during carnivals, fairs, and other similar events at its principal meeting place or any other site selected by such organization, which is located in the city and which is not in violation of any located zoning ordinance. 
(c)  The sponsoring organization shall accept only cash or, at its option, checks in payment of charges or assessments for players to participate in bingo games or raffles. However, no organization shall accept postdated checks in payment of any charges or assessments for players to participate in bingo games. No organization or any person on the premises shall extend lines of credit or accept any credit or debit card or other electronic fund transfer in payment of any charges or assessments for players to participate in bingo. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.4. 
Sec. 10-70. - "Instant bingo." 
(a)  Any organization qualified to conduct bingo games pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be authorized to conduct "instant bingo" as a part of such bingo game and only at such location and at such times as are specified in the bingo application permit for regular bingo games as defined in section 10-66. 
(b)  The gross receipts in the course of a reporting year from the playing of "instant bingo" shall not exceed 50 percent of the gross receipts of an organization's bingo operation. 
(c)  Any organization playing "instant bingo" shall maintain a record of the date, quantity, and card value of instant bingo supplies purchased as well as the name and address of the supplier of such instant bingo supplies. The organization shall also maintain a written invoice or receipt from a nonmember of the organization verifying any information required by this subsection. 
(d)  No organization shall sell an "instant bingo" card to any individual below 18 years of age. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.5. 
Sec. 10-71. - Reports of gross receipts and disbursements required; form of reports; failure to file; certificate of compliance; right of entry upon premises; records; independent accounting procedure. 
(a)  Complete records of all receipts and disbursements shall be kept by the individual designated on the permit application and shall be filed annually under oath with the commissioner of the revenue. The annual or quarterly financial report and other items required to be filed under this section shall be a matter of public record. All accountings shall be made on or before December 1 of each calendar year for which a permit has been issued. The accounting shall include a record of the gross receipts and disbursements of an organization for the year period which commenced on October 1 of the previous year and a record of all money in the possession of the organization that was derived from bingo, instant bingo, or raffles regardless of when the money was received. However, any organization whose gross receipts exceed $50,000.00 during any calendar quarter shall be required to file an additional accounting of its receipts and disbursements during such quarter no later than 60 days following the last day of the quarter. "Gross receipts," as used in this section, shall mean the total amount of money received from bingo, instant bingo, and raffle operations before the deduction of expenses or prizes. 
(b)  All reports of receipts and disbursements shall be made on a form prescribed by the commissioner of the revenue and acknowledged in the presence of a duly authorized notary public. The failure to file reports when due shall cause the automatic revocation of the permit, and no organization shall conduct any bingo game or raffle thereafter until the report is properly filed and a new permit is obtained, including payment of application and processing fee. 
(c)  The financial report shall be accompanied by a certificate, verified under oath, by the board of directors that the proceeds of any bingo games or raffles have been used for those lawful, religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes for which the organization is specifically chartered or organized and that the operation of bingo games or raffles has been in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Any organization having annual gross receipts from bingo games or raffles in excess of $250,000.00 as shown on its annual financial report, shall attach to such report an opinion of a licensed independent certified public accountant that (i) the annual financial report presents fairly, in all material respects, beginning cash, receipts, operating cost, use of proceeds, and ending cash; (ii) the proceeds of any bingo games or raffles have been used, in all material respects, for those lawful, religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes for which the organization is specifically chartered or organized; and (iii) the gross receipts have been used in all material respects in accordance with the provisions of this article. The failure to file the opinion of a licensed independent certified public accountant, when required, shall cause the automatic revocation of the permit and no organization shall conduct any bingo game or raffle thereafter until the opinion required by this subdivision is properly filed with the report and a new permit is obtained including payment of application and processing fee. The opinion required by this section is in addition to the audit fee required by section 10-72. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this article requiring an annual audit, the provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the commissioner of the revenue or his designee from performing unannounced audits or restrict any right of such official to secure records required to be maintained by the provisions of this article. Any such official shall have the authority to go upon the premises on which any organization is conducting a bingo game or raffle for the purpose of carrying out the duties imposed by this article including observation of the conduct of games. The application for the bingo or raffle permit shall constitute permission from, and authority granted by, such organization as well as the owner or lessee of the premises on which bingo or raffle is to be conducted to any law enforcement officer, the commissioner of the revenue and or his designee to enter upon such premises. Denial of access to the premises by the organization, the building owner, or any party shall result in the revocation of a permit. 
(f)  The organization shall maintain a written record for three years of the dates on which bingo or raffles are played or conducted, the number of people in attendance on each date and the amount of the receipts and prizes paid on each day. The organization shall also maintain a record of the name and address of each individual to whom a door prize, regular, or special bingo game prize, raffle prize, or jackpot from the playing of bingo or raffles is awarded, as well as the amount of the award. The organization conducting bingo or raffles shall also maintain an itemized record of all receipts and disbursements, including operating costs and use of proceeds incurred in operating bingo games or raffles. 
(g)  All records required to be maintained by this section shall be kept at the site at which bingo or raffles are conducted as set forth in the permit or at the organization's local address as listed on the application. All records shall be made available to inspection immediately upon the request of the commission of the revenue or his designee. Each organization shall designate a member on the application form to be responsible for providing access to these records. 
(h)  Any organization which ceases to exist or ceases its bingo or raffle operations must file all financial reports, disclosures, and audit fee payments within 30 days of ceasing operations, and on a quarterly basis until all its bingo or raffle funds have been disbursed. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.6. 
Sec. 10-72. - Audit of reports; fee. 
(a)  All reports filed pursuant to section 10-71 shall be audited by the commissioner of the revenue or his designee; however, any report field by an organization with gross receipts of less than $2,000.00 for the designated reporting period shall be exempt from the audit requirement. All reports shall be a matter of public record. 
(b)  An audit fee shall accompany each annual report, except any report filed by an organization with gross receipts of less than $2,000.00 for the designated reporting period. The fee shall be calculated on an annual basis and shall equal two percent of (i) the gross receipts which an organization reports pursuant to section 10-71 and (ii) the interest income on money that the organization has received from bingo, instant bingo, or raffle operations. However, in no case shall the audit fee be less than $25.00. 
(c)  The audit fee shall be payable to the city treasurer. All audit fees shall be separately accounted for and shall be used only for the purpose of auditing and regulating bingo games and raffles. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.7. 
Sec. 10-73. - Prohibited practices. 
    In addition to those other practices prohibited by this article, the following acts or practices shall also be prohibited under the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Except for reasonable and proper operating costs, including costs associated with providing clerical assistance in the conduct of bingo games or raffles for organizations composed of and for deaf or blind persons, publicizing the time and place of bingo games and raffles, and prizes, no part of the gross receipts derived by an organization, as herein defined, permitted to conduct bingo games or raffles may be used for any purpose other than (i) those lawful religious, charitable, community or educational purposes for which the organization is specifically chartered or organized and (ii) expenses relating to the acquisition, construction, maintenance, or repair of any interest in the real property involving the operation of the organization and used for lawful religious, charitable, community, or educational purposes. 
(2)  No organization shall enter into a contract with, or otherwise employ for compensation any person, firm, association, organization, partnership, or corporation of any classification whatsoever for the purpose of organizing, managing, or conducting bingo games or raffles. However, this subsection shall not prohibit the joint operation of bingo games under section 10-77. 
(3)  No person, firm, association, organization, partnership, or corporation shall pay or receive for use of any premises devoted, in whole or in part, to the conduct of bingo games or raffles any consideration in excess of the current fair market rental value of such property. For purposes of this article, no fair market rental value consideration shall be based upon or determined by reference to a percentage of the proceeds derived from the operation of bingo games or raffles no shall such consideration be based upon or determined by any reference to a percentage of the proceeds derived from the operation of bingo games or raffles nor shall such consideration be based upon or determined by any reference to the number of people in attendance at such bingo games or raffles. each day in violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate class 1 misdemeanor as set forth in section 10-74. 
(4)  No building or other premises shall be utilized in whole or in part for the purpose of conducting bingo games more frequently than two calendar days in any one calendar week except as follows: 
a.  The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to the playing of bingo pursuant to a special permit issued in accordance with section 10-69(b). 
b.  No building or other premises owned by an organization as defined by section 10-66 of this article and qualified as a tax-exempt organization pursuant to Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code shall be utilized in whole or in part for the purpose of conducting bingo games more frequently than four calendar days in any one calendar week. 
(5)  Except for persons employed as clerical assistance by organizations composed of or for deaf or blind persons, only bona fide members of any such organization who have been members of such organization, as reflected on the organization's list of members filed with the commissioner of the revenue for at least 90 days prior to such participation, shall participate in the management, operation, or conduct of any bingo game or raffle. Notwithstanding the foregoing, employees of corporate sponsors of a qualified organization may participate in the management, operation, or conduct of one raffle per year. The spouse of any such bona fide member or a firefighter or rescue squad member employed by a political subdivision with which the volunteer firefighter or rescue squad member is associated may participate in the operation and conduct of a bingo game or raffle if a bona fide member is present. 
(6)  Except as provided herein, no person shall receive any remuneration for participating in the management, operation, or conduct of any such game or raffle. Persons employed by organizations composed of or for deaf or blind persons may receive remuneration not to exceed $30.00 per event for providing clerical assistance in the conduct of bingo games or raffles only for such organizations. An organization composed of or for deaf or blind persons that employs a person not a member to provide clerical assistance in the conduct of bingo games or raffles shall have in force fidelity insurance, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 38.2-120, written by an insurer licensed to do business in the commonwealth. Persons 18 years of age and under who sell raffle tickets to raise funds for youth activities in which they participate may receive nonmonetary incentive awards or prizes from the organization provided that organization is nonprofit. 
(7)  No landlord shall, at bingo games conducted on the landlord's premises: (i) participate in the conduct, management, or operation of any bingo games; (ii) sell, lease, or otherwise provide for consideration any bingo supplies, including, but not limited to, bingo cards, instant bingo cards, markers, or other game pieces; or (iii) require as a condition of the lease or by contract that a particular manufacturer, distributor, or supplier of bingo supplies or equipment be used by the organization. If equipment or services are included by a landlord in any lease or contract, the lease or contract shall itemize the amount attributable to the rent of the premises, equipment, and each service to be provided by the landlord. 
The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to any charitable organization conducting bingo games on their own behalf; provided, the organization owns the premises where such bingo games are held. 
(8)  No person shall participate in the operation of bingo games or pull-tab raffles for more than one organization in any one calendar year. A calendar year shall run from January 1 through December 31. 
(9)  No organization shall enter into any contract with or otherwise employ or compensate any member of that organization regarding the sale of bingo or raffle supplies or equipment. 
(10)  No organization shall award any bingo prize money or any merchandise valued in excess of the following amounts: (i) no bingo door prize shall exceed $25.00; (ii) no regular bingo or special bingo game shall award a prize in excess of $100.00; (iii) no instant bingo prize for a single card shall exceed $500.00; and (iv) no bingo jackpot of any nature whatsoever shall exceed $1,000.00, nor shall the total amount of bingo jackpot prizes award in any one calendar day exceed $1,000.00. 
(11)  Except as provided herein, no organization shall award any raffle prize valued at more than $100,000.00. The $100,000.00 limitation shall not apply to a raffle conducted no more than once per calendar year by an organization qualified as a tax-exempt organization pursuant to Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code for a prize consisting of a lot improved by a residential dwelling where 100 percent of the monies received from such raffle, less deductions for the fair market value for the cost of acquisition of the land and materials, are donated to lawful religious, charitable, community, or educational organizations specifically chartered or organized under the laws of the commonwealth and qualified as a Section 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization. The award of any prize money for any bingo or raffle shall not be deemed to be part of any gaming contract within the purview of Code of Virginia, § 11-14. 
(12)  Any bingo game in which all of the gross receipts from players for that game are paid as prize money back to the players shall not be subject to the limitations of subsection (9) of this section, but there shall not more than one such game per calendar day of play and the prize money from any such game shall not exceed $1,000.00. 
(13)  No person shall participate in the management, operation, or conduct of any bingo game or raffle if, within the preceding five years, he has been convicted of a felony or crime of moral turpitude. Further, no person shall participate in the management, operation, or conduct of any bingo game or raffle if that persons, within the past five years, has participated in the management, operation, or conduct of any bingo game or raffle which was found by a local permitting authority or by a court of competent jurisdiction to have been operated in violation of state law or local ordinance. 
(14)  An organization using or selling bingo or raffle supplies, including instant bingo supplies, which have been tampered with in any way, including seals broken or packets, or the tampering with bingo or raffle supplies by the organization shall result in the revocation of a permit. 
(15)  No prize shall be awarded to the winner of a bingo game or raffle other than as advertised by the organization. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.9. 
Sec. 10-74. - Denial, suspension or revocation of permit; penalties. 
(a)  The commissioner of the revenue may deny, suspend or revoke the permit of any organization found not to be in strict compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of sections 10-66 through 10-78 shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Any person violation the provisions of section 10-73(a) shall be guilty of a class 6 felony. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.10. 
Sec. 10-75. - Enforcement of article; injunctive relief. 
    In the event that any person violates the provisions of this article, then the commonwealth's attorney or the city attorney may, in addition to the foregoing criminal penalties, apply to the appropriate circuit court for an injunction restraining the continued operation of bingo games or raffles or any aspect thereof. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.11. 
Sec. 10-76. - Hearings and appeals. 
    Unless automatic revocation is required by ordinance, no permit to conduct bingo games or raffles shall be denied, suspended or revoked except upon notice stating the proposed basis for such action and the time and place for a hearing before the commissioner of the revenue thereon. Where a permit is automatically revoked, the organization may request a hearing with the commission of the revenue. After a hearing, the commissioner of the revenue may refuse to issue or may suspend or revoke any such permit if he determines that the organization has not complied with the provisions of this article. Any organization aggrieved by the decision of the commission of the revenue may appeal such decision to the circuit court. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.12. 
Sec. 10-77. - Joint operation of bingo games; restriction; special permit required. 
(a)  Two qualified organizations as defined in this article may jointly organize and conduct bingo games provided both have been issued a permit under the provisions of section 1-67 and provided both fully comply with all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any two qualified organizations jointly conducting bingo games shall be subject to the same restrictions and prohibitions contained in this article that would apply to a single organization conducting bingo games. Organizations jointly conducting bingo games shall not circumvent any restrictions and prohibitions which would otherwise apply if a single organization were conducting such games. These restrictions and prohibitions shall include, but not be limited to, the frequency with which bingo games may be held, the value of merchandise nor money awarded as prizes, and all other practices prohibited under section 10-73 and Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.9A. 
(c)  Any two qualified organizations which wish to jointly conduct one or more bingo games shall furnish to the commissioner of the revenue a written report setting forth the division of manpower, costs, and proceeds for each game to be jointly conducted. Upon a finding that the division of manpower and costs for each game bears a reasonable relationship to the division of proceeds, the commission of the revenue shall issue a special permit for the joint conduct of all approved bingo games. No bingo game may be jointly conducted until this special permit is obtained by the organization involved for that bingo game. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.13. 
Sec. 10-78. - Only bingo, instant bingo, raffles, and duck races permitted. 
    This article permits organizations to conduct bingo, instant bingo, raffles, or duck races. All games not explicitly authorized by this article are prohibited. 
(Ord. of 11-14-94(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.14. 
Secs. 10-79-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOLROOMS 

Sec. 10-91. - Application of article. 
    All poolrooms in the city shall be subject to the restrictions and conditions contained in the provisions of this article, except as noted in section 10-97. 
(Code 1969, § 3-1) 
Sec. 10-92. - When closing required. 
    Each poolroom shall be closed at 2:00 a.m. each morning and shall not reopen until 6:00 a.m. each morning. 
(Code 1969, § 3-2) 
Sec. 10-93. - Visibility of interior. 
    In no portion of the structure used as a poolroom shall screens, blinds, curtains or other like obstructions be permitted that would cut off or limit the view within the entire poolroom. 
(Code 1969, § 3-3) 
Sec. 10-94. - Betting or gambling. 
    No betting or gambling of any kind shall be allowed in any poolroom or in the structure wherein it is located. 
(Code 1969, § 3-4) 
Cross reference- Gambling, § 58-61 et seq. 
Sec. 10-95. - Presence of minors. 
(a)  The proprietor of a poolroom or person in charge of or manager of a poolroom shall not permit persons under the age of 18 years to enter, frequent or play any games of any kind in such poolroom. 
(b)  There shall be posted at a conspicuous place at the entrance of the poolroom a sign in bold letters not less than two inches in height, with the following announcement: "No person under 18 years of age shall be allowed in this poolroom." 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 3-5) 
Sec. 10-96. - Forfeiture of license because of violation of article. 
    A violation of any of the prohibitions, restrictions or conditions contained in this article by the proprietor or manager of a poolroom shall result in a forfeiture of the license under the provisions of which such poolroom is licensed to operate. 
(Code 1969, § 3-6) 
Sec. 10-97. - What article not applicable to. 
    The provisions, requirements, restrictions and prohibitions of this article shall not apply to the operation of nonstandard, what is commonly known as "coin in the slot" pool tables, or the like. 
(Code 1969, § 3-8) 
Sec. 10-98. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a violation of any of the foregoing restrictions, prohibitions or conditions of this article by the proprietor or manager of a poolroom shall subject such proprietor or manager, as well as any other person involved, to punishment for a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 3-7) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Powers of city as to regulation of animals (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-870) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; health and sanitation, ch. 38; protection of food from contamination, § 38-56; application of traffic regulations to persons riding or driving animals, § 86-3; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Comprehensive animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66 et seq.; offenses involving animals, Code of Virginia, §§ 3.1-796.128, 18.2-403.1 et seq.; inoculation of cats against rabies, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-28.5; cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-29.1:1; diseased animals, dead animals, etc., Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-323, 18.2-510; regulation of hunting and trapping by cities, Code of Virginia, §§ 29.1-526, 29.1-528; hunting near public schools and public parks, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-527; estrays, Code of Virginia, § 55-202 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Keeping noisy, etc., animals or fowl. 
(a)  No person shall, either on his own property or on any property in which he has any interest or over which he exercises any control, keep, maintain or allow to remain any animal or fowl which sets up, causes, emits or gives vent to incessant or intermittent or other noises or commotions of such a character and kind as to disturb any citizen of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or so as to cause any person of ordinary sensibilities any actual physical discomfort. 
(b)  The keeping by any person of any animal or fowl which sets up, brings about, causes, emits or gives vent to such noises shall constitute a nuisance abatable as such by a proper suit in equity in the circuit court for the city, but this shall be in addition to and not in lieu of the punishment provided. 
(Code 1969, § 4-2; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(1), repealed former § 14-1, which pertained to dangerous or vicious animals at large, and derived from Code 1969, §§ 4-1, 4-27(f). Subsequently, said ordinance renumbered former § 14-2 as § 14-1 as set out herein. 
Sec. 14-2. - Dogs, cats and other animals in city parks or school facilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any dog, cat or other animal to allow such dog, cat or other animal on the premises of any city park or school facilities, whether such dog, cat or other animal is running at large or under the direct supervision and control of its owner or custodian. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall subject the owner or custodian of any dog, cat or other animal so found on the premises of any city park or school facilities to punishment for a class 4 misdemeanor. Every time such dog, cat or other animal is permitted on the premises of a city park or school facilities shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 17-14.2; Ord. of 3-23-92; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(1), renumbered former § 14-4 as § 14-2 as set out herein. 
Sec. 14-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(1), repealed former § 14-3, which pertained to cruelty to animals; penalty, and derived from Code 1969, § 4-3. 
Secs. 14-4-14-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POULTRY GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-36. - Confinement; permitting to trespass on property of others. 
    All persons owning or having in their possession, under their control or on their premises chickens, ducks, guinea-fowl and any other like fowl shall strictly confine, keep up and pen the same so that they cannot get off the premises owned or controlled by any such person owning or having or in charge of such chickens, ducks, guineas and like fowl. If any chickens, ducks, guineas and like fowl are allowed, permitted, or in any way trespass upon the property of others, then the owner or the person having charge of such chicken, duck, guinea or other fowl on his premises shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. Each time any chicken, duck, guinea or other like fowl trespasses upon the property of another shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 4-4) 
Sec. 14-37. - Keeping certain fowl as nuisance. 
    The keeping by any person of any chickens, turkeys, ducks or other poultry or fowl which either disturbs any citizen of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or causes any person of ordinary sensibilities any actual physical discomfort, or creates or brings about an insanitary situation or condition detrimental to the health of any citizen of the city, shall constitute a nuisance abatable as such by a proper suit in equity in the circuit court for the city, but this shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, the punishment provided. 
(Code 1969, § 4-5) 
Cross reference- Maintaining nuisance generally, § 30-5. 
Sec. 14-38. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 6-25-2012(1)) 
Sec. 14-39. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by animal control officers or police officers for the City of Salem. 
(Ord. of 6-25-2012(1)) 
Secs. 14-40-14-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BIRD SANCTUARY 

Sec. 14-56. - Establishment. 
    The area within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated and established as a bird sanctuary. 
(Code 1969, § 4-6) 
Sec. 14-57. - Signs. 
    The city manager shall erect appropriate signs designating the city as a bird sanctuary at the corporate limits of the city on U.S. Routes 11 and 460 and State Routes 311 and 419, and at such other places as, in his discretion, he deems necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 4-7) 
Cross reference- Signs, ch. 66. 
Sec. 14-58. - Killing songbirds or wild game birds; molesting nests. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to kill a songbird or wild game bird in the city with any gun, pistol or other firearm, air rifle, BB gun, gravel shooter, bow and arrow, slingshot or any other similar device or weapon. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to molest the nest of any songbird or wild game bird. 
(Code 1969, § 4-8) 
Secs. 14-59-14-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOGS AND CATS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Comprehensive animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6500 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal or animals means domestic animal or animals, including both agriculture and companion animals. 
    Animal control officer means any animal control officer appointed under this article. 
    Animal nuisance is created when any dog, cat, or other animals unreasonably annoy humans, endanger the life or health of other animals or persons or substantially interfere with the rights of citizens, other than their owners, to the enjoyment of life or property. Such acts of nuisance shall include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Repeatedly found to run at large; 
(2)  Damages property other than that of the animal's owner; 
(3)  Attacks or disturbs other animals, persons or vehicles by chasing, barking or biting; 
(4)  Makes excessive noises, including but not limited to, barking, whining, howling, caterwauling or crying; 
(5)  Creates noxious or offensive odors; 
(6)  Defecates upon any public place or upon premises not owned or controlled by the owner unless promptly removed by the animal's owner; or 
(7)  Creates an unsanitary condition or insect breeding site due to an accumulation of excreta or filth. 
    Cat means any member of the animal species felis catus. 
    Dog means every dog, regardless of age. 
    Kennel means an enclosure wherein dogs are kept and from which they cannot escape. 
    Livestock means and includes cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine and enclosed, domesticated rabbits or hares. 
    Owner means and includes every person having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps or harbors an animal, or who has an animal in his care, or who acts as a custodian of an animal, or who permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. In the case of a minor who owns, keeps, harbors, or acts as custodian of an animal, the parent or parents or other lawful guardian of such minor shall be deemed to be the owner of the animal. 
    Run at large means roaming, running or self-hunting off the property of the animal's owner or custodian and not under its owner's or custodian's immediate control. 
    Treasurer means and includes the treasurer of this city or any other officer designated by law to collect taxes in this city. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4-10.1, 4-12; Ord. of 10-26-92, §§ 4-10.1, 4-12; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-87. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(1) repealed § 14-87, which pertained to mad dogs and derived from Code 1969, § 4-11. 
Sec. 14-88. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any dog to permit such dog to run at large, remain unconfined, unrestricted or not penned up, whether licensed or unlicensed, within the corporate limits of the city at any time. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall subject the owner or custodian of such dog so found running at large at any time contrary to the provisions of this section to punishment as provided in section 14-103. Every time such dog is permitted to run at large contrary to the provisions of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Every police officer or animal control officer shall impound any such dog so found running at large contrary to the provisions of this section, and if such dog is found to have done any damage to property, real or personal, such dog may be killed in accordance with the provisions and requirements of § 3.2-6546 of the 1950 Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1969, § 4-12; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-12; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit dogs from running at large, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6538. 
Sec. 14-89. - Female dogs in season. 
    The owner or custodian shall confine every female dog known or suspected of being in season to a building or structure properly enclosed so as to obscure the female dog from public view while the female dog is known or suspected to be in season. If the owner or custodian is identified by any police officer, such owner or custodian shall be notified to secure the dog in a secure place. If the owner or custodian refuses or neglects to do so or if the owner or custodian is not known, then it shall be the duty of any police officer to have the dog killed. 
(Code 1969, §§ 4-13, 4-27(b); Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-27(b)) 
Sec. 14-90. - Dogs and cats deemed personal property; rights relating thereto. 
(a)  All dogs and cats shall be deemed personal property and may be the subject of larceny and malicious or unlawful trespass. Owners may maintain any action for the killing of any such dog or cat, or injury thereto, or unlawful detention or use thereof as in the case of other personal property. The owner of any dog or cat which is injured or killed contrary to the provisions of this chapter by any person shall be entitled to recover the value thereof or the damage done thereto in an appropriate action at law from such person. 
(b)  An animal control officer or other officer finding a stolen dog or cat, or a dog or cat held or detained contrary to law, shall have authority to seize and hold such dog or cat pending action before a general district court or other court. If no such action is instituted within seven days, the animal control officer or other officer shall deliver the dog or cat to its owner. 
(c)  The presence of a dog or cat on the premises of a person other than its legal owner shall raise no presumption of theft against the owner of such property, and the animal control officer may take such dog or cat in charge and notify its legal owner to remove it. 
(d)  The legal owner of a dog or cat impounded under this section shall pay, for the keep of such dog or cat while in the possession of the animal control officer, the sum of $10.00 for the first 24 hours, or any portion thereof, and $10.00 for each 24 hours, or any portion thereof, thereafter, and, in addition thereto, a pickup fee of $20.00. 
(Code 1969, § 4-23; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-23; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6585. 
Sec. 14-91. - Dogs killing, injuring or chasing livestock or poultry. 
    It shall be the duty of any animal control officer or other officer who may find a dog in the act of killing or injuring livestock or poultry to kill such dog forthwith, whether such dog bears a tag or not. Any person finding a dog committing any of the depredations mentioned in this section shall have the right to kill such dog on sight, as shall any owner of livestock or his agent finding a dog chasing livestock on land utilized by the livestock when the circumstances show that such chasing is harmful to the livestock. 
(Code 1969, § 4-24; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-24; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6552. 
Sec. 14-92. - Killing unlicensed dogs and cats. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to kill any dog or cat of unknown ownership found running at large on which the license fee has not been paid in accordance with the provision and requirements of § 3.2-6546 of the 1950 Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1969, § 4-25; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-25; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-93. - Disposal of dead animals. 
    The owner of any animal which has died from disease or other cause shall forthwith cremate or bury such animal. If, after notice, any owner fails to do so, the animal control officer or other officer shall bury or cremate the animal, and he may recover on behalf of the city from the owner his cost for this service. 
(Code 1969, § 4-26; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
State Law reference- Disposal of dead dogs, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6554. 
Sec. 14-94. - Prohibited acts generally. 
    The following shall be class 4 misdemeanors: 
(1)  Diseased dog or cat. For the owner of any dog or cat with a contagious or infectious disease to permit such dog or cat to stray from his premises if such disease is known to the owner. 
(2)  Confinement of dogs and cats; sanitary conditions. The structure or building in which any dogs or cats are confined and the lot, compound, or enclosure in which they are penned shall be kept in such sanitary condition as not to cause offensive odors or to attract flies or other insects. 
(3)  Removing collar or tag. For any person, except the owner or custodian, to remove a legally acquired collar or license tag from a dog or cat, subject to the exceptions listed in section 14-137 herein. 
(4)  Concealing a dog or cat. For any person to conceal or harbor any dog or cat on which the license fee has not been paid or to conceal a rabid dog or cat to keep such dog or cat from being killed. 
(Code 1969, § 4-27(a), (c)-(e); Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-27(a), (c)-(e); Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-95. - Vaccination required generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, hold or harbor any dog or domesticated cat four months of age or over within the city unless the dog or domesticated cat shall have been vaccinated with a modified live virus (flury strain) rabies vaccine in accordance with provisions of § 3.2-6521 of the 1950 Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1969, § 4-28; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6521A. 
Sec. 14-96. - Vaccination of dogs and cats coming into city. 
    Any person transporting a dog or domesticated cat four months of age or over into the city from some other jurisdiction shall be required to conform with the vaccination requirement of section 14-95 forthwith after bringing the dog or cat into the city. 
(Code 1969, § 4-29; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-97. - Certificate of inoculation; disposition of dogs and cats not vaccinated. 
(a)  At the time of vaccination, a certificate of inoculation setting forth the type of vaccine used shall be issued to the dog or cat owner. 
(b)  Any dog or cat found within the city not vaccinated and identified as described in subsection (a) shall be impounded by the animal control officer and/or a police officer, and such dog or cat shall be held in accordance with the provisions of § 3.2-6546 of the 1950 Code of Virginia, as amended. The dog or cat may be returned to its owner upon proof of ownership, vaccination, and payment of the cost of impoundment as provided in section 14-90 herein. 
(Code 1969, § 4-30; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-30; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-98. - Council may provide vaccination clinics. 
    The council may provide for clinics for the vaccination of dogs and cats under the supervision of the animal control officer or his designee and the county health director, and fix fees to be charged for such services. 
(Code 1969, § 4-31; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-31; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-99. - Quarantine. 
    When, in the judgment of the health director, an emergency shall be deemed to exist in the city or any section thereof due to a widespread rabies epidemic, for the protection of the public health, the health director may declare a quarantine in the city or such section thereof as may be affected and restrict all dogs to the owners' premises or to the immediate custody of a responsible person for the duration of such emergency as it is set forth by the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 4-32) 
Sec. 14-100. - Limit on number of dogs and cats kept; location and condition of pens, etc. 
(a)  No person shall keep or permit another to keep, in any one separate location at any one time, a total of more than three dogs and more than a total of three cats. The pen or premises in which such animals are kept shall be not less than 50 feet from the dwelling or other structure used for human habitation of any other person, and such pens and premises shall at all times be kept so clean and free from offensive odors as not to disturb any citizen of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or to cause any person of ordinary sensibilities any actual physical discomfort. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any puppies or kittens under the age of four months, if the pens and premises holding such puppies or kittens are kept or likewise maintained in the manner set forth in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 4-9) 
Sec. 14-101. - Keeping certain dogs and cats as animal nuisance. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog, cat or other animals to cause or permit such animal to perform, create or engage in any animal nuisance, as defined in section 14-86. Any animal found acting in any way forbidden by this article shall hereby be declared a nuisance, and its owner shall be subject to the penalties provided by section 14-103. 
(Code 1969, § 4-10; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Cross reference- Maintaining nuisance generally, § 30-5. 
Sec. 14-102. - Penalties for certain violations. 
    Any person who shall make a false statement in order to secure a dog or cat license to which he is not entitled shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Any person convicted of failure to pay the license fee prior to February 1 of each year, or as otherwise provided in this article, on any dog or cat owned by him shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and shall be required to obtain proper license forthwith; and unless the fine and license fee are immediately paid, the general district court may order the dog or cat disposed of by the animal control officer or other designated official by giving it into the possession of any person willing to pay the cost of impounding and license; or, if not so disposed of, it shall be killed in a humane manner by the animal control officer or other designated official, but the disposing or killing of such dog or cat shall not relieve its owner of the payment of the fine and license fee already due. 
(Code 1969, § 4-33; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-33; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-103. - Penalty for violation of article; impoundment of dogs, cats and animals; disposition of fines. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided for, any violation of this article shall be a class 4 misdemeanor, and each such violation shall constitute a separate offense; in addition, every animal control officer or other officer shall have the right, and it shall be his duty, to seize and impound any such dog, cat, or other animal found in violation of any provision of this article. Such dog, cat, or other animal shall be impounded and held in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia (1950), § 3-2-6546, as amended. All fines collected from any person for violating any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be credited to the general fund of the city and deposited by the city treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 4-34; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-34; Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-104. - Enforcement of article; appointment of animal control officer. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforceable by the game warden, animal control officer, city sheriff, or any police officer of the city unless otherwise specifically provided for. The city manager is hereby authorized to appoint an animal control officer in accordance with section 5.2 of the Charter. 
(Code 1969, § 4-35; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-35) 
Sec. 14-105. - Confinement of animals in vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  Any person who confines an animal in an unattended, enclosed vehicle where the outside temperature is 80 degrees or greater, and the interior of the vehicle is not equipped with a supplemental fan that is operating at the time of such confinement, shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who confines an animal in an unattended, enclosed vehicle so as to cause the animal to suffer from heat stress, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. The animal control officer or other officer shall have the authority to remove any animal found in an enclosed vehicle that appears to be suffering from heat stress. The animal shall be provided immediate veterinary care. The animal owner or custodian shall be responsible for all expenses incurred during the removal of the animal or its subsequent treatment and impoundment. 
(c)  In the event that the person responsible for the violation cannot be ascertained, the registered owner of the vehicle, as required by Code of Virginia (1950), tit. 46.2, ch. 6, as amended, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that such registered owner was the person who committed the violation. 
(Ord. of 6-13-2011) 
Secs. 14-106-14-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(2) shall be in full force and effect October 1, 2010. 

Sec. 14-131. - Required; term; fees generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own and keep a dog or cat four months old or over in this city unless it is licensed as required by the provisions of this division. Licenses shall run by the calendar year; namely, from January 1 through December 31, and the license fee shall be payable at the office of the treasurer and shall be as follows: 
(1)  Male. For a male dog or cat ..... $10.00 
(2)  Unsexed dog or cat. For an unsex[ed] (successfully spayed or neutered) dog or cat ..... $5.00 
(3)  Female. For a female dog or cat ..... $10.00 
(4)  Kennel (for 20 dogs or less). For a kennel of 20 dogs or less ..... $15.00 
(5)  Kennel (for more than 20 dogs). For a kennel of more than 20 dogs ..... $25.00 
(6)  Dangerous dog. As declared by any general district court of the state (in addition to the other applicable fees in this section): A registration certificate and renewal fees as provided in the 1950 Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6540(G) and as amended thereafter. 
(Code 1969, § 4-14; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-14; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2); Ord. of 4-9-2018(1)) 
State Law reference- Amount of license tax, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6528. 
Sec. 14-132. - When fees payable. 
    The license fee on dogs and cats shall be due and payable as follows: 
(1)  On or after January 1 and not later than January 31 of each year, the owner of any dog or cat four months old or older shall pay a license fee as prescribed in the preceding section. 
(2)  If a dog or cat four months of age or older unlicensed by this city shall come in the possession of any person in this city between January 1 and October 31 of any year, a license fee for the current calendar year shall be paid forthwith by the owner. 
(3)  If a dog or cat four months of age unlicensed by this city shall come into the possession of any person in this city between November 1 and December 31 of any year, the license fee for the succeeding calendar year shall be paid forthwith by the owner, and such license shall be valid from the date of payment of the license fee. 
(Code 1969, § 4-15; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
State Law reference- When license tax payable, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6530. 
Sec. 14-133. - Payment of license fee subsequent to summons. 
    Payment of the license fee subsequent to a summons to appear before the judge of the general district court for failure to do so within the time required shall not operate to relieve such owner from the penalties provided. 
(Code 1969, § 4-16) 
Sec. 14-134. - Procedure for obtaining. 
    Any resident of this city may obtain a dog or cat license by making oral or written application to the treasurer, accompanied by the amount of the license fee. The treasurer shall have authority to license only dogs and cats kept by resident owners or custodians within this city and may require information to this effect of any applicant. Any person making application for a dog or cat license shall be required to present to the official who issues such licenses a certificate of rabies vaccination, properly executed and signed by a licensed veterinarian, certifying that the dog or cat has been vaccinated in accordance with the provisions set forth in this article. The certificate must show the date of inoculation, a brief description of the dog or cat, sex and breed, and the owner thereof. The certificate must be presented before the license is issued and must comply with the provisions of section 14-95 herein. When the dog or cat license has been issued, the certificate of vaccination shall be so marked and returned to the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 4-17; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
Sec. 14-135. - Composition. 
    A dog or cat license shall consist of a license receipt and a metal tag stamped or otherwise permanently marked to show the jurisdiction issuing the license, the sex of the dog or cat, the calendar year for which issued, and bear a serial number. The license tag for a kennel shall show the number of dogs authorized to be kept under such license and have attached thereto a metal identification plate for each of such dogs, numbered to correspond with the serial number of the license tag. 
(Code 1969, § 4-18; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
State Law reference- What dog license shall consist of, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6526. 
Sec. 14-136. - Duplicate license tags. 
    If a dog or cat license tag shall become lost, destroyed or stolen, the owner or custodian shall at once apply to the treasurer or his agent who issued the original license for a duplicate license tag, presenting the original license receipt. Upon affidavit of the owner or custodian before the treasurer or his agent that the original license tag has been lost, destroyed or stolen, he shall issue a duplicate license tag, which the owner or custodian shall immediately affix to the collar of the dog or cat. The treasurer or his agent shall endorse the number of the duplicate and the date issued on the face of the original license receipt. The fee for a duplicate tag shall be $1.00. 
(Code 1969, § 4-19; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
State Law reference- Duplicate license tags, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6532. 
Sec. 14-137. - Displaying receipts; wearing of tags. 
(a)  License receipts shall be carefully preserved by the licensees and exhibited promptly on request for inspection by any animal control officer and/or police officer. License tags shall be securely fastened to a substantial collar by the owner or custodian and worn by such dog or cat at all times, except as provided in subsection (b) and (c). 
(b)  The owner of the dog or cat may remove the collar and license tag required by this section when: 
(1)  The dog is engaged in lawful hunting; 
(2)  The dog or cat is competing in a dog or cat show; 
(3)  The dog or cat has a skin condition which would be exacerbated by the wearing of a collar; 
(4)  The dog or cat is confined; or 
(5)  The dog or cat is under the immediate control of its owner. 
(c)  The animal control officer or representative may remove the collar and license tag of such dog or cat when under their immediate control. 
(Code 1969, § 4-20; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-20; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
State Law reference- Displaying receipts, dogs to wear tags, Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6531. 
Sec. 14-138. - Effect of dog or cat not wearing collar and license. 
    Any dog or cat not wearing a collar bearing a license tag of the proper calendar year shall prima facie be deemed to be unlicensed; and, in any proceedings under this article, the burden of proof of the fact that the dog or cat has been licensed, or is otherwise not required to bear a tag at the time, shall be on the owner. 
(Code 1969, § 4-21; Ord. of 2-8-2010(2)) 
Sec. 14-139. - Kennel dogs. 
(a)  The owner of a kennel shall securely fasten the license tag to the kennel enclosure in full view and keep one of the identification plates provided therewith attached to the collar of each dog authorized to be kept enclosed in the kennel. Any identification plates not so in use shall be kept by the owner or custodian and promptly shown to any animal control officer and/or police officer upon request. 
(b)  A kennel dog shall not be permitted to stray beyond the limits of the enclosure, but such requirement shall not prohibit removing dogs therefrom temporarily while under the control of the owner or custodian for the purpose of exercising, hunting, breeding, trial or show. A kennel shall not be operated in such manner as to defraud the city of the license fee applying to dogs which cannot be legally covered thereunder or to in any manner violate other provisions of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 4-22; Ord. of 10-26-92, § 4-22) 
Secs. 14-140-14-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 2-8-2010(1) repealed Div. 3, §§ 14-151-14-155, which pertained to dangerous dogs and derived from Ord. of 10-26-92. 

Secs. 14-151-14-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LIVESTOCK 

Sec. 14-166. - Keeping hogs, pigs, or swine. 
    No person shall keep or maintain any hogs, pigs, or swine of any type within the city. Any violation of this section shall be a class 4 misdemeanor, and each day the violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense; however, the provisions of this section shall not apply to the keeping of hogs, pigs, or swine on any tract or parcel of land zoned for agricultural purposes, provided the hogs, pigs, or swine are kept at least 100 feet from any residence, and provided further that no offensive odors from the keeping of such animals disturb any citizen or resident of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or cause any person of ordinary sensibility any actual physical discomfort. 
(Code 1969, § 4-36; Ord. of 11-13-95(1)) 
Sec. 14-167. - Keeping horses, ponies, cows, etc. 
    Except as provided in this section or in section 14-166, no person shall keep within the city any horses, ponies, cows, or any like livestock. Any violation of this section shall be a class 4 misdemeanor, and each day the violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the keeping of horses, ponies, cows or such livestock on any tract or parcel of land zoned for agricultural purposes or any tract or parcel of land containing eight acres or more; nor shall it apply to any riding stable licensed by the city council, provided that such animals are kept at least 100 feet from any residence, and provided further that no offensive odors from the keeping of such animals shall disturb any citizen or resident of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or cause any person of ordinary sensibility any actual physical discomfort. 
(Code 1969, § 4-37) 
Sec. 14-168. - Boundary lines declared lawful fences; animals running at large beyond boundaries of own land. 
(a)  The boundary lines of each lot, parcel or tract of land within the corporate limits of the city are constituted and determined to be a lawful fence, and it shall be unlawful for the owner, caretaker or manager, temporary or otherwise, of any horse, mule, swine, sheep, goat or cattle of any sort or description to permit such animal or animals to run at large beyond the boundaries of his own lands. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 4-38) 
State Law reference- Trespasses, fences, Code of Virginia, § 55-298.1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-169. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall supersede and take priority over any conflicting provisions of chapter 106 herein. 
(Ord. of 6-25-2012(1)) 
Secs. 14-170-14-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BEEKEEPING 

Sec. 14-181. - Distance from property lines. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or place an apiary or beehive or cause or allow an apiary or beehive to remain: 
(1)  Closer than ten feet to the property line of adjoining property of anyone other than the person maintaining the apiary or beehive or his immediate family; 
(2)  Closer than 40 feet to any house or other building used for residential purposes by anyone other than the person maintaining the beehive or apiary or his immediate family or any apartment, hotel, motel, office, commercial establishment, church or school; or 
(3)  Closer than 30 feet to any "street" as defined by section 1-2 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
Sec. 14-182. - Water supply for bees. 
    Every person owning, possessing, controlling or keeping an apiary or beehive shall maintain, within 50 feet of each beehive an adequate, accessible or usable supply of fresh water for the bees. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
Sec. 14-183. - Density requirements. 
(a)  The keeping of honeybees shall be allowed as an accessory use on any lot at the ratio of four beehives per 10,000 square feet. 
(b)  The density restrictions established by this section shall have no application to an apiary or beehive kept, placed or maintained on any parcel of real property zoned agricultural (A-1). 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
Sec. 14-184. - Exceptions from article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the keeping of apiary or beehives within an educational institution, museum, physician's office or laboratory for the purpose of study, observation or medical research or treatment, provided that such bees are not permitted to fly at large. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
Sec. 14-185. - Penalties; violations declared nuisances. 
    Any person convicted or violation of any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. In addition, any violation of this article is hereby declared a public nuisance, and any person suffering injury or damage therefrom may seek the correction, removal or abatement of such nuisance through appropriate suit in equity. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
Sec. 14-186. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the words "beehive" and "apiary" shall have the following meanings: 
    Apiary shall mean any place where one or more colonies of bees are kept. 
    Beehive shall mean a single colony, hive or stand of bees, regardless of size. 
(Ord. of 11-11-96) 
ARTICLE VII. - WILD AND EXOTIC ANIMALS 

Sec. 14-187. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed to them: 
    Animal shall include any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, not to include birds. 
    Pet shall mean any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. 
    Vicious animal shall mean any animal that has: 
(1)  Killed a person; 
(2)  Inflicted serious injury to a person, including multiple bites, serious disfigurement, serious impairment of health, or serious impairment of a bodily function; or 
(3)  In the case of a dog, continued to exhibit the behavior which resulted in a previous finding by a court that it is a "dangerous dog," provided the owner or custodian of said dog has been given notice of that finding. 
    Wild or exotic animal shall mean any live monkey (nonhuman primate), raccoon, skunk, wolf, squirrel, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or any other warm-blooded animal, poisonous snake or tarantula which can normally be found in the wild state or any other member of crocodilian, including, but not limited to, alligators, crocodiles, caimans, and gavials. Ferrets, guinea pigs, nonpoisonous snakes, rabbits, and laboratory rats which have been bred in captivity and which have never known the wild shall be excluded from this definition. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-188. - Display or exhibition. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept on his premises any wild, exotic or vicious animal or display or for exhibition purposes, whether gratuitously or for a fee. This section shall not be construed to apply to zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, circuses, or veterinary clinics which are properly licensed by the federal government or commonwealth of Virginia. In no case, however, shall such wild or exotic animals be exhibited or displayed in such a manner that persons other than their handlers can pet, fondle or otherwise come in direct physical contact with such animals. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-189. - Keeping as a pet. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept any wild, exotic, or vicious animal as a pet. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-190. - Notice required at place of sale. 
    Any person who offers for sale a wild or exotic animal shall post conspicuously at the place of sale or display the following notice: 
No person may lawfully keep or permit to be kept in the City of Salem any live monkey (nonhuman primate), raccoon, skunk, wolf, squirrel, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx, or any other warm-blooded animal, poisonous snake or tarantula, crocodile or alligator, which can normally be found in the wild state or any other member of the crocodilian, including but not limited to alligators, crocodiles, caimans, and gavials. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-191. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. Each day a violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Sec. 14-192. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by animal control officers or police officers for the City of Salem. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2010(1)) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Powers of city as to buildings for municipal functions, purposes, etc. (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-846, now repealed) and light, ventilation and sanitation of buildings and premises (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-869) adopted, § 2.2. See Code of Virginia § 15.2-1117. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; massage parlor permit, § 22-166 et seq.; environment, ch. 30; air pollution, § 30-41 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 54; planning, ch. 62; signs, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Access to and use of buildings by handicapped, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-517; dangerous buildings and other structures, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-906; fences around swimming pools, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-921; display of numbers on buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2024; buildings, monuments and lands of local governments, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1638 et seq.; Virginia Industrialized Building Safety Law, Code of Virginia, § 36-70 et seq.; Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq.; local licensing of certain contractors, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-1117. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Certificate of qualification-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or engage in, or offer to engage in, for the general public for compensation, plumbing, building- related mechanical or electrical work, unless such person has been issued a certificate of qualification. 
(b)  The applicant for a certificate of qualification shall furnish evidence of his ability or proficiency as may be required by standards established by the state department of housing and community development and the applicant shall be examined to determine his qualifications. The issuance of certificates pursuant to these standards shall be limited to two levels based on the ability and proficiency demonstrated by the applicant in the specified areas of competence. 
(c)  National testing organizations designated by the state department of housing and community development shall administer all examinations to determine an applicant's qualification for certification and the building official shall refuse to grant a certificate to an applicant found not to be qualified. 
(d)  An application fee of $15.00 shall be charged each applicant for level one (journeyman) certification. A fee of $30.00 shall be charged each applicant for level two (master) certification. 
(e)  The violation of any of the provisions of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor and be punishable as such. 
(Code 1969, §§ 6-5.5, 19-10) 
Sec. 18-2. - Same-Revocation. 
    Certification may be revoked for misrepresentation or a fraudulent application, or for incompetence as demonstrated by an egregious or repeated violation of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1969, § 19-11) 
Sec. 18-3. - Gutters, etc., when eaves project over sidewalk; downspouts from gutters. 
    All buildings which are built so close to the street line that the eaves project over the sidewalk shall be provided with gutters so that there shall be no drip upon the sidewalk, and the gutters and eaves shall at all times be kept in good repair. Downspouts from gutters shall be constructed so as to discharge the water, when practicable, under the sidewalk in a suitable pipe. 
(Code 1969, § 6-1) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Regulations concerning the building of houses, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-15(1). 
Sec. 18-4. - Use of covered drain when water flows across street upon erection of building, etc., or grading of lot. 
    No person shall erect, add to, alter or repair any building or other structure of any nature or kind, whether such building or other structure is above or below ground, or so grade any lot, as will concentrate water from any lot, building, structure, gutter or downspout, or from any other source whatsoever, and cause such water to flow across any street, alley or other public way, except in a covered drain of sufficient capacity, the size, location and construction of which shall be in accordance with plans and specifications first approved by the city manager. No building permit shall be issued unless and until satisfactory provisions for the elimination or proper disposition of concentrated water has been reasonably provided for. 
(Code 1969, § 6-2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
Secs. 18-5-18-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 18-36. - Adopted; where copies filed; permit fees. 
(a)  There is adopted, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, service, equipment, use and occupancy, location and maintenance of building, plumbing, electrical and mechanical work in connection therewith, including permits and penalties, those certain codes, known as the Uniform Statewide Building Code, as provided in Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq., of which copies have been and are now on file in the office of the clerk of council, and such codes are adopted and incorporated in this article as a part of this article to the same extent and purpose as though such codes were fully set out at length in this article, and the provisions thereof shall control the construction, alteration or addition to any building and other structure within the city. 
(b)  Every person filing an application for a permit as required by the Uniform Statewide Building Code shall pay to the city a permit fee in accordance with the schedule established by the council. If any person commences any work on a building or structure before obtaining the necessary permit and paying the applicable fee, the permit fee shall be doubled. 
(Code 1969, § 6-5) 
Sec. 18-37. - When and where copies obtainable. 
    Copies of the Uniform Statewide Building Code adopted by section 18-36 may be obtained at the office of the building official in the city during regular business hours. 
(Code 1969, § 6-6) 
Sec. 18-38. - Amendments. 
    The Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code is amended and reordained in the following respects: 
(1)  Unsafe buildings. In addition to the administrative and enforcement provisions contained in the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, adopted in the Uniform Statewide Building Code, as amended from time to time, the provisions of this section shall apply to unsafe buildings. The following words when used in this section for the purposes of this section shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
a.  Board means the board of appeals established under section 116.0 of volume I of the Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
b.  Building means every building or structure which: 
1.  Shows 33 percent or more of damages or deterioration of the supporting members, or 50 percent of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting, enclosing or outside walls or covering; 
2.  Has improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roof or is otherwise overloaded, or which has insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose for which it is used; 
3.  Has been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to become dangerous to the life, safety or health of the occupants thereof or other inhabitants of the city; 
4.  Is so dilapidated, decayed or unsafe as to become dangerous to the safety of the inhabitants of the city; or 
5.  Has parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall or otherwise become detached and cause personal injury or damage to other property. 
c.  Building official shall be as defined in section 102.0 of volume I of the Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
d.  Occupant means the occupants of a building in possession under a contract or lease with the owner thereof or the occupants of a building in possession under a sublease thereof. 
e.  Owner means every individual, firm or corporation holding legal title to a building appearing of record in the clerk's office of the circuit court of the city, where deeds are recorded; the guardian, if any, of any such owner if he is an infant and the committee, if any, of such owner if he is insane; and the trustee or mortgagee under any deed of trust or mortgage creating a lien on such building also appearing of record in such clerk's office. 
(2)  All buildings defined in subsection (1) of this section are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be repaired, vacated or demolished, as the case may be, as required by this section. 
(3)  Whenever it shall come to the attention of the building official that a building is likely to exist in violation of the provisions of this section, he shall inspect or cause an inspection to be made thereof and shall determine whether the existence of such building is in fact in violation of the provisions of this section. Upon such finding, the building official shall notify the board of his finding and the board shall give notice in writing of such finding to the owner and occupant, if any, of the building and shall set forth in such notice a time and place that the owner and occupant may appear before the board to show cause why such dangerous building should not be repaired, vacated or demolished, as the case may be. 
(4)  The notice under this section shall set forth (i) the location of the building; (ii) a statement of the particulars which cause the building to exist in violation of the provisions of this section; (iii) a general statement of the work to be undertaken, if the building can be repaired; and (iv) the time and place of the hearing before the board. If, in the opinion of the building official, the continued occupancy of the building will cause imminent peril to life or property, the board or the building official may order the vacation of the building forthwith. 
(5)  The notice under this section shall be given in the following manner: 
a.
