To persons who are the owners of such buildings, by delivering a copy thereof to them in person; or if they cannot be found at their usual place of abode in the city, by delivering such copy and giving information of its purport to any person found there who is a member of their family, other than a temporary sojourner or guest, above the age of 16 years; or if neither they nor any such person is found there, by leaving such copy posted at the front door of such place of abode. 
b.  To persons who are owners of such buildings who are infants or insane, by delivering a copy thereof to their guardian or committee in person; or if such guardian or committee cannot be found at his usual place of abode in the city, by delivering such copy and information of its purport to any person found there who is a member of his family, other than a temporary sojourner or guest, above the age of 16 years; or if neither he nor any such person is found there, by leaving such copy posted at the front door of such place of abode. 
c.  To a corporation, bank, trust company or other corporate entity who is the owner of such building, by delivering a copy thereof to its president or other officer, manager, director or agent thereof in the city; or if such person cannot be found at the office or place of business in the city of such corporation, bank, trust company or corporate entity, by delivering a copy to any employee thereof found at such office or place of business giving information of its purport; or if no such person is found at such office or place of business, by leaving such copy posted at the front door of such office or place of business. 
d.  If an owner of such building is unknown or cannot with reasonable diligence be found in the city or has no place of abode, office or place of business in the city, the notice shall be given by posting a copy thereof on such building in such place on the front thereof as can be easily and readily seen and by mailing a copy thereof by registered mail to the last known street and post office address of such owner, and the proof of such mailing shall be sufficient evidence of serving notice by mail. 
e.  To an occupant of any building, by delivering a copy thereof to him in person; or if he cannot be found at such building, by delivering a copy and giving information of its purport to any person found there who is a member of his family, other than a temporary sojourner or guest, above the age of 16 years; or if neither he nor any such person is found there, by leaving such copy posted at the front door of such building. If, in the opinion of the building official, the continued occupancy of the building will cause imminent peril to life or property, the board or the building official may order the vacation of the building forthwith. 
f.  The notice shall be served by any officer having authority to serve notices under Code of Virginia, § 8.01-293, who shall make return of the manner and time of service thereof to the board. 
g.  The building official shall, upon order of the board, post on the front door of such building in such place as can be easily and readily seen the following notice, and it shall be unlawful to remove such notice from the building until the order of the board with respect to the building is complied with or unless it is necessary to remove the notice in order to comply with such order: 
"Warning-This building is unsafe and its use or occupancy has been prohibited by the City of Salem, Virginia. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation or their agents to remove this notice without written permission of the building official. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter this building without permission of the building official." 
(6)  The board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing and shall decide the issue within reasonable time. At the hearing before the board, the owner and occupant may appear in person, by agent or attorney, and shall be given an opportunity to be heard. The board shall have the power and it shall be its duty to enter such order or may make such requirement or determination as shall be entered or made. The concurring affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the board shall be necessary to comprise the order of the board. The board shall act by formal resolution, which shall set forth the reason for its action, and the vote of each member participating therein, which shall be spread upon its records, and shall be open to public inspection. Every decision of the board shall be based upon a finding of fact and sworn testimony. The actions or decisions of the board shall be final, and its proceedings may not be stayed otherwise than by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
If, on hearing of the case, the board shall find that the building in question is a dangerous building or structure, it shall enter an order that such building be repaired, vacated or demolished, as the case may be. The board shall: 
a.  Order a building to be repaired when it can be reasonably done so that it will not exist in violation of the provisions of this section; 
b.  Order the occupants thereof to vacate such building when it is in such condition as to make it detrimental to public health or safety; or 
c.  Order the demolition of such building in any other case where the building cannot or will not be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the provisions of this section. 
The order shall specify the time in which the work is to be completed and the day on or before which the work of repair or removal is to be begun. The order shall further specify the repairs which will be necessary if the owner elects to repair rather than remove the building or structure, and such order shall further specify the time in which such vacation is to take place should such building be ordered vacated. A copy of the order shall be given to the owner or occupant or to any person appearing on the owner's behalf, and, should the board deem it advisable, the board may order a notice to be posted on the front door of such building or structure as provided in subsection (5) of this section. 
(7)  If an owner fails to appear or refuses or neglects to comply with the order of the board, the board may order the building to be repaired or demolished, and the building official shall cause the building to be repaired or demolished upon such order of the board and shall submit to the city treasurer a statement of all costs incurred thereby, which shall be added to the taxes for the ensuing tax year assessed against the real estate on which the building stood and shall be collected with such taxes by any manner prescribed by law for the collection of such taxes. 
(8)  If an occupant refuses or neglects to comply with the order of the board, the board shall cause a summons to be issued by the clerk of the general district court against the occupant based upon a statement made in writing by the board to the clerk under oath of the facts which authorize the removal of the occupant from the building. The summons shall be served upon the occupant, together with a copy of the statement, by the authorized officer in the manner provided for the service of the notice upon the occupant under the provisions of subsection (5) of this section. It shall be returned to the general district court and the case shall be heard and determined by such court. Such summons shall be served at least five days before the return day thereof. The case shall be heard upon a plea of not guilty, and upon this issue the court shall determine whether the occupant retains possession of the building in violation of the order of the board, and upon finding that such order is being violated, shall issue a writ directed to the authorized officer commanding him to remove the occupant and his goods or chattels from the building. All costs and expenses incurred in the issuance and service of such summons, the trial of the issue and removing the occupant and his goods and chattels shall be recoverable against the occupant in such proceeding. 
(9)  Every owner or occupant who shall fail, refuse or neglect to comply with the order of the board, or otherwise violate the provisions of this section, shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-7 of the City Code. 
(Code 1969, § 6-5.1) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
Sec. 18-39. - Bond requirements. 
    All persons filing for a building, electrical, plumbing, mechanical or sign permit, unless that person is a state class A or B registered contractor, shall, before the permit is granted, file with the building official a continuing bond in the penal sum of not less than $10,000.00 executed by the applicant and a surety company to be approved by the city attorney. This bond shall be so conditioned that all work performed by or under the supervision of the contractor shall be in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall indemnify the city or the owner of the property against damages by reason of any defect arising out of such construction. It shall further be conditioned to refund to the city or the property owner any money expended to correct any work or repair any damage done or caused by the contractor in the execution of his work and further conditioned to save harmless any other person for whom the contractor or his employees may perform construction or furnish materials, and that the contractor will pay all fees, all fines, and penalties properly imposed upon such contractor for violation of any provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 6-5.2) 
Sec. 18-40. - Allowing one's name, license or bond to be used to obtain permit fraudulently. 
    No person bonded and licensed by the city shall allow his name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit or for the construction of any work under his name, license or bond, nor shall he make any misrepresentations or omissions in his returns. 
(Code 1969, § 6-5.3) 
Sec. 18-41. - Certificate of compliance. 
    Upon the change of occupancy in existing buildings, the building official shall make or cause to be made inspections under the provisions of Volume II of the Uniform Statewide Building Code (National Property Maintenance Code). 
(Code 1969, § 6-5.4; Ord. of 3-11-96) 
Secs. 18-42-18-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Electricity in mobile home parks, § 54-47; poles and wires, § 74-136 et seq.; city electric system, § 90-26 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-166. - Short circuiting fuse plugs. 
    No person shall short circuit fuse plugs, by the use of any metal or otherwise, anywhere on the city electrical system, whether within or without the city. 
(Code 1969, § 8-1) 
Secs. 18-167-18-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 18-186. - Appointment, etc. 
    The city manager shall appoint an electrical inspector, whose salary shall be fixed by the council and his term of office by the city manager. He shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 8-2) 
Sec. 18-187. - Duties generally. 
    The electrical inspector shall see that the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relative to electric wiring and the installation and maintenance of electrical equipment and appliances are enforced, and he shall perform such other duties as may from time to time be assigned to him. 
(Code 1969, § 8-3) 
Sec. 18-188. - Right of entry. 
    The electrical inspector may, in the discharge of his duties under this chapter, enter at all reasonable hours any building, manhole or subway or climb any pole, for the purpose of examining and testing the electrical appliances therein or thereon contained and, for that purpose, he shall be given prompt access to all buildings, public and private, and to all manholes, subways or poles on application to the individual or company owning or in charge of such building, manhole, subway or pole. 
(Code 1969, § 8-4) 
Sec. 18-189. - Removal of defective wire or appliance and unsafe conditions. 
    Whenever any electric wire or appliance shall be defective through improper or insufficient installation or for any other reason or otherwise become unsafe as determined by the electrical inspector, the electrical inspector shall at once cause or direct the removal of such defective wire, appliance or unsafe conditions at the expense of the owner of the premises. 
(Code 1969, § 8-5; Ord. of 2-26-2018(1)) 
Sec. 18-190. - Failure, etc., to correct defects after notice. 
    Any person engaging in the business of electrical construction and of the installation of wiring and apparatus for electric light, heat or power in the city failing to correct any defect in his work, after having been given ten days' notice by the electrical inspector, shall not receive any further permit until such defect has been corrected. It shall be unlawful for the recipient of any such notice to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such notice within the period thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 8-6) 
Sec. 18-191. - Forfeiture of license for continual, etc., violation of provisions of Code, etc., as to electrical affairs. 
    In any case in which a person engaging in the business of electrical construction and of the installation of wiring and apparatus for electric light, heat or power in the city shall continually or persistently violate the provisions of this Code or any other ordinance of the city in regard to electrical affairs or the orders of the electrical inspector touching the same, the license such person holds to engage in business as set out in this section shall be forfeited. 
(Code 1969, § 8-7) 
Cross reference- Licensing, § 22-36 et seq. 
Sec. 18-192. - Permit for wiring of building or alteration of wiring generally; application therefor. 
(a)  No building shall be wired for electric lights, motors or heating devices and no alteration shall be made in the wiring of any building for light, heat or power or to increase the load carried by such wires without a written permit therefor from the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(b)  Any person desiring a permit as required in subsection (a) shall file an application therefor with the city manager or his duly authorized representative. Such application shall be submitted in such form and contain such information as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 8-8) 
Sec. 18-193. - Record of work done, permits, etc.; annual report. 
    The city manager or his duly authorized representative shall keep a full and complete daily record of all work done, permits and licenses issued, examinations made, and other official work performed, as required by this article. The city manager shall make a report thereof to the council on or before June 30 of each year. 
(Code 1969, § 8-9) 
Sec. 18-194. - Inspection of wiring; certificates of satisfactory inspection. 
    Upon the completion of the wiring of any building for light, heat or power, it shall be the duty of the company, firm or individual doing such wiring to notify the electrical inspector, who shall have such wiring and appliances inspected at once and, if approved, he shall have a certificate of satisfactory inspection issued, which shall contain the date of such inspection and an outline of the result of the examination. No such certificate of satisfactory inspection shall be issued unless such electric wiring and appliances are in strict conformity to the rules and regulations prescribed or required by this article, nor shall current be turned on such installation until such certificate is issued. 
(Code 1969, § 8-10) 
Sec. 18-195. - Inspection fees. 
    Prior to the issuance of the certificate of satisfactory inspection required under section 18-194, the person applying therefor shall pay the city treasurer an inspection fee in conformity to the table or schedule established by the council. 
(Code 1969, § 8-11) 
Sec. 18-196. - Discontinuance of service for failure to comply with article. 
    In any case of failure of any person to comply with this article, the electrical inspector shall have authority, after due notice, to discontinue electric service in any locality concerned and to enforce discontinuance of such electric service until such requirements are complied with. 
(Code 1969, § 8-12) 
City electric system, § 90-26 et seq. 
Sec. 18-197. - Referral to city manager of appeals from electrical inspector's decisions, etc. 
    Any difference of opinion caused by the interpretation of the provisions of this article between the electrical inspector and any electrician, any appeal from a decision of the electrical inspector, or any complaint against the electrical inspector shall be referred to the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 8-13) 
Secs. 18-198-18-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 18-226. - Adoption. 
(a)  Pursuant to state law, there is hereby adopted by reference the 1990 edition of the National Electrical Code of the National Fire Protection Association, for electrical wiring and apparatus, as approved by the American Standards Association, as amended, as fully as though completely set out in this division. The installation and use of electrical wiring and apparatus within the city, all electrical construction, and all material and appliances used in connection with electrical work and the operation of all electrical apparatus within the city shall conform to the rules and requirements of such edition of the National Electrical Code adopted in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the 1990 edition of the National Electrical Code hereby adopted. 
(Code 1969, § 8-14) 
Sec. 18-227. - When and where copies may be obtained. 
    Copies of the National Electrical Code, 1990 edition, adopted as provided in section 18-226, may be obtained at the office of the building official during regular business hours. 
(Code 1969, § 8-15) 
Secs. 18-228-18-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 90. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-261. - Application of article. 
    This article shall apply to all plumbing within the city and likewise shall apply to all plumbing connected with the city water system and the city sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 19-1) 
Sec. 18-262. - Performance of plumbing work, etc., by registered plumber. 
    No person other than a plumber, registered as provided in section 18-1, shall engage in the actual performance of plumbing work or, subject to the provisions of chapter 90, make any connection with any sewer, drain, soil, waste or water pipe or any other pipe connected therewith. 
(Code 1969, § 19-12) 
Sec. 18-263. - Connection of downspout, etc., to sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect, permit to be connected, construct or maintain, or suffer to be constructed or maintained, on any premises belonging to such person or under his control, any downspout, roof drain, surface drain, stormwater drain or any other conductor of surface or storm water which is discharged into the city sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Where any downspout, drain or conductor of surface or storm water is in any manner connected to the city sanitary sewer system, it shall be the duty of both the owner and the lessee of the property on which such downspout, drain or conductor of surface or storm water exists to remove, sever or break the connection thereof with the sanitary sewer into which it is discharged, and to so provide that such conductor shall not discharge into the city sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 19-2) 
Secs. 18-264-18-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 18-286. - Appointment, etc. 
    The city manager shall appoint a plumbing inspector, whose salary shall be fixed by the council and his term of office by the city manager. He shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 19-3) 
Sec. 18-287. - Duties generally. 
    The plumbing inspector shall see that the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relative to plumbing are enforced, and he shall perform other duties as may from time to time be assigned to him. 
(Code 1969, § 19-4) 
Sec. 18-288. - Inspection and right of entry. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the right, at all reasonable hours, to inspect all buildings or premises within the city for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article and to enter buildings or premises for such purpose. 
(Code 1969, § 19-5) 
Sec. 18-289. - Referral to city manager of appeals from plumbing inspector's decisions, etc. 
    Any difference of opinion caused by the interpretation of the provisions of this article between the plumbing inspector and any master plumber, appeals from the plumbing inspector's decision, or complaints against the plumbing inspector shall be referred to the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 19-6) 
Secs. 18-290-18-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT FOR PLUMBING WORK 

Sec. 18-311. - Required. 
    A plumber, registered as provided in this article, desiring to do plumbing work in relation to the sanitary arrangements of any building shall first get a written permit therefor from the plumbing inspector; provided, however, that no permit is required for such ordinary repairs as defined by the Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1969, § 19-7) 
Sec. 18-312. - Fees. 
    Any permittee under section 18-311 shall pay, to the appropriate city officer, such permit or inspection fee as may be established by the council. 
(Code 1969, § 19-8) 
Sec. 18-313. - Permit for person not in employment of permittee; procedure when plumbing job is not finished by plumber who started it. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any plumber to take out a permit, as required in section 18-311, in contemplation of plumbing work which is to be done by any person not in his employment. 
(b)  Before any plumber undertakes to complete a job of plumbing work started by another, he must first have the work theretofore completely inspected before proceeding further. 
(Code 1969, § 19-9) 
Secs. 18-314-18-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SWIMMING POOLS WITH PUBLIC FINANCING, MEMBERSHIP FEES OR PAID ADMISSION[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Powers of city as to swimming pools (Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-858, 15.2-886) adopted, § 2.2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-351. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Maximum load or design load means the maximum number of persons permitted in the swimming pool at any one time and shall be determined by dividing the total square footage of swimming pool water surface area by 27. 
    Operator or manager means the individual responsible for operation and management of the swimming pool. 
    Swimming pool means any artificial swimming, wading or spray pool intended for recreational purposes, including all appurtenant equipment, structures and facilities, provided by any person or political subdivision for the use of guests who gain access through public financing or by membership fees or paid admission. 
(Code 1969, § 27-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-352. - Application of article. 
(a)  The structural and equipment provisions and requirements of this article shall not apply to any swimming pool constructed prior to the effective date of this section, except as follows: 
(1)  When any condition exists in such swimming pool that would endanger the health, safety or life of any person, the health director may order such swimming pool closed until such condition is corrected. Provided, that such owner, operator or manager of such swimming pool furnishes evidence satisfactory to the health director of his intention to comply with the provisions and requirements deemed necessary by the health director. 
(2)  When any material alteration or structural change is made to any pool, or when any placement or replacement of any substantial equipment is made to any such swimming pool. 
(b)  The provisions and requirements of this article with respect to operational procedures and standards and lifeguards shall be complied with by all operators or managers of swimming pools, regardless of the date of construction thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 27-2) 
Editor's note- The ordinance codified as this article was adopted on January 22, 1962, to be in full force and effect 30 days after passage. The above section was amended on May 28, 1962, by an emergency ordinance. 
Sec. 18-353. - Permit prerequisite to construction; plans and specifications. 
    A permit shall be obtained from the building official before the construction, remodeling or major alteration of any swimming pool. Plans and specifications for use in connection with such construction, remodeling or major alteration shall have been approved by the building official and the health director prior to the issuance of such permit. Plans and specifications for use in connection with such construction, remodeling or major alteration shall be submitted in triplicate to the building official and one set of plans and specifications, when approved, will be so stamped and returned to the person filing the application for such permit. Original tracings will not be stamped for approval. 
(Code 1969, § 27-3) 
Sec. 18-354. - Operation without license or permit. 
    No person shall operate a swimming pool without a license or permit. 
(Code 1969, § 27-4) 
Sec. 18-355. - Procedure when article is not complied with or dangerous conditions exist. 
    When the health director finds that the provisions of this article are not met or that any condition exists that endangers the life, health or safety of the users of any bathing place, he may order the facility closed until the condition is corrected. Continued failure to comply with this article shall be cause for revocation of any operating license or permit issued as required in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 27-5) 
Sec. 18-356. - Penalty for violating article. 
    Any person violating, or aiding or abetting any violation of, any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 27-6) 
Secs. 18-357-18-375. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 18-376. - Compliance with division. 
    The operation of swimming pools shall be in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 27-7) 
Sec. 18-377. - Operating records. 
    The person responsible for the operation of a swimming pool shall keep or maintain such records of the operation of such swimming pool as may be required by the health director. These records shall be kept on file for a period of at least one year from their submission. 
(Code 1969, § 27-8) 
Sec. 18-378. - Lifeguards and lifesaving equipment. 
    The management of any swimming pool available for use of guests or members, whether for pay or not, shall designate a reliable and competent person as a lifeguard. The management shall further provide for the use of this lifeguard such lifesaving equipment as may be required, depending upon the size and depth of the pool. The number of lifeguards and the required proficiencies, conforming to the standards established by the American Red Cross for lifesaving personnel, shall be determined by the design and depth of pools and the number of bathers. 
(Code 1969, § 27-9) 
Secs. 18-379-18-400. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Dressing Rooms 

Sec. 18-401. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this subdivision shall apply to dressing rooms at swimming pools. 
(Code 1969, § 27-10) 
Sec. 18-402. - Soap. 
    Soap shall be provided at each shower and lavatory of swimming pool dressing rooms. 
(Code 1969, § 27-11) 
Sec. 18-403. - Common use of brushes, combs, etc. 
    The common use of brushes, combs, towels and drinking utensils in swimming pool dressing rooms is prohibited. 
(Code 1969, § 27-12) 
Sec. 18-404. - Suits and towels. 
    Suits and towels in swimming pool dressing rooms shall be laundered and handled in a sanitary and safe manner. 
(Code 1969, § 27-13) 
Sec. 18-405. - Floor. 
    The floor of the dressing room shall be maintained in a clean and dry condition when the swimming pool is not in use. 
(Code 1969, § 27-14) 
Sec. 18-406. - General housekeeping. 
    All of the dressing room facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary and safe manner. Toilet paper shall be provided at each water closet and female urinal. 
(Code 1969, § 27-15) 
Secs. 18-407-18-430. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Water 

Sec. 18-431. - Operation of chlorination equipment. 
    The chlorination equipment at a swimming pool shall be operated so as to maintain a free chlorine residual content of not less than 0.5 parts per million at all points throughout the swimming pool water when there are bathers present. 
(Code 1969, § 27-16) 
Sec. 18-432. - Alkalinity. 
    With reference to the alkalinity of the water in a swimming pool, the hydrogen-ion concentration shall be maintained at 7.2 or above. 
(Code 1969, § 27-17) 
Sec. 18-433. - Filtration. 
    The filters at a swimming pool shall be operated 24 hours per day during the days the swimming pool is in use. At all times when the swimming pool is open for use, the water shall be sufficiently clear to permit a disc six inches in diameter, divided into alternate black and white quadrants, when placed on the bottom of the pool at the deepest point, to be clearly visible from the swimming pool deck at all distances up to ten yards in a horizontal direction from projection of the disc on the swimming pool surface. 
(Code 1969, § 27-18) 
Sec. 18-434. - Use of chemicals. 
    Chemicals other than chlorine, sodium or calcium hypochlorite, lime, soda ash and aluminum sulfate shall not be used to treat swimming pool water without written permission of the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-19) 
Sec. 18-435. - Posting of placard in filter room. 
    In the filter room at each swimming pool, there shall be prominently displayed a placard showing the following data: 
(1)  Size of the swimming pool in feet and volume in gallons; 
(2)  Capacity of the filters in square feet and gallons per minute; 
(3)  Capacity of the pumps in gallons per minute at the appropriate head in feet; 
(4)  Head loss at which the filters should be backwashed; and 
(5)  Complete instructions for operating the recirculation and disinfection equipment. 
(Code 1969, § 27-20) 
Secs. 18-436-18-450. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Pool Area 

Sec. 18-451. - Spectators, etc., on the deck. 
    At a swimming pool, no spectators, visitors or other persons other than bathers shall be allowed on the deck of the swimming pool. 
(Code 1969, § 27-21) 
Sec. 18-452. - Persons eating or drinking. 
    At a swimming pool, any person in the process of eating or drinking shall be restricted to the area designated for the preparation and serving of food. 
(Code 1969, § 27-22) 
Secs. 18-453-18-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION GENERALLY 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Secs. 18-461-18-470. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Pools and Pool Areas 

Sec. 18-471. - Water supply; certain piping arrangements prohibited. 
    All water used in swimming pools shall be from sources that are approved by the health director. No piping arrangements shall exist which, under any conditions, will permit sewage or wastewater to enter the swimming pool water system or water from the swimming pool to enter the city's water supply. 
(Code 1969, § 27-23) 
Sec. 18-472. - Location. 
    No swimming pool shall be so located as, in any way, to adversely affect its sanitary operation, bather's safety or water quality. 
(Code 1969, § 27-24) 
Sec. 18-473. - Materials. 
    Materials used in connection with swimming pools shall provide a rigid type tight tank with light color and smooth and easily cleaned surfaces. 
(Code 1969, § 27-25) 
Sec. 18-474. - Shape, contour and slope. 
    Each swimming pool shall be designed and constructed of such shape, contour and slope that efficient and safe control of the bathers can be accomplished. In water depths under five feet, the slope of the bottom of a swimming pool shall not exceed one foot in 12 feet. 
(Code 1969, § 27-26) 
Sec. 18-475. - Decks. 
    There shall be a deck at least four feet wide extending around the entire perimeter of each swimming pool. Such deck shall be constructed of concrete or other approved materials. The material shall have a nonslip but smooth finish. Such deck shall have a pitch of not less than one-eighth of an inch nor more than five-eighths of an inch to the foot and be so designed as to conduct drainage away from the pool area in a manner that will not create or maintain pools of water or a nuisance. 
(Code 1969, § 27-27) 
Sec. 18-476. - Steps and ladders. 
    Two or more ladders shall be provided for each swimming pool having a perimeter greater than 100 feet and one ladder for a pool 100 feet or less. Steps projecting into the swimming pool area shall not be permitted. Treads of all steps, ladders or other means of egress shall be of nonslip construction. Each recessed step area shall be provided with one or more handrails. 
(Code 1969, § 27-28) 
Sec. 18-477. - Overflow facilities. 
(a)  Provision shall be made in each swimming pool for the removal of floating materials and scum from the surface of the water. 
(b)  If a recessed type of gutter located near the top of the walls is used, the gutter shall have a minimum depth of three inches and shall be of a design which will permit satisfactory cleaning of the overflow channel. The lip of the scum gutter shall be level and be designed to serve as a handhold for bathers. The gutter drain outlets shall be spaced around the pool not more than 15 feet on centers. The gutter bottom shall slope toward these outlets with a minimum slope of one-eighth inch to the foot. The drains shall not be less than 21/2 inches in diameter and the total orifice area of the grating shall be at least twice the cross-sectional area of the outlet pipe. The above-described gutter may be replaced by an arrangement of overflow devices in the walls which will provide the proper removal of scum and floating material. There shall be one such device for each 400 square feet of pool area with a minimum of four per pool, each of which shall be individually controlled. 
(c)  If the recirculation system is designed for water to enter the bottom portion of the pool and overflow the top, then adequate measures for the proper removal of the scum and floating material from the deck shall be provided. This may be by a continuous drain or multiple drains. If multiple drains are used, each drain grating shall have a total orifice area of at least four times the cross-sectional area of drainpipe, which shall have a minimum diameter of 21/2 inches. In the use of drain channels continuous around the perimeter of the pool, the channel grating shall be designed so as not to create a hazard to fingers and toes, and shall be resistant to corrosion. 
(Code 1969, § 27-29) 
Sec. 18-478. - Inlets and outlets; disposal of wastewater to storm sewer, etc. 
(a)  The inlets for the recirculation of water in a swimming pool shall be submerged and be so located as to produce uniform circulation of water throughout the swimming pool without the existence of dead spots. Wall inlets shall be located on not more than 20-foot centers entirely around the perimeter of the swimming pool. Bottom inlets shall be spaced, depending on the pool dimensions, so as to produce uniform water circulation. If used, the number of bottom inlets shall be the same as required for wall inlets. Each inlet is to be designed as an adjustable orifice or provided with a valve. 
(b)  An outlet drain shall be provided for completely emptying the swimming pool and direct connection thereof to a sanitary sewer shall not be permitted. The outlet drain shall be covered with a grate of such design that it cannot be readily removed by or produce any hazard to the bathers. 
(c)  Disposal of wastewater to a storm sewer or natural watercourse shall be subject to approval of the city manager and the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-30) 
Sec. 18-479. - Marking of depth. 
    The depth of the water in a swimming pool shall be marked at every one-foot increment of depth, in water depths five feet and under, on both sides of the pool. In water deeper than five feet, the markings shall be no further apart than three feet. Numerals and letters shall be at least five inches in size and of good contrast with the walls and deck. 
(Code 1969, § 27-31) 
Sec. 18-480. - Lighting. 
    Where swimming pools are to be used after dark, the swimming pool area shall be equipped with lighting fixtures of such number and design as to light all parts of the pool, the water therein, and the entire area. Fixtures shall be installed in such a manner as to create no hazard to the bathers. The design and installation of the fixtures shall be such that lifeguards can clearly see every part of the swimming pool including decks, diving boards, and other appurtenances without being blinded by glare. 
(Code 1969, § 27-32) 
Sec. 18-481. - Drinking water. 
    At each swimming pool, a safely dispensed approved supply of drinking water shall be readily accessible to the bathers. 
(Code 1969, § 27-33) 
Sec. 18-482. - Preparation, etc., of food and drink. 
    Food and drink preparation, serving and consumption and consumption facilities shall be permitted at a swimming pool only within designated areas approved for these purposes by the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-34) 
Sec. 18-483. - Unobstructed headroom above diving board. 
    At any swimming pool, at least 12 feet of free and unobstructed headroom shall be provided above the diving boards. 
(Code 1969, § 27-35) 
Sec. 18-484. - Dimensions, etc., of diving areas. 
(a)  At any swimming pool, the minimum depth of water and minimum dimensions in diving areas shall be determined as follows: 
Elevation of

(b)  At any swimming pool, the minimum length of any diving area terminating at a vertical wall shall be 30 feet. 
(c)  Where multiple diving boards are used at any swimming pool, the space between centerlines shall be not less than ten feet, and the centerline of no board shall be closer than ten feet to a side wall, nor shall the diving end of the board be closer than ten feet to the wall in which it is attached. Where multiple diving boards are used and are elevated from three to five meters above water level, the above measurements shall be increased to a minimum depth of 15 feet, and for those elevated five to ten meters above water level, the minimum depth shall be 18 feet. 
(Code 1969, § 27-36) 
Secs. 18-485-18-500. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Dressing Room Facilities 

Sec. 18-501. - Exception to application of subdivision. 
    The provisions of this subdivision shall not be construed to apply to a swimming pool serving patrons of transient or lodging accommodations. 
(Code 1969, § 27-37) 
Sec. 18-502. - Dressing rooms to be provided. 
    A dressing room for each sex shall be provided at each swimming pool. 
(Code 1969, § 27-38) 
Sec. 18-503. - Disposition of liquid waste. 
    All liquid waste from any dressing room at a swimming pool shall be discharged to an approved public sewerage system or to sewage disposal facilities approved by the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-39) 
Sec. 18-504. - Lockers, etc. 
    Metal lockers, wire baskets, hooks or other sanitary means of storage of clothing and personal accessories shall be provided at each dressing room at a swimming pool, but wooden lockers or cloth bags shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1969, § 27-40) 
Sec. 18-505. - Floors. 
    The floors of a dressing room at a swimming pool shall have a minimum pitch of three inches in ten feet to the drains with no low spots which will allow water to stand. Such floors shall be of smooth but nonslip finish and the rooms shall be so ventilated that the floors do not remain damp or wet when the swimming pool is not in use. 
(Code 1969, § 27-41) 
Sec. 18-506. - Showers. 
    Showers shall be provided in dressing rooms at swimming pools in the proportion of one for each 40 persons of each sex at the time of maximum load. Each shower shall supply an adequate quantity of heated water through a device that will prevent scalding. Drainage from each shower shall be such as to prevent water from one shower draining across the floor area of another. Each shower shall be equipped with suitable facilities for making soap available. 
(Code 1969, § 27-42) 
Sec. 18-507. - Toilet facilities. 
    Toilet facilities shall be provided in dressing rooms at swimming pools in proportion of one water closet for each 40 females or one water closet and one urinal for each 60 females at the time of maximum load. One water closet and one urinal shall be provided for each 60 males at the time of maximum load. The urinals and water closets shall be so located that the bathers will pass by them and then by the showers and lavatory on their way to the swimming pool. 
(Code 1969, § 27-43) 
Sec. 18-508. - Lavatories. 
    Lavatories shall be provided in dressing rooms at swimming pools in the proportion of one for each 60 persons of each sex at the time of maximum load. Each lavatory shall be provided with suitable facilities for making soap available. 
(Code 1969, § 27-44) 
Secs. 18-509-18-525. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Recirculation System and Appurtenances 

Sec. 18-526. - Recirculation system generally. 
    All swimming pools shall be equipped with a recirculation system consisting of pumps, hair and lint catcher, filters, disinfection equipment, and necessary pipe connections to the inlets and outlets. Adequate provision shall be made for backwashing filters. The recirculation system shall be designed for an eight-hour or less turnover of the swimming pool water. 
(Code 1969, § 27-45) 
Sec. 18-527. - Filter rooms. 
(a)  Any room containing the filtration equipment, pumps and other recirculation system appurtenances shall be finished in a light color and be provided with adequate illumination and ventilation. The floor of the filter room shall be designed to provide adequate drainage. The provision of any facility for discharging filter back- washing water onto the filter room floor is strictly prohibited. 
(b)  All of the recirculation equipment in the filter room shall be so installed that it is convenient to operate or repair such equipment. All entrances below ground surface shall be by stair- way. Adequate headroom shall be provided above all filters. 
(Code 1969, § 27-46) 
Sec. 18-528. - Pumping equipment. 
    The pumping equipment forming part of a recirculation system at a swimming pool shall have sufficient capacity to discharge the volume of water for the required turnover of the pool against the maximum head in the recirculation system. The pump used for backwashing sand filters shall have sufficient capacity to backwash the unit at the rate of at least 12 gallons per minute per square foot of filter area against maximum head. 
(Code 1969, § 27-47) 
Sec. 18-529. - Hair and lint catcher. 
    The hair and lint catcher forming part of a recirculation system at a swimming pool shall be installed ahead of the filter pump and be so designed and located that it can be easily and simply dismantled for cleaning and inspection. 
(Code 1969, § 27-48) 
Sec. 18-530. - Filters. 
(a)  The recirculation system of any swimming pool shall be equipped with a filtration system that will filter the entire contents of the swimming pool within eight hours or less at the rates of three gallons or less per square foot per minute. 
(b)  In sand filters, the layer of filter sand shall be at least 20 inches in depth, properly supported by uniform layers of clean, graded gravel to a minimum depth of 12 inches, or supported by porous plates. The filter sand shall have an effective size between 0.45 and 0.55 millimeter, with a uniformity coefficient of not greater than 1.7. 
(c)  In anthracite coal filters, the anthracite shall have a depth of at least 24 inches and shall have an effective size between 0.6 and 0.8 millimeter with a uniformity coefficient of not greater than 1.8. 
(d)  Pressure filters shall be equipped with readily accessible air relief valves and with an access hole large enough to permit inspection, maintenance and repair work. Each pressure filter system shall be equipped with a pressure gauge on the inlet and outlet to indicate the loss of head in pounds per square inch. A sight glass that can be easily removed for cleaning shall be provided on the waste discharge line. 
(e)  Gravity-type filters shall be equipped with loss of head gauges. 
(f)  The filtration rate for diatomaceous earth filters and similar equipment may not exceed two gallons per square foot of filter area with eight hours' turnover of pool volume. 
(g)  Arrangements or equipment shall be provided for application of filter aid and proper precoating and cleaning of filter elements. It will be necessary to evaluate such equipment individually, and approval or rejection shall be at the discretion of the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-49) 
Sec. 18-531. - Rate of flow indicators. 
    The recirculation system at a swimming pool shall be equipped with a rate of flow indicator reading in gallons per minute, so located as to indicate the rate of flow of the effluent from the filter and also the rate of backwash in gallons per minute in sand or anthracite coal filters. 
(Code 1969, § 27-50) 
Sec. 18-532. - Suction cleaners. 
    A suction cleaner shall be provided at each swimming pool. Where the suction cleaner is operated by the recirculating pump, a device shall be provided for throttling the flow from the pool outlet and the suction cleaner line shall be connected through the hair and lint catcher. 
(Code 1969, § 27-51) 
Sec. 18-533. - Equipment for feeding chemicals to water. 
    Means shall be provided at each swimming pool for regulating the feeding of chemicals to the water in the recirculation system. The installation of mechanically operated, positive, chemical feeders or open-type chemical machines is required. The installation of closed-type solution pots is prohibited. 
(Code 1969, § 27-52) 
Sec. 18-534. - Disinfection and disinfection equipment. 
(a)  All swimming pools shall be provided with approved chlorine feeding equipment. The chlorinating equipment shall be capable of applying a dose up to six parts per million of chlorine at the rate of recirculation. Chlorine gas feeding equipment and chlorine gas cylinders shall be installed in an enclosed space or room separate from the filter room equipped with a door capable of being locked. When this chlorinator room is tight, it shall be equipped with a forced draft fan exhausting to the outside from the floor level and a fresh air inlet shall be provided near the ceiling. Unless the topography makes it difficult or impossible, the chlorinator room shall be located above ground level and below deck level of the swimming pool. The chlorine gas tanks shall be protected from direct sunlight and fastened in place during storage and use. An approved type gas mask shall be provided where chlorine gas is being utilized. This shall be located accessible to, but outside of, the chlorinator room. 
(b)  Nothing in subsection (a) shall be construed as prohibiting any other method of disinfection or equipment demonstrated as of at least equal efficiency and approved by the health director. 
(Code 1969, § 27-53) 
Sec. 18-535. - Chemical testing equipment. 
    Each swimming pool shall be provided with approved equipment for the determination of hydrogen-ion concentration (pH) ranging from 6.8 to 8.0. Satisfactory equipment shall also be provided for determination of residual chlorine content ranging from 0 to 1.0 parts per million. 
(Code 1969, § 27-54) 
Secs. 18-536-18-550. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF WADING POOLS 

Sec. 18-551. - Water supply, lighting, overflow facilities, inlets and outlets. 
    Water supply, lighting, overflow facilities, inlets and outlets for wading pools shall meet the requirements set forth in division 3 of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 27-55) 
Sec. 18-552. - Location. 
    Wading pools shall be so located that drainage from surrounding areas will not wash contamination into the pool during rainfall. 
(Code 1969, § 27-56) 
Sec. 18-553. - Slope of bottom. 
    The bottom of each wading pool shall slope not less than three inches in ten feet toward the drain. 
(Code 1969, § 27-57) 
Sec. 18-554. - Deck. 
    Each wading pool shall be entirely surrounded by a deck at least four feet in width, constructed of permanently impervious material which shall have and retain a finish as smooth as possible that is nonslip to bare feet. The deck shall slope not less than three inches in ten feet away from pool edge, and the water on the deck discharged to waste. 
(Code 1969, § 27-58) 
Sec. 18-555. - Separation from swimming pools. 
    Wading pools shall be separated from swimming pools and appropriate protection features, such as a fence, shall be installed. 
(Code 1969, § 27-59) 
Sec. 18-556. - Dressing rooms. 
    Separate dressing room facilities will not be required when a wading pool is operated in conjunction with a swimming pool. If the wading pool is not operated with a swimming pool, then the requirements of division 3 of this article shall apply. 
(Code 1969, § 27-60) 
Sec. 18-557. - Recirculation of water; disposal of wastewater. 
    A complete recirculation system shall be installed at wading pools which cannot be served adequately by an adjacent swimming pool recirculation system. The recirculation system shall provide a pool volume turnover rate of once in three hours or less. An alternate method of water circulation system is the continuous addition of water properly treated at a rate of flow sufficient to replace all of the water in the wading pool once in three hours or less. The overflow water, with this method, shall be continuously discharged to waste. The provisions for the disposal of wastewater contained in division 3 of this article shall apply to wading pools. 
(Code 1969, § 27-61) 
Secs. 18-558-18-580. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF SPRAY POOLS 

Sec. 18-581. - Application of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to spray pools. 
(Code 1969, § 27-62) 
Sec. 18-582. - Water supply; submergence of spray heads. 
    The water sprayed into a spray pool shall be from an approved supply. Spray heads shall be so installed that there will be no possibility for submergence. 
(Code 1969, § 27-63) 
Sec. 18-583. - Construction materials. 
    Spray pools shall be constructed of permanently impervious material that shall have and retain a finish as smooth as possible that is nonslip to bare feet. 
(Code 1969, § 27-64) 
Sec. 18-584. - Slope of bottom. 
    Spray pool bottoms shall slope not less than three inches in ten feet toward the drains. 
(Code 1969, § 27-65) 
Sec. 18-585. - Drains; disposal of wastewater. 
    The spray pool shall be equipped at its low point with an unvalved drain to waste. The drain shall be of such size and design that water sprayed into the pool will not pond in the pool bottom. The provisions for the disposal of wastewater contained in division 3 of this article shall apply to spray pools. 
(Code 1969, § 27-66) 
Sec. 18-586. - Deck. 
    The spray pool shall be entirely surrounded by a deck at least four feet in width, constructed of permanently impervious material which shall have and retain a finish as smooth as possible and nonslip to bare feet. The deck shall slope not less than three inches in ten feet away from the pool edge and water on the deck discharged to waste. 
(Code 1969, § 27-67) 
Secs. 18-587-18-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FENCING OF SWIMMING POOLS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt ordinance relative to fencing of swimming pools, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-29. 

Sec. 18-611. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fence means a close type vertical barrier not less than four feet in height above ground surface. A woven steel wire, chainlink, picket or solid board type fence or a fence of similar construction which will prevent the smallest of children from getting through shall be construed as within this definition. 
    Swimming pool means and includes any outdoor manmade structure constructed from material other than natural earth or soil designed or used to hold water for the purpose of providing a swimming or bathing place for any person or any such structure for the purpose of impounding water therein to a depth of more than two feet. 
(Code 1969, § 27-68) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-612. - Enclosure of swimming pool required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, maintain, use, possess or control any swimming pool on any property within the city without having a fence completely around such swimming pool; provided, however, that a dwelling house or accessory building may be used as part of such enclosure. 
(Code 1969, § 27-69) 
Sec. 18-613. - Self-closing and self-latching devices for gates or doors in fences. 
    All gates or doors opening through fences used in the enclosure of swimming pools shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use; provided, however, that the door of any dwelling or accessory building which forms a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped. All self-latching devices shall be not less than four feet above ground level. 
(Code 1969, § 27-70) 
Sec. 18-614. - Clearance of ground; distance from swimming pool. 
    Fences used in the enclosure of swimming pools shall be so constructed as to come within two inches of the ground at the bottom and shall be at least five feet at any point from the edge of the swimming pool. 
(Code 1969, § 27-71) 
Sec. 18-615. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Each violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $300.00 or confinement in jail for not more than 30 days, either or both. Each day that such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1969, § 27-72) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes:
