Sec. 22-74. - Short-term rental business. 
(a)  Every person conducting or operating a business which qualifies as a short-term rental business, as defined in section 82-178, shall pay an annual license tax as follows: If the amount of the gross receipts throughout the then next preceding calendar year did not exceed $15,000.00, then the license tax shall be $30.00 on the first $15,000.00 and $0.20 per $100.00 in excess of $15,000.00. 
(b)  The same penalty and interest as provided in this article shall apply to new licenses if not obtained within 30 days after the commencement of business. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-40A; Ord. of 11-13-89; Ord. of 12-10-90; Ord. of 1-14-91; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-75. - Professional service. 
(a)  Professional service means: A person is engaged in providing a professional service if engaged in rendering any service specifically enumerated below or engaged in any occupation or vocation in which a professed knowledge of some department of science or learning, gained by prolonged course of specialized instruction and study is used by its practical application to the affairs of others, either advising, guiding or teaching them, and in serving their interests or welfare in the practice of an art or science founded on it. The word profession and professional imply attainments in professional knowledge as distinguished from mere skill, and the application of knowledge to use for others as a vocation. 
(b)  Every person conducting or engaging in any of the professions or occupations enumerated in this section and maintaining an office within the city shall pay an annual license tax based upon gross receipts derived from such profession or occupation received during the preceding year. The license tax shall be as follows: When the gross receipts did not exceed $5,173.00, the license tax shall be $30.00; when such receipts exceed $5,173.00, the license tax shall be $30.00 on the first $5,173.00 plus $0.58 on every $100.00 in excess of $15,000.00. 
(c)  Those engaged in rendering a professional service include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Acupuncture. 
Architect. 
Attorney at law. 
Certified public accountant. 
Chiropractor. 
Dentist. 
Dermatologist. 
Doctor of dental surgery. 
Doctor of medicine. 
Doctor of veterinary medicine. 
Engineers, any and all types. 
Oculist. 
Optician. 
Optometrist. 
Osteopath. 
Pharmacist. 
Physiotherapist. 
Podiatrist. 
Psychologist. 
Surgeon. 
Surveyor. 
And any other professional service occupations. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-41; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-76. - Real estate service. 
(a)  Real estate service means any person rendering a service for compensation as lessor, buyer, seller, agent or broker. 
(b)  Every person conducting or engaging in any of the real estate services or occupations enumerated in this section and maintaining an office within the city shall pay an annual license tax of $30.00 for the first $5,173.00 of gross receipts, plus $0.58 per $100.00 in excess of $5,173.00 of gross receipts, namely: 
(c)  Those engaged in rendering a real estate service include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Appraisers of real estate. 
Escrow agents. 
Fiduciaries. 
Lessors of real estate. 
Real estate agents, brokers and managers. 
Rental agents for real estate. 
And other real estate services. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-42; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-77. - Financial service. 
(a)  Financial service means any person rendering a service for compensation in the form of a credit agency, an investment company, or a broker or dealer in securities and commodities exchange. 
(b)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Banks and trust companies subject to Virginia Bank Franchise Tax. 
(2)  Savings and loan companies (including those whose name includes "savings bank") and state chartered credit unions are limited to a license tax of $50.00. 
(3)  Federal Credit Unions are exempt under the Federal Credit Union Act. 
(c)  Every person conducting, operating or engaging in any of the following businesses, trades or occupations shall pay an annual license tax of $30.00 for the first $15,000.00 of gross receipts plus $0.58 on every $100.00 in excess of $15,000.00 of gross receipts. 
(d)  Those engaged in rendering a financial service include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Buying installment receivables chattel mortgage. 
Financing. 
Consumer financing. 
Credit card service. 
Factors. 
Financing accounts receivable. 
Industrial loan company. 
Installment financing. 
Inventory financing. 
Loan or mortgage brokers. 
Loan or mortgage company. 
Safety deposit box company. 
Security and commodity service. 
Stockbrokers. 
Working capital financing. 
And other financing service occupations. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-43; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. of 3-25-85; Ord. of 12-9-96(2); Ord. of 11-9-2015(2)) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 11-9-2015(2) shall be in full force and effect on Jan. 1, 2016. 
Sec. 22-78. - Repair service. 
(a)  Repair service means any person engaged in the conduct of a business, trade or occupation that repairs, renovates, cleans or services some article or item of personal property for compensation of any nature, unless the service is specifically provided for under another section of this article. 
(b)  Every person conducting, operating or engaging in any of the following businesses, trades or occupations shall pay an annual license tax of $30.00 for the first $8,334.00 in gross receipts, plus $0.36 per $100.00 in excess of $8,334.00 of gross receipts. 
(c)  Those engaged in rendering a repair service include, but are not limited to, the following: 
Air conditioning equipment repair. 
Bicycle repair. 
Boat and boat motor repair. 
Boiler repair. 
Business and office machine repair and service. 
Electrical appliance repair. 
Engine repair, any and all types. 
Farm machinery repair. 
Furnace and heating equipment repair. 
Furniture repair. 
Gun repair. 
Industrial and commercial machinery repair. 
Lawn equipment, any and all types. 
Lawnmower repair and sharpening. 
Leather goods repair, any and all types. 
Motor vehicle repair, any and all types. 
Musical instrument repair or tuning. 
Nickel and chrome plating. 
Paint and body shop for vehicles. 
Radio, television and communication equipment. 
Saw repair and sharpening. 
Scales repair. 
Shade repair. 
Shoe repair. 
Tire repair or recapping. 
Tool repair. 
Toy repair. 
Watch, clock and jewelry repair. 
Welding shop. 
And other repair services. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-45; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-79. - Junk dealers, canvassers and dealers in certain secondhand merchandise. 
(a)  Junk dealers and canvassers. 
(1)  Every person trading, purchasing, bartering or exchanging any kind of secondhand or used articles, junk, rags, bottles, metals such as steel, iron, lead, tin, aluminum, copper, etc., and/or any rubber, wood, glass, plastic, etc., except furniture, clothes, shoes and household appliances, etc., intended to be resold for use as such shall be deemed a junk dealer or junk canvasser. 
(2)  On every junk dealer trading in any kind of the articles enumerated in subsection (a)(1) shall be a license tax of $200.00. On every junk canvasser or agent canvassing the city for the purpose of buying any kind of the articles enumerated in subsection (a)(1) there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(3)  A license for junk dealers located in the city shall be a personal privilege and shall be granted only upon order of the council and shall not be prorated or transferred. On every junk canvasser, the license shall only be granted upon the approval of the chief of police. 
(b)  Dealers in certain secondhand merchandise. 
(1)  Requirement of register for dealers in certain secondhand merchandise. Every person who is a dealer in or is in the business of purchasing secondhand or used silver, silverplated, gold, goldplated or pewter flatware, holloware, tableware or other similar household items, watches and jewelry, guns and coins shall keep at his place of business a register in which he shall record with respect to each purchase of any of the foregoing items the following information: 
a.  A complete and accurate description of the goods, articles or things purchased, including the number of items; 
b.  The time and date of receiving the goods, articles or things purchased; 
c.  The amount of money paid for the goods, articles or things purchased; and 
d.  The name and complete and accurate address of the person selling the goods, articles or things purchased, which information shall be taken from a valid driver's license or special identification card issued by the state division of motor vehicles, or other reliable identification card or document, together with a particular description of such person. 
(2)  Access of law enforcement officers to register. The register required to be maintained by subsection (b)(1) shall be open to inspection by any federal, state or local law enforcement officer during business hours. 
(3)  Examination of merchandise by law enforcement officers. Every person who is a dealer in or is in the business of purchasing any of the items enumerated in subsection (b)(1) and every person in the employ of such person shall admit to his premises during business hours any federal, state or local law enforcement officer to examine any item purchased and to search for and take into possession any article known by him to be missing or known or believed by him to have been stolen. 
(4)  Purchases from minors prohibited. No person who is a dealer in or is in the business of purchasing any of the items enumerated in subsection (b)(1) shall purchase, buy or receive, directly or indirectly, any such items from any person under the age of 18 years of age. 
(5)  Penalties. Violation of any provision of subsections (b)(1) through (4) of this section shall be a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(6)  License tax required. 
a.  On every dealer of secondhand merchandise as enumerated in subsection (b)(1), located in the city, there shall be a license tax of $200.00, and the license shall be a personal privilege license and shall be granted only upon order of the council and shall not be prorated or transferred. 
b.  On every canvasser of secondhand merchandise as enumerated in subsection (b)(1), there shall be a license tax of $50.00, and such license shall only be granted upon approval of the chief of police. 
(c)  Regulatory license. The license for junk dealers, canvassers and dealers in certain secondhand merchandise is a regulatory license by authority of Code of Virginia, title 58.1. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-48; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Cross reference- Automobile graveyards, § 86-471 et seq. 
Sec. 22-80. - Pawnbrokers. 
(a)  Any person who shall in any manner lend or advance money or other things for profit on the pledge and possession of personal property or other valuable things, other than securities or written or printed evidences of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling such personal property or other valuable things back to the seller at a stipulated price shall be held to be a pawnbroker. On every pawnbroker there shall be a license tax of $150.00. 
(b)  A license under this section shall be a personal privilege and shall be granted only upon order of council and shall not be prorated or transferred. Such license is a regulatory license by authority of Code of Virginia, title 58.1. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-49; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000 et seq. 
Sec. 22-81. - Photographers outside state. 
(a)  Any person having no regular established place of business in this state upon which is a properly levied license tax, who provides photographer's service consisting of the taking of pictures or the making of pictorial reproductions in this state shall pay for this privilege the sum of $30.00 per year. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall apply to: 
(1)  Amateur photographers who expose, develop and finish their own work and who do not receive compensation for such work or receive compensation for performing any of the processes of photography; 
(2)  Coin-operated photography machines; or 
(3)  Photographers providing service in the course of their employment by newspapers, magazines or television stations. 
(c)  A license under this section is a regulatory license by authority of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3727. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-50; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. of 12-9-96(2); Ord. of 11-27-00) 
Sec. 22-82. - Alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  The terms used in this section shall have the meanings set forth in Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq., unless a different meaning shall be clearly intended. 
(b)  All persons licensed under any provision of this section shall comply in every respect with all the provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq.) and the other provisions of Code of Virginia, title 4.1, and no license shall be issued by the city commissioner of the revenue, under the provisions of this section, unless and until such applicant therefor shall hold and present to the commissioner of the revenue the proper state license as required by the provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100 et seq.) and the other provisions of Code of Virginia, title 4.1. 
(c)  If any person is holding a city license without, at the same time, holding the proper state license provided for in the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act and in the other provisions of Code of Virginia, title 4.1, such city license shall, during the period such person does not hold the proper state license, confer upon such person no rights, powers or privileges under the provisions of this section. 
(d)  The license tax for every distillery, wholesale winery, brewery, bottler, wholesale beer distributor, wholesale wine distributor, wholesale druggist, and on-premises or off-premises beer and/or wine licensee, druggist licensee, and banquet licensee when alcohol of more than 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight is distilled, brewed, distributed or sold, shall be as follows: 
(1)  On every distiller, there shall be a license tax of $1,000.00; but no license shall be required under the provisions of this subsection (d)(1) where there is manufactured not more than 5,000 gallons of alcohol or spirits, either or both, during the license year. 
(2)  On every winery, there shall be a license tax of $1,000.00. 
(3)  On every brewery, there shall be a license tax of $1,000.00. 
(4)  On every bottler, there shall be a license tax of $500.00. 
(5)  On every wholesale beer distributor, there shall be a license tax of $250.00. 
(6)  On every wholesale wine distributor, there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(7)  On every retail on-premises beer license, there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(8)  On every retail off-premises beer license, there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(9)  On every on-premises wine and beer license, there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(10)  On every retail off-premises wine and beer license, there shall be a license tax of $50.00. 
(e)  The license tax for manufacturers, wholesalers, bottlers and retailers of any beverage containing one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight shall be as follows: 
(1)  On every manufacturer, there shall be a license tax of $150.00. 
(2)  One every wholesaler of beer, there shall be a license tax of $200.00; on every wholesaler of wine there shall be a license tax of $50.00; provided, however, that every distribution house used in whole or in part by any person for distributing beverages among his retail stores must secure, in addition to the license provided for in this subsection, a wholesale merchant's license as provided for in section 22-69. 
(3)  On every bottler, there shall be a license tax of $500.00. 
(f)  Any license tax imposed by this section shall be additional to other licenses and taxes, and beverages shall be considered goods, wares and merchandise for the purpose of licenses or taxes. 
(g)  The license taxes required by this section shall not be prorated. No license issued under the provisions of this section shall be transferable from one person to another, but may be amended to show a change in the place of business. 
(h)  Any police officer shall at all times during business hours be allowed free access to every place where beverages are manufactured, bottled, distilled, brewed, stored, distributed, offered for sale, and/or sold for the purpose of examining and inspecting such premises. 
(i)  Mixed beverage license. On every establishment serving mixed beverages, there shall be the following license tax: 
Capacity or type of 
establishment License tax (per year) Up to 100 seats $200.00 101 to 150 seats $350.00 Over 150 seats $500.00 Private nonprofit club $350.00  
(j)  No license tax required under this section shall be prorated. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-51; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted December 9, 1996, amended § 22-82 to read as set out. Formerly, such section pertained to bingo. 
Sec. 22-83. - Yard sales, garage sales, etc. 
(a)  Certain sales regulated. A yard sale, garage sale, carport sale, basement sale or any sale operated out of a single-family, two-family, multifamily or business location by the person who owns or holds an annual lease for the property where the sale is to be conducted, being of two hours or more in duration, and where the items were not purchased to be resold at such sale, shall be regulated by this section. "Goods," as used in this section, means any goods, wares, merchandise or any other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated by this section. 
(b)  Permit required; display. No garage sale, yard sale, carport sale, basement sale or any such sale described in subsection (a) shall be held until the person conducting such sale shall have first obtained a sale permit in the amount of $5.00 from the office of the commissioner of the revenue. Application for more than two permits for any one person at the same address within one calendar year shall be reason for the denial of the permit by the commissioner of the revenue or his deputies. Such permit shall be conspicuously displayed upon the premises during the time of the sale so it may be inspected by any authorized representative of the city. 
(c)  Operating requirements. The following general operating requirements shall apply to all sales regulated by this section: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct more than two such sales in one calendar year at the location owned or leased by him. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct such sale for longer than three consecutive days. 
(3)  No signs advertising the sale or giving direction to its location shall be used, erected or allowed, except that one sign shall be allowed on the property of the sale location during the time of the sale. 
(4)  Any person may change the dates of such sales. The commissioner of the revenue may change the date of the sale upon request if notified the day before the first day of such sale and the change of dates shall not be legal until the license is changed by the commissioner of the revenue or his deputies. 
(d)  Penalty. All violations of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-52; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-83.1. - Charitable nonprofit organization sales. 
(a)  A yard sale, rummage sale, garage sale, bazaar, basement sale, or any sale operated by an organization, defined as a charitable nonprofit organization in Code of Virginia, § 18.2-340.1(1), being of two hours or more in duration, and where the items were not purchased to be resold at such sale, shall be regulated by this section. "Goods," as used in this section, means goods, wares, merchandise or any other property capable of being the subject of a sale regulated by this section. 
(b)  No such sale described in subsection (a) shall be held until the organization conducting such sale shall have first obtained a permit in the amount of $5.00 from the commissioner of the revenue. Application for more than four permits for any one organization in a calendar year shall be reason for the denial of the permit by the commissioner of the revenue. Such permit shall be conspicuously displayed upon the premises during the time of the sale so it may be inspected by any authorized representative of the city. 
    Each permit issued hereunder shall be of one, two or three days' duration as requested by the organization. 
(c)  No signs advertising the sale or giving directions to its location shall be used, erected, or allowed, except that one sign shall be allowed on the property of the location during the time of the sale. 
(d)  All violations of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 9-27-93(1); Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-84. - Show and sale; flea markets. 
    Any person may sponsor a show and sale or flea market in the city upon and pursuant to the following: 
(1)  A tax of $30.00 is hereby imposed on each charitable non-profit organization's antique, art or craft show and sale provided that such sale shall not continue for a period longer than 30 consecutive days. 
(2)  A tax of $30.00 is hereby imposed on such other show and sale. The payment of such tax shall permit such show and sale for a period not exceeding 30 consecutive days from the date such show and sale has begun. A license issued hereunder shall be in lieu of an itinerant vendor's or peddler's license which would be otherwise required of any seller who participates in such show and sale under the sponsorship of such person. 
(3)  The tax imposed herein shall not apply to any auction or sale if the only sales thereunder are directly by a non-profit organization. 
(4)  (a)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the owner, lessee, promoter, sponsor or proprietor of a flea market shall pay a permit fee of $30.00 for each flea market show and sale not exceeding 30 consecutive days for each such show and sale. For the purposes herein, a flea market shall be defined as follows: 
An assembly of vendors, selling new or used goods in the open air or within temporary structures, who display and sell their wares on the lands of another for a consideration. 
(b)  Such owner, lessee, promoter, sponsor or proprietor shall, in addition to the permit fee provided herein, be subject to a business license tax in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Such permit fee shall not be required of a charitable, non-profit organization that sells or displays goods at a flea market provided that the proceeds of such sale are retained by the charitable, non-profit organization and not shared with other persons, businesses or organizations. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-53; Ord. of 12-9-96(2); Ord. of 3-10-97(1); Ord. of 11-9-2015(1)) 
Sec. 22-85. - Going out of business sales; permit required, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or conduct a sale for the purpose of discontinuing a retail business, or to modify the word "sale" in any advertisement with the words "going out of business" or any other words which tend to insinuate that the retail business is to be discontinued and the merchandise liquidated, unless such person obtains a permit to conduct such sale from the commissioner of the revenue. 
(b)  The commissioner of the revenue shall issue permits to retail merchants for special sales as required by subsection (a) upon the application of such merchant, and shall inspect the advertisement and conducting of such sale to ensure that it is being advertised and conducted in conformity with the required permit. All applications for special sale permits shall be accompanied by an inventory, including the kind and quantity of all goods which are to be offered for sale during the sale, and only the goods specified in the inventory list may be advertised at a reduced price or sold at a reduced price during the sale period. Goods not included on the inventory of special sale goods shall not be commingled with or added to the special sale goods. The commissioner of the revenue shall have the right to revoke a special sale permit upon proof that goods not appearing on the original inventory of special sale goods have been commingled with or added to the special sale goods. 
(c)  Each special sale permit shall be valid for a period of no longer than 60 days, and any extension of that time shall constitute a new special sale and shall require an additional permit and inventory. An additional permit beyond the initial 60-day permit may be granted solely for the purpose of liquidating only those goods contained in the initial inventory list and which remain unsold. Any person who advertises such sale shall conspicuously include in the advertisement the permit number assigned for the sale and the effective dates of the sale as authorized in the permit. 
(d)  The fee for the issuance of each special sale permit shall be $25.00. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80; Ord. of 8-13-90; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-86. - Reserved 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted December 9, 1996, reserved § 2-86. Formerly, such section pertained to penalty for violation of article and derived from Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-54. 
Sec. 22-87. - Appeals and rulings. 
(a)  Any person assessed with a license tax as a result of an audit may apply within 90 days from the date of such assessment to the assessor for a correction of the assessment. The application must be filed in good faith and sufficiently identify the taxpayer, audit period, remedy sought, each alleged error in the assessment, the grounds upon which the taxpayer relies, and any other facts relevant to the taxpayer's contention. The assessor may hold a conference with the taxpayer if requested by the taxpayer, or require submission of additional information and documents, a further audit, or other evidence deemed necessary for a proper and equitable determination of the application. The assessment shall be deemed prima facie correct. The assessor shall undertake a full review of the taxpayer's claims and issue a determination to the taxpayer setting forth its position. Every assessment pursuant to an audit shall be accompanied by a written explanation of the taxpayer's right to seek correction and the specific procedure to be followed in the jurisdiction (e.g., the name and address to which an application should be directed). 
(b)  Provided a timely and complete application is made, collection activity shall be suspended until a final determination is issued by the assessor, unless the assessor determines that collection would be jeopardized by delay or that the taxpayer has not responded to a request for relevant information after a reasonable time. Interest shall accrue in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, but no further penalty shall be imposed while collection action is suspended. 
(c)  Any person assessed with a local license tax as a result of an audit may apply within 90 days of the determination by the assessing official on an application pursuant to this section to the tax commissioner of the state department of taxation for a correction of such assessment. The tax commissioner shall issue a determination to the taxpayer within 90 days of receipt of the taxpayer's application, unless the taxpayer and the assessing official are notified that a longer period will be required. The application shall be treated as an application pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1821 and the tax commissioner may issue an order correcting such assessment pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1822. Following such an order, either the taxpayer or the assessing official may apply to the appropriate circuit court pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3984. However, the burden shall be on the party making the application to show that the ruling of the tax commission is erroneous. Neither the tax commissioner nor the department of taxation shall be made a party to an application to correct an assessment merely because the tax commissioner has ruled on it. 
(d)  On receipt of a notice of intent to file an appeal to the tax commissioner under this section, the assessing official shall further suspend collection activity until a final determination is issued by the tax commissioner, unless the assessor determines that collection would be jeopardized by delay or that the taxpayer has not responded to a request for relevant information after a reasonable time. Interest shall accrue in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, but no further penalty shall be imposed while collection action is suspended. 
(e)  Any taxpayer may request a written ruling regarding the application of a local license tax to a specific situation from the assessor. Any person requesting such a ruling must provided all the relevant facts for the situation and may present a rationale for the basis of an interpretation of the law most favorable to the taxpayer. Any misrepresentation or change in the applicable law or the factual situation as presented in the ruling request shall invalidate any such ruling issued. A written ruling may be revoked or amended prospectively if (i) there is a change in the law, a court decision, or the guidelines issued by the department of taxation upon which the ruling was based or (ii) the assessor notifies the taxpayer of a change in the policy or interpretation upon which the ruling was based. However, any person who acts on a written ruling which later becomes invalid shall be deemed to have acted in good faith during the period in which such ruling was in effect. 
(Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Secs. 22-88-22-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC UTILITIES 

Sec. 22-111. - Water, heat, light and power companies. 
    On every person selling water, gas or electricity for light, heat or power in the city, there shall be a license tax equal to one-half of one percent of the gross receipts derived from such business in the city. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-44.1; Ord. of 12-9-96(2); Ord. of 10-9-00(1)) 
Sec. 22-112. - Telegraph companies. 
(a)  On every person engaged in the business of transmitting telegraph messages between the city and other points in the state, there shall be a license tax of $25.00. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to lay a license tax upon the business of transmitting messages for the United States government. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-44.2; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Sec. 22-113. - Telephone companies. 
    On every person engaged in the business of transmitting telephone messages between points within the city there shall be a license tax equal to one-half of one percent of the local exchange gross receipts derived from such business in the city. 
(Ord. of 11-24-80, § 14-44.3; Ord. of 12-9-96(2)) 
Secs. 22-114-22-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MASSAGE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-13-2017(2), adopted Nov. 13, 2017, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 22-136-22-141, 22-166-22-173, and enacted §§ 22-136, 22-137 and similar provisions in ch. 58. The former Art. III pertained to massage and massage parlor permit and derived from Code 1969, §§ 14A-1-14A-14; Ord. of 7-10-95(1); Ord. of 12-9-96(2) 

Sec. 22-136. - Massage parlor. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed upon every person doing business in this city or holding himself out as doing business in this city as a massage parlor as such term is defined in section 58-200 of this Code, a license tax of $5,000.00 per year which shall be due and payable as provided in this chapter. Such license shall not be proratable or transferable. 
(b)  The commissioner of the revenue shall not issue the license required by this section until presented with a valid nonsuspended massage parlor permit issued pursuant to section 58-206 et seq. of this Code and a massage technician permit issued pursuant to sections 58-202 of this Code for each massage technician employed by a massage parlor. 
(c)  If any person shall commence to do business in this city as a massage parlor or hold himself out as doing business in this city through any advertising medium as a massage parlor without first obtaining the license required by this section, such person shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day's operation without a license shall constitute a separate offense. Any conviction under this section shall not relieve any person convicted of doing business without a license from payment of the license tax prescribed by this section. 
(d)  If any person shall be in violation of this section for one month or longer, such person shall moreover be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the license tax which was due and payable at the beginning of the tax year, in addition to the license tax imposed by this section, and such penalty shall be assessed and paid along with the license tax and shall become a part of the license tax and shall be enforced in the manner provided by law for the enforcement of the collection of other taxes. 
(e)  In addition to the class 1 misdemeanor and the penalty, any violation of this section may be enjoined through appropriate legal proceedings. 
(Ord. of 11-13-2017(2)) 
Sec. 22-137. - Powers and duties of the commissioner as to massage parlors. 
    It shall be the duty of the commissioner of the revenue to ascertain the name of every person operating a massage parlor in the city, liable for collection of the tax levied in section 22-136, who fails, refuses or neglects to make timely payments of the required tax. The commissioner, or designee, may have a summons issued for such person and may serve a copy of such summons upon such person in the manner provided by law and shall make one return of the original to the general district court of the city. Police powers are hereby conferred upon the commissioner, or designee, while engaged in performing their duties under section 22-136 and this section, and they shall exercise all the powers and authority of policy officers in performing such duties. 
(Ord. of 11-13-2017(2)) 
Secs. 22-138-22-173. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - PRECINCTS; VOTING PLACES 

Sec. 26-36. - Division of city into election precincts. 
    The election precincts of the city shall be constituted as set out in this article. 
(Code 1969, § 7-1) 
State Law reference- Councils of cities to establish districts or precincts, Code of Virginia, § 24.2-307. 
Sec. 26-37. - Procedure when voting place is not available. 
    Should for any reason one or more of the voting places indicated in this article be unavailable, then a suitable voting place or places shall be fixed by the judges of election of the respective precincts affected. 
(Code 1969, § 7-2) 
Sec. 26-38. - Precinct A or Conehurst Precinct. 
(a)  Boundaries. Precinct A or Conehurst Precinct shall embrace all of the territory within the corporate limits of the city situate as follows:

Chapter 30 - ENVIRONMENT[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Noise prohibitions generally. 
(a)  (1) It shall be a Class 2 misdemeanor and a public nuisance for any person to willfully make, permit, continue, or cause to be made, permitted or continued any noise disturbance. For the purposes of this article, a "noise disturbance" means any sound which by its character, intensity and/or duration (i) endangers or injures the health or safety of persons within the city; or (ii) annoys or disturbs reasonable persons of normal sensitivities within the city. 
(2)  Any of the following acts, or the causing or permitting thereof, among others, is declared to be a noise disturbance constituting a Class 2 misdemeanor and a public nuisance, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(i)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, whistling or singing between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. so as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary or on a public right-of-way or public property. 
(ii)  Schools, public buildings, churches, and hospitals. The creation of any noise disturbance within any school, court, public building, church, or on the grounds thereof. 
(b)  The use, operation, or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which such sound is located or originates, without first obtaining a permit as provided by section 30-2, shall be unlawful. 
(c)  Section 30-1 shall have no application to any sound generated by any of the following: 
(1)  Any horn, siren, bell, whistle, or similar device used in accordance with the law to signal a warning to the citizens of the city; the approach of any train at a railcrossing; or the approach of any police vehicle, fire truck, rescue vehicle, or any similar emergency vehicle responding to an emergency situation or used to summon the members of any fire or rescue squad. 
(2)  Any mechanical or electronic horns, sirens, bells or similar devices that may be sounded as part of a burglary or fire alarm system installed for the protection of persons or property, provided that such device is deactivated by the property owner, lessee, or authorized agent within 60 minutes of its initial sounding. 
(3)  Sound which is necessary for the protection or preservation of property or the health, safety, life, or limb of any person. 
(4)  Noncommercial public speaking and public assembly activities conducted on any public right-of-way or public property for which a permit has been issued by the city. 
(5)  Parades, fireworks, school-related activities and other special events or activities for which a permit has been issued by the city, within such hours as may be imposed as a condition for the issuance of the permit. 
(6)  Activities on or in municipal and school athletic facilities and on or in publicly owned property and facilities, provided that such activity has been authorized by the owner of such property or facilities or its agent. 
(7)  Religious services, religious events or religious activities, including, but not limited to music, bells, chimes, and organs which are a part of such service, event or activity. 
(Code 1969, § 17-25; Ord. of 9-22-97) 
Cross reference- Noise made by animal or fowl, § 14-2; railroad whistle or horn, § 86-451; bell to be rung upon approach of locomotive to street crossing, § 86-452. 
Sec. 30-2. - Loudspeakers, etc.-Permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or control, or cause to be used, operated or controlled, any loudspeaker or other mechanical device, apparatus, machine or instrument of any nature or kind whatsoever whereby the human voice or music is intensified or amplified, unless he shall first have obtained a permit for such use, operation or control from the chief of police. Any person desiring such a permit shall file an application therefor with the chief of police. 
(b)  Upon the filing of an application for permit under subsection (a), and the completion of any investigation he may deem requisite, the chief of police shall, if it appears to him that section 30-1 will not be violated, issue the permit in question, subject to such terms and conditions as he may impose. 
(Code 1969, § 17-26) 
Sec. 30-3. - Same-Manner of use, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or control, or to cause to be used, operated or controlled, any loudspeaker or other mechanical device, apparatus, machine or instrument of any nature or kind whatsoever whereby the human voice or music is intensified or amplified in such manner as to produce, make, create or give rise to any sound or noise, in any public or private place, of such a character and kind as to disturb any citizen of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or property rights or to cause any person of ordinary sensibilities any actual physical discomfort. 
(Code 1969, § 17-27) 
Sec. 30-4. - Removal of trash, garbage, etc. 
    All persons shall keep their premises, whether owned, leased, occupied, or in their charge, clear of trash, garbage, refuse, litter and other substances which might endanger the health or safety of the other residents of the city and, if after written notice from the city manager or the building official, the trash, garbage, refuse, litter, and other substances which might endanger the health or safety of the other residents of the city are not cleared away within a period of 15 days from the giving of such notice, then the person in question shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. After the expiration of such 15 days, the city manager or the building official may cause such trash, garbage, refuse, litter and other substances which might endanger the health or safety of the other residents of the city removed where necessary, and the cost thereof shall thereupon be chargeable to and be collected from the owner of the premises in question, or the person leasing, occupying or having such premises in his charge, as other taxes or levies are or may be collected. 
(Code 1969, § 24-29; Ord. of 3-10-97(2)) 
Charter reference- Power to abate or remove nuisances (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-867) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-11. 
Sec. 30-5. - Allowing noxious, etc., matter or nuisance to be placed, etc., in or upon house, lot, etc. 
    No person shall permit any noxious, unwholesome or offensive matter or nuisance of any kind, either to health or comfort, to be placed or to remain in any house, cellar, lot or other property belonging to him, or in his possession, control or occupancy; provided, however, this section shall not be construed to prevent the storing of fertilizers within the city in warehouses or other buildings removed from the street and where the odor of such fertilizers cannot reach the street. 
(Code 1969, § 13-3) 
Cross reference- Keeping certain fowl as nuisance, § 14-37; keeping certain dogs and cats as nuisance, § 14-101. 
Sec. 30-6. - Placing nuisance on property of another. 
    No person shall place a nuisance on the property of another person. 
(Code 1969, § 13-4) 
Sec. 30-7. - Allowing stagnant water to remain in house or cellar or upon lot or property. 
    No person shall permit any stagnant water to remain in any house, cellar or upon any lot or other property belonging to him or in his possession, control or occupancy. 
(Code 1969, § 13-5) 
Charter reference- Power to compel the raising or draining of grounds subject to be covered by stagnant water (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-867) adopted, § 2.2. 
Sec. 30-8. - Correction of situations injurious to health and abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  When, in the opinion of the health director, anything shall be found which is, or is likely to be, injurious to the health of the neighborhood or any person or family, the health director shall notify the city manager thereof. The city manager shall, thereupon, require the owner or occupant of the premises in question or the person causing the nuisance to correct the injurious situation or abate the nuisance within 24 hours in such a manner as the city manager may deem expedient. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the recipient of an order from the city manager requiring the correction of any injurious situation or abatement of a nuisance, as provided for in subsection (a), to fail, neglect or refuse to correct the injurious situation or abate the nuisance within 24 hours in the manner deemed expedient by the city manager. In case of such failure, neglect or refusal, the city manager may have the injurious situation corrected or nuisance abated and recover the costs thereof from the person responsible for the failure, neglect or refusal. 
(Code 1969, § 13-7) 
Secs. 30-9-30-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIR POLLUTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Local air pollution ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1321. 

Sec. 30-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Actual heat input means the sum of the actual heat input of all combustion installations which are operating during any specified period at a facility. 
    Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more substances which are or may be harmful or injurious to human health, welfare or safety, to animal or plant life, or to property, or which unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment by the people of life or property. 
    Air pollution episode means a situation which is declared by responsible authorities when weather and/or pollution conditions indicate a potential threat to human health. 
    Air quality means the specific measurement in the ambient air of a particular air contaminant at any given time. 
    Ambient air means that portion of the atmosphere external to buildings, to which the general public has access. 
    Ambient air quality standard-primary means air quality which, allowing an adequate margin of safety, is requisite to protect the public health. 
    Ambient air quality standard-secondary means air quality which is requisite to protect the public welfare from any known or anticipated adverse effects associated with the presence of air contaminants in the ambient air. 
    Best available control technology means any emission control device or technique which is capable of limiting emissions to the levels proposed or promulgated pursuant to 40 CFR 60. Where no standard of performance has been proposed or promulgated for a source or portion thereof under 40 CFR 60, best available control technology shall be determined on a case-by-case basis considering the following: 
(1)  The process, fuels and raw material available and to be employed in the facility involved; 
(2)  The engineering aspects of the application of various types of control techniques which have been adequately demonstrated; 
(3)  Process and fuel changes; 
(4)  The respective costs of the application of all such control techniques, process changes, alternative fuels, etc.; 
(5)  Any applicable emission standards; and 
(6)  Locational and siting considerations. 
    Capital expenditure means an expenditure for a physical or operational change to a facility which exceeds the product of the applicable annual asset guideline repair allowance percentage specified in the latest of Internal Revenue Service Publication 534 and the affected facility's basis, as defined by section 1012 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
    Combustion installation means a source consisting of any furnace, oven kiln incinerator, fuel-burning equipment, or any other stationary equipment in which solid, liquid or gaseous materials are burned. 
    Commence means to undertake or to enter into a contractual obligation to undertake and complete, within a reasonable time, a continuous program of onsite construction or modification including site clearance, grading, dredging, or land filling specifically designed for a source in preparation for construction or modification of the source. For the purpose of this definition, interruptions resulting from acts of God, strikes, litigation, or other matters beyond the control of the owner shall be disregarded in determining whether a construction or modification program is continuous. 
    Construction means fabrication, erection or installation of a source, and includes the term "reconstruction." 
    Contaminant means smoke, dust, soot, grime, carbon, or any other particulate matter, radioactive matter, noxious gas, acids, fumes, gases, odor, vapor, or any combination thereof. 
    Control equipment means any equipment which has the function of controlling the emissions from a process, fuel-burning, or refuse-burning equipment and thus reduces the creation or the emission of air contaminants into the atmosphere, or both. 
    County air pollution control officer means the medical director. 
    Dust means solid particles projected into the air by natural forces, such as wind, volcanic eruption or earthquake and by mechanical or manmade processes such as crushing, grinding, milling, drilling, demolition, shoveling, conveying, screening, bagging and sweeping. 
    Emergency means a situation that immediately and unreasonably affects public health, safety or welfare, the health of animal or plant life, or property, whether used for recreational, commercial, industrial, agricultural or other reasonable use. 
    Emission standard means any provision of this article prescribing an emission limitation or level or opacity, prescribing equipment or fuel specifications, or other requirements that result in control of air contaminants. 
    Existing source means any stationary source other than a new source or modified source. 
    Fixed capital cost means the capital needed to provide all the depreciable components. 
    Fuel-burning equipment means a source consisting of any furnace, and all appurtenances thereto, used in the process of burning fuel for the primary purpose of producing heat or power by indirect heat transfer. 
    Fugitive dust means solid airborne particulate matter or dust emitted from any source other than a flue, stack, duct or chimney. 
    Fumes means minute particulate matter generated by the condensation of vapors from solid matter after volatilization from the molten state, or generated by sublimation, distillation, calcination or chemical reaction when their processes create airborne particles. 
    Gases means formless fluids which, under standard conditions, occupy the space of enclosure and which can be changed to the liquid or solid state only by the combined effect of increased pressure and decreased temperature. 
    Heat input means the total gross heating value of all fuels burned. 
    Heating value means the heat released by combustion of one pound of fuel or other material measured in British thermal units (Btu) on an as-received basis. 
    Incinerator means any source consisting of a furnace and all appurtenances thereto designed for the destruction of refuse by burning. "Open burning" is not considered incineration. For purposes of this definition, the destruction of any combustible liquid or gaseous material by burning in a flare or flare stack shall be considered incineration. 
    Malfunction means any sudden failure of air pollution control equipment or process equipment or of a process to operate in a normal or usual manner. 
    Medical director means the director of the county department of health or his duly authorized agent. 
    Mobile sources means any vehicle, including, but not limited to, any motor vehicle, truck, or other land craft, aircraft, locomotive, bus or ship, rail vehicle, or watercraft, which emits or may emit any air contaminant. 
    Modification means any physical change in, or changes in the method of operation of, a facility which increases the amount of any air contaminant emitted into the atmosphere by that facility or which results in the emission of any air contaminant into the atmosphere not previously emitted, except that the following shall not, by themselves, be considered modifications under this definition: 
(1)  Maintenance, repair and replacement which the state air pollution control officer determines to be routine for a source type. 
(2)  An increase in production rate of a facility, if that increase can be accomplished without a major capital expenditure on the stationary source containing that facility. 
(3)  An increase in the hours of operation. 
(4)  Use of an alternative fuel or raw material if, prior to the date any provision of this article becomes applicable to that source type, the facility was designed to accommodate that alternative use. A facility shall be considered to be designed to accommodate an alternative fuel or raw material if provisions for that use were included in the final construction specifications. 
(5)  The addition or use of any system or device whose primary function is the reduction of air contaminants, except when an emission control system which the state air pollution control officer considers to be less efficient. 
(6)  The change in ownership of a facility. 
    Modified source means any stationary source, the modification of which is commenced on or after the effective date of applicable provisions of this article. 
    Motor vehicles means any powered conveyance normally licensed by the state department of motor vehicles. 
    New source means any stationary source, the construction or reconstruction of which is commenced on or after the effective date of applicable provisions of this article; any source relocated on or after the effective date of applicable provisions of this article. 
    Nuisance means environmental conditions, intermittent or continuous, produced or correctable by human agency, prejudicial to reasonable enjoyment of health, comfort or safety by an individual or causing injury or damage to persons, property or the conduct of business. 
    Odor means the sensation resulting from stimulation of the human sense of smell. 
    Opacity means the degree to which emissions reduce the transmission of light and obscure the view of an object in the background, expressed as a percentage. 
    Open burning means the burning of any matter in such a manner that the products of combustion resulting from the burning are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through an adequate flue, stack, duct or chimney. 
    Open fire means a fire in which any material is burned in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, incinerator, or other equipment connected to a stack. 
    Owner means any person, including bodies politic and corporate, associations, partnerships, personal representatives, trustees and committees, as well as individuals, who owns, leases, operates, controls or supervises a source. 
    Particulate means any finely divided solid or liquid material, other than uncombined water, as measured by the applicable test or sampling method. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, a governmental body, a municipal corporation, or any other legal entity. 
    Process unit means any action, operation or treatment, and the equivalent used in connection therewith, and all methods or forms of manufacturing or processing that may emit smoke, particulate matter or gases. 
    Process weight means total weight of all materials introduced into any source process unit which may cause any emissions of contaminants. Process weight includes solid fuels charged, but does not include liquid and gaseous fuels charged or combustion air for all fuels. 
    Process weight rate means rate established as follows: 
(1)  For continuous or long-run steady-state source operations, for total process weight for the entire period of continuous operation or for a typical portion thereof, divided by the number of hours of such period or portion thereof; 
(2)  For cyclical or batch unit operations, or unit processes, the total weight for a period that covers a complete operation or an integral number of cycles, divided by the hours of actual process operation during such a period. 
    Production rate means the weight of final product obtained per hour of operation. If the rate of product going to storage can vary, the production rate shall be determined by calculation from the feed rates of raw material. 
    Rated capacity means the capacity as stipulated in the purchase contract for the condition of 100 percent load, or such other capacities as mutually agreed to by the state air pollution control officer and owner. 
    Reconstruction means the replacement of components or a facility to such an extent that: 
(1)  The fixed capital cost of the new components exceeds 50 percent of the fixed capital cost that would be required to construct a comparable entirely new facility; and 
(2)  It is technologically and economically feasible to meet the applicable emission standards prescribed under this article. 
    Reference method means any method of sampling and analyzing for an air pollutant as described in appendix A of 40 CFR 60. 
    Salvage operations means any source consisting of any business, trade or industry engaged in whole or in part in salvaging or reclaiming any product or material, such as, but not limited to, reprocessing of used motor oils, metals, chemicals, shipping containers or drums, and specifically including automobile graveyards and junkyards as defined in Code of Virginia, § 33.1-348. 
    Shutdown means the cessation of operation of a source for any purpose. 
    Smoke means small gas-borne particulate matter consisting predominantly but not exclusively of carbon, ash and other material in concentrations sufficient to form a visible plume. 
    Source means any and all points of origin of emission of air contaminants, whether privately or publicly owned or operated or a person contributing to emission of air contaminants. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, this term includes all types of business, commercial and industrial plants, works, shops and stores, and heating and power plants or stations, buildings, and other structures of all types. 
    Stack or chimney means any flue, conduit or duct arranged to conduct emissions into the atmosphere. 
    Standard conditions means dry gas temperature of 68 degrees Fahrenheit and gas pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. 
    Startup means the setting in operation of a source for any source. 
    Stationary source means any building, structure, facility or installation which emits or may emit any air contaminant. 
    Total capacity means the sum of the rated capacities of all fuel-burning equipment which must be operated simultaneously under conditions of maximum load at a facility, expressed as heat input. 
    Unless specifically defined in this section, the technical terms used in this article have the meanings commonly ascribed to them by recognized authorities. 
(Code 1969, § 2A-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-42. - Smoke or other visible emissions, stationary sources. 
(a)  Prohibition of visible emissions. No owner shall cause, suffer, allow or permit the discharge into the outdoor atmosphere, from any source, of visible emissions of greater than 20 percent opacity. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  When starting a new fire or flowing tubes or cleaning a firebox, a person may discharge into the atmosphere from any source emissions not greater than 60 percent opacity for brief periods not to exceed six minutes in any 60-minute period. 
(2)  The limits of subsection (a) shall not apply when the opacity of the visible emissions is due to the presence of uncombined water. 
(3)  The limits of subsection (a) shall not apply during periods of startup, shutdown and malfunction. 
(c)  Traffic hazard. No person shall discharge from any source whatsoever such quantities of air contaminants, uncombined water, or other materials which may cause a traffic hazard. 
(Code 1969, § 2A-3) 
Sec. 30-43. - Particulate emissions from existing fuel-burning equipment. 
(a)  Emissions prohibited for fuel-burning equipment. 
(1)  No owner or other person shall allow to be emitted into the atmosphere from any fuel-burning equipment, or to pass a convenient measuring point near the stack outlet, particulate matter in the flue gases to exceed the appropriate following standard: 
a.  For facilities with total capacity less than 25,000,000 Btu's per hour, the maximum allowable emission ratio shall be 0.4 pound of particulate per million Btu input. 
b.  For facilities with total capacity between 25,000,000 and 10,000,000,000 Btu's per hour, the maximum allowable emission ratio, E, in pounds of particulate per million Btu input, shall be determined by the total capacity in millions of Btu's per hour. 
c.  For facilities with total capacity in excess of 10,000,000,000 Btu's per hour, the maximum allowable emission shall be 0.1 pound of particulates per million Btu input. 
d.  Figure 1 illustrates the above emission standard. 
(2)  The maximum allowable particulate emissions for a facility shall be the product of the total capacity and the emission ratio. The emission contribution of each unit shall be determined using procedures acceptable to the state air pollution control officer. 
(b)  Emission testing. For the purpose of emission testing, the particulate emission for each of the indirect heating furnace units of the facility shall be its contribution to the total allowable emission from the facility when operating at total capacity. When it is not possible to satisfactorily perform emission tests at the rated capacity of an individual indirect heating furnace unit or jointly on all units in operation, the measurements taken at actual operating load shall be related to the allowable emission at rated capacity for the unit(s) being tested, adjusted for any changes in emission control equipment efficiency due to variations in load from rated capacity. 
(c)  Exemptions. 
(1)  All fuel-burning equipment using solid fuel with a maximum heat input of less than 350,000 Btu's per hour shall be exempt from this section. 
(2)  All fuel-burning equipment using gas or oil with a maximum heat input of less than 1,000,000 Btu's per hour shall be exempt from this section. 
(Code 1969, § 2A-4)

Sec. 30-44. - Particulate matter (other than from fuel-burning equipment and incinerators). 
(a)  Emission of particulate matter prohibited. 
(1)  Unless covered by a specific emission standard in section 4.40(b) of the Commonwealth of Virginia Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution (August 9, 1975) as amended, the maximum allowable emission of particulate matter from any source shall be determined from Figure 2. 
(2)  Interpolation of the data in Figure 2 for process weight rates up to 60,000 pounds per hour shall be accomplished by use of the equation E = 4.10 P0.67 , and interpolation and extrapolation of the data for process weight rates in excess of 60,000 pounds per hour shall be accomplished by use of the equation # = 55.0 P0.11-40 , where E equals emission rate in pounds per hour and P equals process weight rate in tons per hour. 
(3)  Where the nature of any process or operation or the design of any equipment is such as to permit more than one interpretation of this section, the interpretation that results in the maximum value for allowable emission shall apply. 
(4)  For purposes of this section, the total process weight rate for each individual process unit at a plant or premises shall be used for determining the maximum allowable emission rate of particulate matter that passes through a stack or stacks. 
(5)  This section does not apply to fuel-burning equipment and incinerators. 
(b)  No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit any materials to be handled, transported or stored, or a building, its appurtenances, or a road to be used, constructed, altered, repaired or demolished, without taking reasonable precautions to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne or to create a nuisance. Such reasonable precautions may include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Use of water or chemicals for control of dust in the demolition of existing buildings or structures, construction operations, the grading of roads or the clearing of land. 
(2)  Application of asphalt, oil, water or suitable chemicals on dirt roads, materials stockpiles, and other surfaces which can create airborne dusts. 
(3)  Installation and use of hoods, fans and fabric filters to enclose and vent the handling of dusty materials. Adequate containment methods shall be employed during sandblasting or similar operations. The use of sandblasting for cleaning building exteriors in residential or commercial areas is prohibited. 
(4)  Open equipment for conveying or transporting materials likely to become airborne shall be covered or treated in an equally effective manner at all times when in motion. 
(5)  The paving of roadways and their maintenance in a clean condition. 
(6)  The prompt removal of earth or other material from paved streets over which such earth or other material has been transported by trucking or earth-moving equipment or erosion by water. 
(Code 1969, § 2A-5)
