307.1 General. Delete and substitute section 307.1 as follows: 
A person shall not kindle or maintain or authorize to be kindled or maintain a bonfire or recreational fire or the use of portable outdoor fireplace unless conducted in accordance with Sections 307.1.1 through 307.5. 
307.1.1 Prohibited open burning. Delete and substitute Section 307.1.1 as follows: 
All open burning within the limits of the city shall be prohibited. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Open burning for training and instruction of government and public fire fighters under the supervision of the designated official. 
2.  Open burning for the destruction of any combustible liquid or gaseous material by burning in a flare or flare stack. 
3.  Open burning for the disposal of hazardous or toxic materials where the fire code official and the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality determine that there is no practical alternative method of disposal. 
4.  Open burning for the disposal of debris or to remedy an emergency resulting from a disaster situation and when operating under an emergency declaration of the federal, state, or local government. 
307.3 Extinguishment authority. Delete and substitute section 307.3 as follows: 
When a bonfire, recreational fire or the use of a portable outdoor fireplace creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable situation, or a required permit for a bonfire has not been obtained, the fire code official is authorized to order the extinguishment of any burning operation. 
307.4 Location. Delete and substitute section 307.4 as follows: 
The location for a bonfire shall not be less than 50 feet from any structure or combustible material. The location for a recreational fire shall not be less than 25 feet from any structure or combustible material. Provisions shall be made to prevent the fire from spreading to a structure prior to ignition. 
307.4.1.1 Bonfire size and duration; materials. Add Subsection 307.4.1.1 as follows: 
1.  A bonfire shall not exceed 5'x5' in size and shall not burn longer than three (3) hours. 
2.  Fuel for a bonfire shall consist only of seasoned dry firewood and shall be ignited with a small quantity of paper. The fire shall not be utilized for waste disposal purposes, and the fuel shall be chosen to minimize the generation of smoke and air contaminants. 
307.4.2.1 Recreational Fire size; materials. Add Subsection 307.4.2.1 as follows: 
1.  A recreational fire shall not exceed 3'x3' in size and two (2) feet in height. 
2.  Fuel for a recreational fire shall consist only of seasoned dry firewood and shall be ignited with a small quantity of paper. The fire shall not be utilized for waste disposal purposes, and the fuel shall be chosen to minimize the generation of smoke and air contaminants. 
307.4.3 Portable outdoor fireplaces. Delete exception. 
307.5 Attendance. Delete and substitute Section 307.5 as follows: 
Bonfires, recreational fires and the use of portable outdoor fireplaces shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. A minimum of one portable fire extinguisher complying with Section 906 with a minimum 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire-extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose or water truck, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(Ord. of 2-25-08; Ord. of 1-9-2017) 
Secs. 34-64-34-80. - Reserved. 
Chapter 38 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to regulate health, safety and general welfare (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-839) and to regulate beverages, foods and sanitation of food establishments (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-853) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14; environment, ch. 30; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 54; signs, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; vegetation, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Certain local regulations pertaining to food and beverage containers prohibited, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1425; power to prevent injury or annoyance from anything dangerous, offensive or unhealthy, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-14(5); state funds for drug enforcement, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-131.12; local ordinances regulating smoking, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-291.4; regulation of well covers, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-318; inspection warrant for inspecting or testing for toxic substances, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-393 et seq.; sanitation in transportation terminals, festivals, fairs, service stations, etc., Code of Virginia, § 32.1-202. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Power to regulate milk, food and food products (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-853) adopted, § 2.2. 
State Law reference- Sanitary requirements for food and food establishments, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-365 et seq.; restaurants, Code of Virginia, § 35.1-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-36. - Display of foods for human consumption upon sidewalks, etc. 
    No foods for human consumption, including meats and fish, shall be displayed upon the sidewalks of the city or in any doors opening on sidewalks, unless such foods shall be displayed on adequately elevated and removable racks or platforms and otherwise properly protected. 
(Code 1969, § 11-1) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
Secs. 38-37-38-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Restaurant license, § 22-67; tax on prepared food and beverages, § 82-101 et seq. 
State Law reference- Sanitary requirements for food and food establishments, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-365 et seq.; restaurants, Code of Virginia, § 35.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 38-56. - Protection from contamination of foodstuffs displayed or stored. 
    No establishment where foods are manufactured, prepared, packed, handled, stored, offered for sale, sold, consumed or distributed, including hotels, restaurants and other public eating houses, bakeries, ice cream parlors or manufacturers of ice cream, groceries, markets, retail or wholesale stores, or manufacturers of any of the aforementioned articles, shall display or store any foodstuff in the city unless such foodstuff so displayed or stored shall be properly protected from flies, dogs, insects, animals or from any other sources of contamination. 
(Code 1969, § 11-2) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 38-57. - Sanitary condition required. 
    The proprietor of any food establishment, as referred to in section 38-56, shall keep such food establishment in a clean, wholesome and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1969, § 11-3) 
Sec. 38-58. - Cleanliness of employees. 
    Employees in any food establishment, as referred to in section 38-56, shall, when engaged in the preparation, handling or disposition of foods, be clean in their person and wear clean garments. 
(Code 1969, § 11-4) 
Sec. 38-59. - Toilets and washing facilities for employees. 
    The proprietor of any food establishment, as referred to in section 38-56, shall provide adequate toilet and washing facilities for his employees of a type approved by appropriate authority. 
(Code 1969, § 11-5) 
Secs. 38-60-38-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FOOD HANDLER'S CERTIFICATE OF HEALTH 

Sec. 38-76. - Prerequisite to working in eating or drinking establishment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to work in an eating or drinking establishment in the city where food or drinks are offered for sale and consumption on the premises, except where the services performed are in a supervisory or clerical capacity and where such work does not bring one in contact with food or drinks or their containers, unless such person holds a food handler's certificate of health, issued by the health director, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1969, § 11-6) 
Sec. 38-77. - Chest X-ray and blood serology test; issuance. 
    A certificate of health shall be issued only after a chest X-ray and blood serology test of the applicant for the certificate of health, as required in section 38-76, has been made by a qualified physician, and a report thereof transmitted to the health director, who shall then determine whether or not the certificate of health shall be issued. 
(Code 1969, § 11-7) 
Sec. 38-78. - Revocation or suspension. 
    Food handlers' certificates of health issued under this division may at any time be revoked or suspended by the health director for just cause. 
(Code 1969, § 11-8) 
Sec. 38-79. - Transfer. 
    Food handlers' certificates of health issued under this division shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1969, § 11-9) 
Sec. 38-80. - Renewal. 
    Food handlers' certificates of health issued under this division shall be renewed annually, with the same requirements as for the original issuance. 
(Code 1969, § 11-10) 
Sec. 38-81. - Employment of person without certificate of health. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, manager or person in control of any eating or drinking establishment in the city where food or drinks are offered for sale or consumption on the premises to employ or permit any person to work in any such eating or drinking establishment, except in a supervisory or clerical capacity doing work not bringing such person in contact with food or drinks, unless there has been issued to, and such person has in his possession, a food handler's certificate of health as required by section 38-76. 
(Code 1969, § 11-11) 
Sec. 38-82. - Periodic check of establishments. 
    The health director shall be responsible for making a periodic check of the eating and drinking establishments to see that the employees thereof conform to the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1969, § 11-12) 
Chapter 42 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Virginia Fair Housing Law, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the fair housing board. 
    Elderliness means an individual who has attained his 55th birthday. 
    Familial status means one or more individuals who have not attained the age of 18 years being domiciled with (i) a parent or other person having legal custody of such individual or individuals, or (ii) the designee of such parent or other person having custody with the written permission of such parent or other person. The term "familial status" also includes any person who is pregnant or is in the process of securing legal custody of any individual who has not attained the age of 18 years. For purposes of this section, "in the process of securing legal custody" means having filed an appropriate petition to obtain legal custody of such minor in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
    Housing means any building, structure or facility, or portion thereof, located in the city that is used or occupied, or is intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied, as the home, residence or sleeping place of one or more individuals, groups or families, and any vacant land located in the city offered for sale or lease for the purpose of constructing or locating such building, structure or facility, including any interest in housing as so defined, fee simple, leasehold or other. 
    Lending institution means any bank, insurance company, savings and loan association, credit union, mortgage lender or any other person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans. 
    Person in the business of building, developing, selling, renting or leasing housing means any person who, within the preceding 12 months, has participated as principal or real estate broker, real estate salesman or rental agent in three or more transactions involving the sale, lease or rental of any housing. 
    Personal residence means a building or structure containing living quarters and occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four individuals, four groups or four families living independently of each other and used by the owner thereof as a bona fide residence for himself and any member of his family forming his household. 
    Real estate broker means a person doing business in the city who is the holder of a real estate broker's license issued pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-2100 et seq. 
    Real estate salesperson means a person doing business in the city who is the holder of a real estate salesperson's license issued pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-2100 et seq. 
(Code 1969, §§ 13A-1, 13A-4) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-37. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 42-38(a)(3), this article shall not apply to any single-family house sold or rented by an owner, provided that such private individual does not own more than three single-family houses at any one time. In the case of the sale of any single-family house by a private individual owner not residing in the house at the time of the sale or who was not the most recent resident of the house prior to sale, the exemption granted shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any 24-month period; provided that such bona fide private individual owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three such single-family houses at any one time. The sale or rental of any such single-family house shall be exempt from the application of this article only if the house is sold or rented (i) without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent, salesperson, or of the facilities or the services of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings, or of any employee, independent contractor, or agent of any broker, agent, salesperson, or person; and (ii) without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice, of any advertisement or written notice in violation of this article. However, nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies, and other professional assistance as is necessary to perfect or transfer the title. This exemption shall not apply to or inure to the benefit of any licensee of the real estate board, regardless of whether the licensee is acting in his personal or professional capacity. 
(b)  Except for section 42-38(a)(3), this article shall not apply to rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as his residence. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preferences to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status, or handicap. Nor shall anything in this article apply to a private membership club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. Nor, where matters of personal privacy are involved, shall anything in this article be construed to prohibit any private, state-owned or state-supported educational institution, hospital, nursing home, religious or correctional institution from requiring that persons of both sexes not occupy any single-family residence or room or unit of dwellings or other buildings, or restrooms in such room or unit in dwellings or other buildings, which it owns or operates. 
(d)  Nothing in this article prohibits conduct against a person because such person has been convicted by any court of competent jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance as defined in federal law. 
(e)  It shall not be unlawful under this article for any owner to deny or limit the rental of housing to persons who pose a clear and present threat of substantial harm to others or to the dwelling itself. 
(f)  A rental application may require disclosure by the applicant of any criminal convictions, and the owner or managing agent may require as a condition of acceptance of the rental application that the applicant consent in writing to a criminal record check to verify the disclosures made by the applicant in the rental application. The owner or managing agent may collect from the applicant monies to reimburse the owner or managing agent for the exact amount of the out-of-pocket costs for such criminal record checks. Nothing in this article shall require an owner or managing agent to rent a dwelling to an individual who, based on a prior record of criminal convictions involving harm to persons or property, would constitute a clear and present threat to the health or safety of other individuals. 
(g)  Nothing in this article limits the applicability of any reasonable local, state or federal restriction regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling. Owners or managing agents of dwellings may develop and implement reasonable occupancy and safety standards based on factors such as the number and size of sleeping areas or bedrooms and overall size of a dwelling unit, so long as the standards do not violate local, state or federal restrictions. Nothing in this article prohibits the rental application or similar document from requiring information concerning the number, ages, sex and familial relationship of the applicants and the dwelling's intended occupants. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-2(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.2. 
Sec. 42-38. - Unlawful discriminatory housing practices. 
(a)  It shall be an unlawful discriminatory housing practice for any person to: 
(1)  Refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, or familial status. 
(2)  Discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in the connection therewith to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness or familial status. 
(3)  Make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published, any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination or an intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap. The use of words or symbols associated with a particular religion, national origin, sex or race shall be prima facie evidence of an illegal preference under this article, which shall not be overcome by a general disclaimer. 
(4)  Represent to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  Deny any person access to membership in or participation in any multiple listing service, real estate brokers' organization, or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against such person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap. 
(6)  Include in any transfer, sale, rental or lease of housing any restrictive covenant that discriminates because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap, or for any person to honor or exercise, or attempt to honor or exercise, any such discriminatory covenant pertaining to housing. 
(7)  Induce or attempt to induce to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of persons of a particular race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap. 
(8)  Refuse to sell or rent, or refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise discriminate or make unavailable or deny, a dwelling because of a handicap of: 
a.  The buyer or renter; 
b.  A person residing in or intending to reside in that dwelling after it is so sold, rented or made available; or 
c.  Any person associated with the buyer or renter. 
(9)  Discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of a handicap of: 
a.  That person; 
b.  A person residing in or intending to reside in that dwelling after it was so sold, rented or made available; or 
c.  Any person associated with that buyer or renter. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, discrimination includes: 
(1)  A refusal to permit, at the expense of the handicapped person, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to be occupied by any person if such modifications may be necessary to afford such person full enjoyment of the premises; except that, in the case of a rental, the landlord may, where it is reasonable to do so, condition permission for a modification on the renter's agreeing to restore the interior of the premises to the condition that existed before the modification, reasonable wear and tear excepted; 
(2)  A refusal to make reasonable accommodations in rules, practices, policies or services when such accommodations may be necessary to afford such person equal opportunity to use and enjoy a dwelling; or 
(3)  In connection with the design and construction of covered multifamily dwellings for first occupancy after March 13, 1991, a failure to design and construct dwellings in such a manner that: 
a.  The public use and common use areas of the dwellings are readily accessible to and usable by handicapped persons; 
b.  All the doors designed to allow passage into and within all premises are sufficiently wide to allow passage by handicapped persons in wheelchairs; and 
c.  All premises within covered multifamily dwelling units contain an accessible route into and through the dwelling; light switches, electrical outlets, thermostats, and other environmental controls are in accessible locations; there are reinforcements in the bathroom walls to allow later installation of grab bars; and there are usable kitchens and bathrooms such that an individual in a wheelchair can maneuver about the space. As used in this subsection the term "covered multifamily dwellings" means buildings consisting of four or more units if such buildings have one or more elevators and ground floor units in other buildings consisting of four or more units. 
(c)  Compliance with the appropriate requirements of the American National Standards for Building and Facilities (commonly cited as "ANSI A117.1") or with any other standards adopted as part of regulations promulgated by HUD providing accessibility and usability for physically handicapped people shall be deemed to satisfy the requirements of subsection (b)(3) of this section. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to invalidate or limit any state law or regulation which requires dwellings to be designed and constructed in a manner that affords handicapped persons greater access than is required by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-2(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.3. 
Sec. 42-39. - Discrimination in residential real estate-related transactions; unlawful practices by lenders, insurers, appraisers, etc.; deposit of funds in such institutions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or other entity, including any lending institution, whose business includes engaging in residential real estate-related transactions, to discriminate against any person in making available such a transaction, or in the terms or conditions of such a transaction, or in the manner of providing such a transaction, because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap. It shall not be unlawful, however, for any person or other entity whose business includes engaging in residential real estate transactions to require any applicant to qualify financially for the loan or loans for which such person is making application. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "residential real estate-related transaction" means any of the following: 
(1)  The making or purchasing of loans or providing other financial assistance (i) for purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling, or (ii) secured by residential real estate; or 
(2)  The selling, brokering, insuring or appraising of residential real property. However, nothing in this article shall prohibit a person engaged in the business of furnishing appraisals of real property to take into consideration factors other than race, color, religion, national origin, sex, elderliness, familial status or handicap. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any state, county, city or municipal treasurer or governmental official whose responsibility it is to account for, to invest, or to manage public funds to deposit or cause to be deposited any public funds in any lending institution provided for in this section which is found to be committing discriminatory practices, where such findings were upheld by any court of competent jurisdiction. Upon such a court's judicial enforcement of any order to restrain a practice of such lending institution or for such institution to cease or desist in a discriminatory practice, the appropriate fiscal officer or treasurer of the state or any political subdivision thereof which has funds deposited in any lending institution which is practicing discrimination, as set forth in this section, shall take immediate steps to have such funds withdrawn and redeposited in another lending institution. If for reasons of sound economic management, this action will result in a financial loss to the state or any of its political subdivisions, the action may be deferred for a period not longer than one year. If the lending institution in question has corrected its discriminatory practices, any prohibition set forth in this section shall not apply. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-2(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.4. 
Sec. 42-40. - Interference with enjoyment of rights of others. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory housing practice for any person to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of his having exercised or enjoyed, or on the account of his having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of, any right granted or protected by this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-2(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.5. 
Sec. 42-41. - Familial status protection not applicable to housing for older persons. 
(a)  Nothing in this article regarding unlawful discrimination because of familial status shall apply to housing for older persons. As used in this section, "housing for older persons" means housing: 
(1)  Provided under any state or federal program that is specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons, as defined in the state or federal program; 
(2)  Intended for, and solely occupied by, persons 62 years of age or older; or 
(3)  Intended for, and solely occupied by, at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit. The following criteria shall be met in determining whether housing qualifies as housing for older persons under this subsection (a)(3): 
a.  The existence of significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical or social needs of older persons, or if the provision of such facilities and services is not practicable, that such housing is necessary to provide important housing opportunities for older persons; 
b.  That at least 80 percent of the units are occupied by at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit; and 
c.  The publication of, and adherence to, policies and procedures which demonstrate an intent by the owner or manager to provide housing for persons 55 years of age or older. 
(b)  Housing shall not fail to meet the requirements for housing for older persons by reason of: 
(1)  Persons residing in such housing as of September 13, 1988, who do not meet the age requirements of subsections (a)(2) and (3), provided that new occupants of such housing meet the age requirements of those subsections; or 
(2)  Unoccupied units, provided that such units are reserved for occupancy by persons who meet the provisions of subsections (a)(2) and (3). 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.7. 
Sec. 42-42. - Civil action; enforcement by private parties. 
(a)  An aggrieved person may commence a civil action in an appropriate United States district court or state court not later than two years after the occurrence or the termination of an alleged discriminatory housing practice or the breach of a conciliation agreement entered into under this article, whichever occurs last, to obtain appropriate relief with respect to such discriminatory housing practice or breach. 
(b)  An aggrieved person may commence a civil action under subsection (a) no later than 180 days after the conclusion of the administrative process with respect to a complaint or charge, or not later than two years after the occurrence or the termination of an alleged discriminatory housing practice, whichever is later. This subsection shall not apply to actions arising from a breach of a conciliation agreement. An aggrieved person may commence a civil action under this section whether or not a complaint has been filed under Code of Virginia, § 36-96.9, and without regard to the status of any such complaint. If the board or a federal agency has obtained a conciliation agreement with the consent of an aggrieved person, no action may be filed under this section by such aggrieved person with respect to the alleged discriminatory housing practice which forms the basis for such complaint except for the purpose of enforcing the terms of such an agreement. 
(c)  In a civil action under subsection (a), if the court finds that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is about to occur, the court may award to the plaintiff, as the prevailing party, compensatory and punitive damages, reasonable attorney's fees and costs, and, subject to subsection (d), may grant as relief any permanent or temporary injunction, temporary restraining order, or other order, including an order enjoining the defendant from engaging in such practice, or order such affirmative action as may be appropriate. 
(d)  Relief granted under subsection (c) shall not affect any contract, sale, encumbrance, or lease consummated before the granting of such relief and involving bona fide purchasers, encumbrancers or tenants, without actual notice of the filing of a complaint with the board or civil action under this article. 
(e)  Upon timely application, the attorney general may intervene in such civil action, if the attorney general certifies that the case is of general public importance. Upon intervention, the attorney general may obtain such relief as would be available to the private party under subsection (c). 
(Code 1969, § 13A-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-96.18. 
Sec. 42-43. - Other remedies. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prevent any person from exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which he might otherwise be lawfully entitled or from filing any complaint with any other public agency. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-12) 
Secs. 42-44-42-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FAIR HOUSING BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 42-61. - Created; composition; appointment; compensation, terms and removal of members; vacancies; absence from meetings; administrator; additional personnel. 
(a)  There is hereby created in the city a fair housing board, which shall consist of five members, all of whom shall reside in the city. The members shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve without compensation. Members shall be appointed for staggered terms of three years each. Any member may be removed by the council upon good cause appearing to the council. Any vacancy shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired portion of a term. Absence from five consecutive meetings by any member shall vacate such member's position on the board. 
(b)  There shall be an administrator of the fair housing board, not a member of the board, who shall be appointed by the city manager. He shall serve as secretary of the board and shall be responsible for keeping the records of the board's proceedings. The administrator may be a person otherwise employed by the city, and the duties of the administration of this article may be assigned in addition to other duties. 
(c)  The city council may authorize the employment of such additional personnel to the fair housing board as are deemed warranted to secure effective enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-4) 
Sec. 42-62. - Organization; meetings; quorum; reports. 
(a)  At the first meeting of the fair housing board following annual appointments thereto, the board shall elect a chairman and a vice-chairman from its membership and establish such procedures of organization and conduct as it may deem necessary. 
(b)  The fair housing board shall meet not less than quarter-annually and upon a call of the chairman or of any three members of the board. All meetings of the board shall be with due written notice to each member. No business shall be conducted unless three or more members are present. 
(c)  The fair housing board shall render as of January 1 of each year, and thereafter quarterly during each year, to the city council a full written report of its activities under the provisions of this article, and any recommendations of the board concerning measures to be taken to further the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-5) 
Sec. 42-63. - Procedure in handling complaints. 
    The procedure of the administrator of the fair housing board in the case of the filing of a complaint shall be as follows: 
(1)  A complaint alleging the commission of a discriminatory housing practice, in writing and sworn to or affirmed, may be filed with the administrator by the complainant. Such a complaint shall state the name and address of the complainant and of the person against whom complaint is made and shall also state the alleged facts surrounding the alleged commission of a discriminatory housing practice, the date the discriminatory housing practice was allegedly committed, and such other information as the board by regulation may require. Upon receipt of such complaint, the administrator shall furnish a copy of the complaint to the person who allegedly committed or is about to commit the alleged discriminatory housing practice and to the chairman of the board. For the protection of the privacy of the individuals involved, in personal matters, every complaint shall be held in confidence by the board, its administrator and employees, unless and until the complainant and the person complained against consent to its being made public or until a hearing such as is described in subsections (5) and (6) of this section is begun. No complaint shall be filed more than 30 days after the date of the alleged discriminatory housing practice. 
(2)  Upon the filing of a complaint as set forth in subsection (1) and notice thereof to the person against whom such complaint is made, the administrator of the board shall make such investigation as he deems appropriate to ascertain the facts. If the administrator of the board shall determine that there are reasonable grounds to believe a violation has occurred and is susceptible of conciliation (such determination to be made within 15 days of the filing of the complaint), he shall attempt to conciliate the matter by methods of conference and persuasion with all interested parties and such representatives as the parties may choose to assist them. Conciliation conferences shall be informal, and nothing said or done during such initial conferences shall be made public by the board or its members or any of its staff, unless all parties thereto agree in writing. 
(3)  The terms of conciliation agreed to by the parties may be reduced to writing and incorporated into a consent agreement signed by the parties, which agreement is for conciliation purposes only and does not constitute an admission by any party that this article has been violated. Consent agreements shall be signed on behalf of the board by the chairman or the vice-chairman. 
(4)  It shall be a violation of this article to violate or fail to adhere to any provision contained in a consent agreement. A failure by the board to enforce a violation of any provision of a consent agreement shall not constitute a waiver of any right of any party to such agreement. 
(5)  If the administrator determines that the complaint lacks reasonable grounds upon which to base a violation of this article, he shall give written notice of such determination to the complainant, the person complained against and the board. The notice shall also state that the complaint will stand dismissed unless, within 20 days after mailing of such notice, the complainant files with the board, in writing, a request for a hearing by the board. Upon the filing of request for such hearing, the administrator shall immediately mail a copy of such request to the person complained against, together with notice of the time and place fixed by the board for such hearing. Thereafter, and at such time, the board shall afford the parties an opportunity to appear before the board in person or by counsel. Upon such hearing, the board may, in its discretion, dismiss such complaint or determine that there are reasonable grounds to believe the alleged violation of this article has occurred. 
(6)  If the administrator or the board has determined that there are reasonable grounds to believe the alleged violation of this article has occurred and the administrator (i) fails to conciliate a complaint after the parties have, in good faith, attempted such conciliation, or (ii) fails to effect an informal conciliation agreement or a formal consent agreement, or (iii) determines that the complaint is not susceptible of conciliation, he shall notify the chairman of the board immediately and in all cases shall give such notice within 30 days after the filing of the complaint; provided, that such period may be extended not more than 30 additional days by the board for good cause appearing to the board. Upon receiving such notice, the chairman of the board shall promptly thereafter schedule a public hearing to determine whether a violation of this article has been committed. The board shall give written notice to the respondent and the complainant containing a statement of charges and of the time and place of hearing. The respondent or his counsel may file such statements with the board prior to the hearing date as he deems necessary in support of his position. The hearing shall be open to the public, unless for the protection of the privacy of the individuals involved, in personal matters, the respondent requests in writing a private hearing, in which case the hearing shall be private. The hearing shall be held within 20 days after mailing of the statement of charges and notice of hearing. The notices so issued shall be signed by the chairman or the secretary of the board and sent by certified mail. The interested parties may, at their option, appear before the board in person or by duly authorized representatives and may be represented by an attorney. The parties may testify and present evidence, and the right to cross examine witnesses shall be preserved; and, for these purposes, the board may invite such additional persons to appear as the ends of justice may require. All testimony and evidence shall be given under oath or by affirmation. The board shall not be bound by strict rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law but shall adhere to rules of equity. The board shall keep a full record of the hearing, which record shall, unless such hearing is private, be public and open to inspection by any person, and upon request by any principal party to the proceedings, the board shall furnish such party a copy of the hearing record at the cost of the party so requesting. 
(7)  If, at the conclusion of the hearing, the board shall determine that the respondent has committed or is committing the discriminatory housing practice charged, the board shall state its finding and conclusions and shall issue and cause to be mailed by certified mail to the respondent a copy of such decision, which shall contain a warning to cease and desist from such discriminatory practice and to take such affirmative action as may be indicated to effect the purposes of this article, including, if the board so determines, reporting on the manner of his compliance. 
(8)  If, upon all the evidence at the hearing, the board shall find the respondent has not engaged in the discriminatory housing practice charged, the board shall state its findings and conclusions and shall dismiss the complaint. Notice of such action shall be given to the complainant and to the respondent by certified mail. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-6) 
Sec. 42-64. - Procedure when acting on own initiative. 
    In a case in which the fair housing board proceeds on its own initiative, without receiving a formal complaint, the procedure followed shall be that prescribed in section 42-66. No investigation shall be undertaken by the board on its own initiative if more than 60 days have elapsed since the occurrence of the discriminatory housing practice that the board has reason to believe occurred. In a case in which there is no complainant, the administrator of the board shall be responsible for developing the evidentiary record before the board. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-7) 
Sec. 42-65. - Powers generally. 
    In making the investigations, pursuing conciliation and persuasion and conducting hearings, all as described in sections 42-62-42-64, the fair housing board shall have authority to hear testimony under oath, to make findings of fact, and to issue decisions and warnings in accordance with the provisions of this article, and to make and adopt and publish such rules of procedure as may be necessary or proper for carrying out its functions under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-8) 
Sec. 42-66. - Authority to seek interlocutory relief. 
    If, at any time after a complaint has been filed or upon institution of an investigation on the fair housing board's own initiative, the board believes that appropriate civil action to abate or prevent any discriminatory housing practice, to preserve the status quo or to prevent irreparable harm appears advisable, the board may, after consultation with the commonwealth's attorney or his authorized designee, certify the matter to the commonwealth's attorney to bring any action necessary to abate or prevent such practice, preserve such status quo or to prevent such irreparable harm, including but not limited to temporary restraining orders and preliminary injunctions. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-9) 
Sec. 42-67. - Judicial review of decisions. 
(a)  Any party aggrieved by a written decision of the fair housing board made after hearing held pursuant to section 42-63 may present to the circuit court for the city a petition, duly verified, setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying the grounds of the illegality, and making party defendant thereto the opposing party in proceedings before the board. Such petition shall be presented to the court within 30 days after the filing of the decision in the office of the board. 
(b)  Upon presentation of such petition, the court may allow a writ of certiorari directed to the fair housing board to review such decision of the board and shall prescribe therein the time within which a return thereto must be made, which shall not be less than ten days and may be extended by the court. The allowance of the writ shall not stay proceedings upon the decision appealed from, but the court may, on application, on notice to the board and to the opposing party and on due cause shown, grant a restraining order. 
(c)  The fair housing board shall not be required to return the original papers acted upon by it, but it shall be sufficient to return certified or sworn copies thereof or of such portions thereof as may be called for by the writ of certiorari provided for in subsection (b). The return shall concisely set forth such other facts as may be pertinent and material to show the grounds of the decision appealed from and shall be verified by the chairman or the administrator. 
(d)  If, upon the hearing, it shall appear to the court that testimony is necessary for the proper disposition of the matter, it may take evidence or appoint a commissioner to take such evidence as it may direct and report the same to the court with his findings of fact and conclusions of law, which shall constitute a part of the proceeding upon which the determination of the court shall be made. The court may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the decision brought up for review. 
(e)  Costs shall not be allowed against the fair housing board, unless it shall appear to the court that it acted with gross negligence or in bad faith or with malice in making the decision appealed from. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-10) 
Sec. 42-68. - Enforcement by court generally. 
    If the respondent refuses or fails to comply with any decision or warning of the fair housing board, the board shall refer the matter to the commonwealth's attorney, who shall bring an action against such respondent in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce compliance with such decision. Any person who shall be found by the board to have violated the intent of this article or the public policy stated in this article relating to discriminatory housing practices shall be subject to injunctive or other appropriate action or proceeding, and any court of competent jurisdiction may issue restraining orders, temporary or permanent injunctions, or such form of relief as the court deems appropriate, and may award damages as provided in section 42-42. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-11) 
Sec. 42-69. - Addressing of notices. 
    All notices required under the provisions of this article to be given by certified mail shall be addressed to the person to whom such notice is intended at the last known address of such person or to the attorney of such person, should such attorney have formally appeared before the fair housing board on behalf of such person. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-13) 
Sec. 42-70. - Time limitation for complaints. 
    Any complaint filed under the provisions of this article shall stand dismissed unless the fair housing board has, within 90 days of the date of the filing of complaint of the alleged discriminatory housing practice, served upon the respondent a decision pursuant to the provisions of subsection (7) of section 42-63. 
(Code 1969, § 13A-14) 
Chapter 46 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Police jurisdiction over lands, buildings and structures, jurisdiction of offenses, appeals (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-887) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; regulation of teenage dancehalls, § 10-36; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; automatic police or fire alarm dialing systems, § 58-11; false report of commission of crime, § 58-15; purpose of chapter pertaining to signs, § 66-2; service charge on certain dwellings for police and fire protection and for collection and disposal of refuse, § 82-7; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Police and public order, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-131 et seq.; disposal of unclaimed property, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-133.01; destruction of unclaimed weapons, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-133.01:1; city sheriffs, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-796; powers of governor as to law enforcement agencies in localities, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-410. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Composition of police department; appointment, etc., of officers. 
    The police department shall consist of as many police officers as the council shall determine, which officers shall be appointed by and be under the immediate control of the director of the department of public safety. 
(Code 1969, § 21-1) 
Sec. 46-2. - Reports to council of arrests, complaints, etc. 
    The director of the department of public safety shall make such reports to the council of arrests, complaints, the amount of property stolen and all other such information as the council may by resolution require. 
(Code 1969, § 21-2) 
Sec. 46-3. - Powers and authority of police officers. 
    All police officers shall be invested with all the powers and authority belonging to any police officer or conservator of the peace in the state. 
(Code 1969, § 21-4) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of police force, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-138. 
Sec. 46-4. - Duties of police officers generally. 
(a)  Each police officer shall preserve and enforce the laws of the state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relative to crime. Each police officer shall use his best endeavors to prevent the commission of crime within the city and to prevent offenses against the laws of the state and against this Code and other ordinances of the city. Each police officer shall detect and arrest offenders against the laws of the state and this Code and other ordinances of the city, shall preserve the good order of the city and shall protect the inhabitants of the city from violence and the property of the citizens therein from injury. 
(b)  Police officers shall have no power or authority in civil matters, except that a police officer of the city may execute and serve an order of temporary detention and an emergency custody order and may exercise such other powers as may be specified for law enforcement officers pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 37.1-67.1, or may serve an order of protection pursuant to Code of Virginia, §§ 16.1-253.1, 16.1-253.4 and 16.1-279.1. However, a police officer of the city shall in all other cases execute such warrants or summons as may be placed in his hands by any magistrate for the city and shall make due return thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 21-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-138. 
Sec. 46-5. - Records generally. 
    The police officers, under the direction and authority of the director of the department of public safety, shall preserve all records which are essential to the effective administration and maintenance of the police department. Such records shall contain an accurate account of the performance of all duties required by the state laws and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 21-6) 
Sec. 46-6. - Sale or other disposition of property seized by police. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all police officers to, as soon as practicable, deliver all property seized by them to the chief of police. The chief of police shall keep a record of all such property so seized or otherwise taken possession of. If such property so seized or taken possession of shall not be claimed and possession surrendered to the rightful owner within 60 days from the date of the final disposition of any court proceedings in connection with which such property was seized or otherwise taken possession of, or in case there are no court proceedings, then if such property so seized or taken possession of shall not be claimed by the rightful owner thereof and possession surrendered to such owner within 60 days from the date of such seizure, the chief of police or his duly authorized agents shall make reasonable attempts to notify the rightful owner of the property, obtain from the commonwealth's attorney in writing a statement advising that the item is not needed in any criminal prosecution, and cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city once a week for two successive weeks notice that there will be a public sale of unclaimed personal property. Such property shall be described generally in the notice, together with the date, time and place of the sale. The publication shall provide that if such property is not claimed by the rightful owner thereof within ten days from the date of such publication, such property will be sold at public auction at such place as the chief of police may select and in such manner as to expose to the inspection of bidders all property so offered for sale; provided, that such unclaimed property, if deemed by the chief of police to be of use to the department of police, may be retained for the use of such department. 
(b)  Should, however, any unclaimed property seized or taken possession of by the police be of a perishable nature, or so bulky or of such character as to make it dangerous or inadvisable or dangerous to retain possession thereof for 60 days as provided for in subsection (a), upon a certification of such fact by the chief of police, setting forth his reasons why such property should not be retained for the period of time provided for in subsection (a), the chief of police shall cause such property to be advertised forthwith in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city and sell such property at public auction at any time after three days shall have elapsed from the seizure or taking possession thereof. 
(c)  The chief of police or his duly authorized agents shall pay from the proceeds of sale of unclaimed property under this section the costs of advertisement, removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and liens, and notice of sale. The balance of the funds shall be held by such officer for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership. If no claim has been made by the owner for the proceeds of such sale within 60 days of the sale, the remaining funds shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. Any such owner shall be entitled to apply to the city within three years from the date of the sale and, if timely application is made therefor, the city shall pay the remaining proceeds of the sale to the owner without interest or other charges. No claim shall be made nor any suit, action or proceeding be instituted for the recovery of such funds after three years from the date of the sale. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall apply to the disposition of deadly weapons, such as pistols, revolvers, derringers, bowie knives, dirks, metallic knuckles and other like weapons, the seizure and disposition of which are covered by Code of Virginia, § 18.2-310. 
(Code 1969, § 21-7) 
State Law reference- Disposal of unclaimed property in possession of police, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-133.01; disposal of unclaimed firearms or other weapons in possession of police, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-133.01:1. 
Sec. 46-7. - Term of police officers. 
    All police officers appointed by the director of the department of public safety shall hold office during good behavior and at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 21-3) 
Sec. 46-8. - Refusal to aid officer in execution of his office. 
    If any person on being required by any sheriff or other officer refuse or neglect to assist him: (i) in the execution of his office in a criminal case, (ii) in the preservation of the peace, (iii) in the apprehending or securing of any person for a breach of the peace, or (iv) in any case of escape or rescue, he shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 17-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-463. 
Sec. 46-9. - Impersonating officer. 
    No person shall falsely assume or exercise the functions, powers, duties and privileges incident to the office of sheriff, police officer, marshal, chief of police, or other police officer or peace officer, or shall falsely assume or pretend to be any such officer. 
(Code 1969, § 17-35) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-174. 
Secs. 46-10-46-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRISONERS[2] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Prisoner escaping from jail, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-477 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 46-41-46-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WORK FORCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to require prisoners to work (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-904) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Municipal work forces, Code of Virginia, § 53.1-128. 

Sec. 46-56. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established a city work force for the purpose of working on the streets, roads and public property in the city, or farms owned, leased or rented by the city and in or on any other public property or works owned, leased or operated by the city, whether such public property or works are located within or outside the city. 
(Code 1969, § 9-9) 
Sec. 46-57. - Who may be worked. 
    Every person 18 years of age or older who is convicted and confined for any violation of a local ordinance and who is confined as a punishment or for failure to pay a required fine shall be liable to work in such work force. Every person 18 years of age or older who is confined pending disposition of a nonviolent criminal offense or an offense under Code of Virginia, § 20-61 et seq. may work in such work force on a voluntary basis with the approval of and under the supervision of the sheriff. 
(Code 1969, § 9-10) 
Sec. 46-58. - How and by whom guarded. 
    The director of the street department, or the superintendent of the work force, if the appointment of one is deemed necessary by the city manager, shall guard, supervise and compel prisoners on the work force to do such work as may be ordered done by the city manager, and shall return such prisoners to the jail at night for safekeeping. 
(Code 1969, § 9-11) 
Sec. 46-59. - Police powers of director of street department, etc. 
    The director of the street department or the superintendent of the work force, as the case may be, shall in the discharge of his duties and in guarding and managing prisoners on the work force, be invested with all the powers and rights of a regular police officer, and shall, when necessary, be supplied with the requisite equipment to prevent the escape of such prisoners. 
(Code 1969, § 9-12) 
Sec. 46-60. - Clothing and supplies for prisoners. 
    The director of the street department, or the superintendent of the work force, as the case may be, shall be furnished with proper clothing and supplies, where necessary, for the prisoners working in the work force, and such clothing and supplies shall be procured by the purchasing agent and paid for out of the city treasury. 
(Code 1969, § 9-13) 
Chapter 50 - LIBRARY[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Local libraries generally, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-33 et seq. 

Sec. 50-1. - Management of public libraries. 
    The public libraries of the city shall be operated under the management and supervision of the city manager, in accordance with the provisions of section 5.2 of the Charter. 
(Code 1969, § 2-4.2) 
Chapter 54 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 38; planning, ch. 62; signs, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 78; taxation, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Construction and safety standards, Code of Virginia, § 36-85.11; enforcement of obligations imposed on landlords, Code of Virginia, § 55-248.49. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home means any trailer, mobile home or any unit used for living and sleeping purposes, and which may be, or is, intended for transport from one place to another, whether by motive power or otherwise. 
    Mobile home park means any trailer court or place, lot or tract of land upon which is located, or which is held out for the location of, one or more trailers or mobile homes. 
(Code 1969, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-2. - Authority for adoption of chapter; purpose of chapter. 
    This chapter is adopted under the general police and Charter powers of the city. This chapter is intended to regulate mobile homes and mobile home parks in the city in such a manner as to protect the citizens of this community, as well as those occupying such mobile homes and mobile home parks. 
(Code 1969, § 29-2) 
Sec. 54-3. - Formulation and promulgation of rules and regulations by health director. 
    The health director may formulate and promulgate rules and regulations concerning mobile home parks. 
(Code 1969, § 29-3) 
Sec. 54-4. - Compliance with chapter, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, leasing, renting, operating or in charge of any mobile home park in the city to comply with all the provisions of this chapter and the rules or regulations formulated and promulgated by the health director governing such mobile home parks. 
(Code 1969, § 29-4) 
Sec. 54-5. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    It shall be the duty of the health director and of the police force generally to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 29-5) 
Sec. 54-6. - Right of entry of health director. 
    For the purpose of securing enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, the health director or any city police officer may, at any reasonable time, enter upon the premises of any mobile home park within the city to inspect such mobile home park and all accommodations connected therewith. 
(Code 1969, § 29-6) 
Sec. 54-7. - Limitations on parking mobile homes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any mobile home, while such mobile home is used for human habitation, on any street, alley or other public place in the city or to park any mobile home, when such mobile home is not so used, on the streets of the city for a longer period than three days. 
(Code 1969, § 29-7) 
Sec. 54-8. - Limitation on keeping mobile home used as human habitation, not in mobile home park. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, keep or maintain, for more than three consecutive days, any mobile home, while used for human habitation, upon any lot or parcel of land within the city, except in a mobile home park, as provided for in this chapter. 
(Code 1969, § 29-8) 
Secs. 54-9-54-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Mobile home courts district R-M, § 66-255. 
State Law reference- Campgrounds, Code of Virginia, § 35.1-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-36. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to mobile home parks in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-17) 
Sec. 54-37. - Drainage of area where located and premises. 
    Every mobile home park shall be located on a well-drained area and the premises graded so as to prevent the accumulation of storm, casual or surface waters. 
(Code 1969, § 29-18) 
Sec. 54-38. - Required space for trailer. 
    Every mobile home park in the city shall be laid off so as to provide a space of not less than 1,000 square feet of ground per mobile home, exclusive of the ground underneath the mobile home in the particular space. 
(Code 1969, § 29-19) 
Sec. 54-39. - Distance between mobile homes; arrangement of mobile homes. 
(a)  No mobile home shall be closer than 15 feet to any other mobile home, nor within 25 feet of the right-of-way line of any street, nor closer than five feet to the mobile home park property line. 
(b)  The mobile homes shall be arranged in rows abutting or facing on a driveway or on an unoccupied space of not less than 30 feet in width. Where there is provided a continuous driveway with an entrance and exit to a public highway, such driveway shall be not less than 16 feet in width. Such driveway or space shall have unobstructed access to a public street. 
(Code 1969, § 29-20) 
Sec. 54-40. - Adequate water supply required; water tap or connection for each mobile home space. 
    An adequate supply of water from the city water system, for drinking and domestic purposes, shall be supplied by the owner or operator to meet the requirements of each mobile home park. Each mobile home space in a mobile home park shall have a separate and independent water tap or connection permanently installed and ready to be connected to the plumbing fixtures within each mobile home. 
(Code 1969, § 29-21) 
Cross reference- Waterworks system and water supply generally, § 90-71 et seq. 
Sec. 54-41. - Sewer connections and plumbing fixtures; disposition of wastewater, etc. 
(a)  Each mobile home space, as provided for in this article, shall have a separate and independent sewer connection, connected to the city's sanitary sewer system, permanently installed, and ready to be connected to the plumbing fixtures within each mobile home. All such sewer connections and appurtenances shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit any wastewater or materials from sinks, baths, showers or other plumbing fixtures in any mobile home park to be deposited upon the surface of the ground. All such fixtures, when in use, shall be connected to the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 29-22) 
Sec. 54-42. - Facilities for water closets, lavatories, etc. 
    There shall be provided in every mobile home park one room equipped with one water closet, one lavatory and one bathtub or shower for each sex, and there shall be provided an additional water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower for each sex for every ten or fractional part thereof in excess of ten males or ten females occupying mobile homes in the mobile home park in question, which mobile homes are not equipped with individual toilet facilities. One of such rooms shall be distinctly marked "Men" and one of such rooms shall be distinctly marked "Women" or "Ladies." The rooms for such toilet facilities shall be separated by a sound resistant wall. A vestibule or screen wall shall be provided to prevent direct view into the toilet room when exterior doors are open. 
(Code 1969, § 29-23) 
Sec. 54-43. - Receptacles for garbage, refuse, etc. 
    Each mobile home space, as provided for in this article, while occupied by any mobile home, shall have at least one metal watertight container of not more than 30 gallons, nor less than 15 gallons' capacity, with a closefitting cover for the deposit of garbage, refuse, rubbish and the like. Such waste and garbage receptacles shall at all times be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition; and in addition thereto, the requirements of all other city ordinances relative to the collection and disposal of garbage and trash shall be complied with. 
(Code 1969, § 29-24) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 70. 
Sec. 54-44. - Lighting. 
    Every mobile home park shall be provided with adequate means of lighting the mobile home park at night. Such sufficient lighting facilities shall be kept lighted during the time from one-half hour after sunset until one-half hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1969, § 29-25) 
Sec. 54-45. - Recreation area. 
    At least 200 square feet per mobile home space in a mobile home park shall be made available for recreational uses. These areas shall be located so as to be free of traffic hazards. 
(Code 1969, § 29-26) 
Sec. 54-46. - Heating appliances and fuel. 
    All heating appliances and fuels used in mobile home parks shall meet the rules, regulations and requirements of the National Fire Protection Association or the American Insurance Association. Any mobile home using liquefied petroleum gas shall comply with, and be subject to, the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city relative to standards for liquefied petroleum gas equipment and its use. Any person occupying a mobile home using oil as a fuel shall store such oil in a cylinder which shall be connected to the stoves or heaters of the mobile home by copper or other metallic tubing, and shall have leakproof connections. Such oil cylinders shall be securely fastened in place not less than five feet from any mobile home exit. 
(Code 1969, § 29-28) 
Cross reference- Liquefied petroleum gas, § 34-201 et seq. 
Sec. 54-47. - Electricity. 
    Every mobile home park shall be provided with electric power. An electric outlet supplying 110-220 volts shall be provided for each mobile home space and such outlets shall be weatherproof and within easy reach of the parked mobile home. In no instance shall any power line across the mobile home park area be less than 18 feet above the ground if it is not under the ground. Service drops to each mobile home space shall be weatherproof, insulated, and not smaller than two number 8 wires. Adequate overcurrent protection shall be provided on all circuits. All electric wiring in every mobile home park shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-29) 
Cross reference- Electricity, § 18-166 et seq.; city electric system, § 90-26 et seq. 
Sec. 54-48. - Removal of wheels. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or operating a mobile home park to remove, or cause to be removed, or permit the removal of, the wheels or any similar transporting devices, except for necessary repairs, from any mobile home or to otherwise permanently fix or attach such mobile home to the ground. Any alteration of, addition to, or removal of the wheels from any mobile home, as set forth in this section, shall be construed as removing it from the provisions of this article and converting it into a dwelling and it shall thereupon be subject to the requirements of chapters 18 and 106 and all other similar provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-30) 
Sec. 54-49. - Inspection of premises; effect of discovery of condition in violation of article. 
    Each mobile home park located within the city shall be inspected by the fire chief at least twice each month to see that the provisions of this article are complied with. The chief of police or health director, either or both, shall also inspect such mobile home parks periodically, at least once each 30 days, to see that the provisions of this article are complied with. If such inspection reveals that any of the provisions of this article are violated, such violation shall subject the owner, operator, lessee or person in charge of such mobile home park not only to penalties for the violation of this article, but the permit provided for in this article may be forthwith revoked. 
(Code 1969, § 29-31) 
Secs. 54-50-54-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 54-76. - Required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate within the city any mobile home park without first having secured a written permit therefor from the city manager. The fee for the issuance of such permit shall be $20.00, which fee shall be paid into the city treasury and placed in the general funds of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 29-9) 
Sec. 54-77. - Application, contents. 
    Any person desiring a permit as required in section 54-76 shall make application therefor in writing to the city manager, stating his name and address, the location and general layout of the proposed mobile home park, the detailed plans and specifications of the water supply, electric wiring plans, parking facilities, provisions for sewage and garbage disposal of such proposed mobile home park, and such other information as the city manager may deem necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 29-10) 
Sec. 54-78. - Investigation of applicant, etc. 
    Upon the filing of any application as required by section 54-77, the city manager and the chief of police shall make, or cause to be made, an investigation of the character of the applicant and the premises whereon or wherein the mobile home park in question is to be located. 
(Code 1969, § 29-11) 
Sec. 54-79. - Issuance and refusal generally. 
    On receipt of evidence by the city manager that the applicant in question is a proper person to receive a permit, as required in section 54-76, and if the premises whereon or wherein the proposed mobile home park is to be located is found to be in compliance with the provisions of this article and other ordinances of the city and laws of the state relative to mobile home parks, the city manager shall issue the permit as required in section 54-76; otherwise, the city manager shall refuse to issue such permit. 
(Code 1969, § 29-12) 
Sec. 54-80. - To be deemed personal privilege; transfer prohibited. 
    Any permit issued under section 54-79 shall be deemed to be a personal privilege and no such permit shall be transferable. 
(Code 1969, § 29-13) 
Sec. 54-81. - Posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for the holder of a permit issued under section 54-79 to fail, neglect or refuse to keep such permit posted at all times in a conspicuous place in the mobile home park in question. 
(Code 1969, § 29-14) 
Sec. 54-82. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued as provided in section 54-79 may be revoked by the city manager at any time for failure to comply with the provisions of this article or any other ordinance of the city, or law of the state or regulations of the state board of health regarding public health, applicable to mobile home parks. 
(Code 1969, § 29-15) 
Sec. 54-83. - Appeal of refusal or revocation. 
    There shall be a right of an appeal to the council from the action of the city manager in refusing to issue a permit to the person applying therefor, as provided in section 54-79, and from the action of the city manager revoking a permit, as provided in section 54-82. Such appeal shall be by written application only, directed to the council and delivered to the clerk of council within ten days after the refusal to issue such permit or within ten days from the revocation of the permit, as the case may be. 
(Code 1969, § 29-16) 
Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Human relations, ch. 42. 
State Law reference- Local control of firearms restricted, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-29.15; local ordinances prohibiting obscenity, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-389. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Abusive language. 
    If any person shall, in the presence or hearing of another, curse or abuse such other person, or use any violent abusive language to such person concerning himself or any of his relations, or otherwise use such language, under circumstances reasonably calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 17-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-416. 
Sec. 58-2. - Adultery and fornication-Adultery defined. 
    Any person, being married, who voluntarily shall have sexual intercourse with any person not his spouse shall be guilty of adultery. 
(Code 1969, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-365. 
Sec. 58-3. - Same-Fornication defined. 
    Any person, not being married, who voluntarily shall have sexual intercourse with any other person shall be guilty of fornication. 
(Code 1969, § 17-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-344. 
Sec. 58-4. - Same-How punished. 
    If any person commits adultery or fornication, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 17-4) 
State Law reference- Penalty for adultery or fornication, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-344, 18.2-365. 
Sec. 58-5. - Same-By persons forbidden to marry. 
    If any person commits adultery or fornication with any person whom he is forbidden by law to marry, such person shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-7; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to a person committing adultery or fornication with his daughter or granddaughter, or with her son or grandson, or her father or his mother. 
(Code 1969, § 17-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-366. 
Sec. 58-6. - Advertisements, etc., tearing down, etc. 
    No person shall tear down an advertisement, poster, sign or the like put up by or with the consent of the owner of the property whereupon the advertisement, poster, sign or the like is posted or erected, or alter or mutilate the advertisement, poster, sign or the like without the consent of such owner. 
(Code 1969, § 17-6) 
Sec. 58-7. - Ambulances and firefighting equipment, calling or summoning without just cause. 
    No person shall without just cause therefor call or summon, by telephone or otherwise, any ambulance or firefighting apparatus. 
(Code 1969, § 17-7) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-212. 
Sec. 58-8. - Assault and battery. 
    No person shall commit an unjustifiable assault or unjustifiable assault and battery upon another, which assault or assault and battery does not amount to a felony under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1969, § 17-8) 
State Law reference- Assaults and bodily woundings, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-51 et seq. 
Sec. 58-9. - Attempts-Generally.
