    The provisions of sections 86-248 to 86-250 shall not apply to any vehicle owned or controlled by the state department of transportation or counties, cities or towns while actually engaged in the construction, reconstruction or maintenance of highways. 
(Code 1969, § 15-93(c); Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-891. 
Sec. 86-256. - Parking of passenger buses, trucks, etc., between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or driver of any motor passenger bus or the owner, operator or driver of any truck, trailer or semitrailer to park such bus, truck, trailer or semitrailer or permit such bus, truck, trailer or semitrailer to be parked on any street or public place between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. following of any day; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to trucks not exceeding half-ton capacity. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Sec. 86-257. - Permit for parking truck beside railroad car standing on public right-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any truck beside a railroad car standing on any public right-of-way without a special permit from the chief of police, which permit shall be issued only in cases of extreme hardship and physical necessity for the purpose of loading or unloading. 
(Code 1969, § 15-95; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Sec. 86-258. - Where school bus to be stopped. 
    Every school bus shall stop as far to the right of the street as possible before discharging or loading passengers and, when possible, shall not stop where the visibility is obscured for a distance of 200 feet either way from the bus. 
(Code 1969, § 15-96; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Sec. 86-259. - Leaving vehicle standing for more than four days on street, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any street or within any city parking lot and leave such vehicle standing for a period of more than four consecutive days. 
(Code 1969, § 15-97; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Sec. 86-260. - Blocking driveways of filling stations, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle so as to block any driveway of any filling station or other like establishment. 
(Code 1969, § 15-98; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Cross reference- Chapter 34 of Salem City Code. 
Sec. 86-261. - Removal and disposition of certain unattended vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof: 
(1)  Is left unattended on a public highway or other public property and constitutes a traffic hazard; 
(2)  Is illegally parked; 
(3)  Is left unattended for more than four days on public property without the permission of an agent of the city. 
(b)  It shall be presumed that a vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof is abandoned on a public highway if: 
(1)  It lacks either: 
a.  A current license plate; or 
b.  A current city license plate or sticker; or 
c.  A valid state safety inspection certificate or sticker; or 
(2)  It has been in a specific location for four days without being moved. 
(c)  Each vehicle removal under this section shall be reported to the police department, and notice thereof given to the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer as promptly as possible. The owner of such vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof, before obtaining possession thereof, shall pay to the persons entitled thereto all costs incidental to the removal, storage and locating the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof. Should such owner fail or refuse to pay the cost or should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown and unascertainable after a diligent search has been made, and after notice to him at his last known address and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the state department of motor vehicles against the motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof, the vehicle shall be treated as an abandoned vehicle under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1200 et seq. 
(Code 1969, § 15-99; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1213. 
Sec. 86-262. - Leaving vehicles on private property prohibited; removal and disposition; notice of disposition. 
(a)  No person shall leave any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof on the private property of any other person without his consent. On complaint of the owner of the property on which such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof has been left for more than four days, such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof may be removed by or under the direction of a law enforcement officer to a storage area. Nothing in this section shall prohibit a property owner from removing a vehicle in accordance with Virginia state law. 
(b)  Any such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof may be removed for safekeeping by or under the direction of a police officer to a storage area; provided, however that no such vehicle or part thereof shall be so removed from privately owned premises without the written request of the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises. The person at whose request such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof is removed from private property shall indemnify and hold harmless the city against any loss or expense incurred by reason of removal, storage or sale thereof. 
(c)  In the case of the removal of a motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof from private property, when it cannot be readily sold, the motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof may be disposed of in whatever manner the council may provide. In all other respects, the provisions of section 86-261 and Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1217 shall apply to these removals. Disposal of a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer may at the option of the council be carried out under either the provisions of section 86-261 or under the provisions of this section after a diligent search for the owner, after notice to him at his last known address, and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the department against the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, and after the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer has been held at least 60 days. The department shall be notified of the disposition of any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer under section 86-261 or the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1969, § 15-100; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1215. 
Sec. 86-263. - Notice of disposition of vehicle under section 86-261 or 86-262. 
    The state department of motor vehicles shall be notified of the disposition of any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer under section 86-261 or 86-262. 
(Code 1969, § 15-101; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1215. 
Sec. 86-264. - Keeping inoperative motor vehicles on residential, commercial or agricultural property. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, except within a fully enclosed building or structure or otherwise shielded or screened from view, on any property zoned for residential, commercial or agricultural purposes, any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer which is inoperative. As used in this section, an "inoperative motor vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle which is not in operating condition; or which for a period of 60 days or longer has been partially or totally disassembled by the removal of tires and wheels, the engine, or other essential parts required for operation of the vehicle; or on which there are displayed neither valid license plates nor valid inspection decal. However, the provisions of this section shall not apply to a licensed business which is regularly engaged in business as an automobile dealer, salvage dealer or scrap processor. 
(b)  Removal and disposition of inoperative vehicles on property zoned for residential, commercial or agricultural purposes; costs. 
(1)  The owners of property zoned for residential, commercial or agricultural purposes shall, at such time as the council may prescribe, remove therefrom any such inoperative motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers that are not kept within a fully enclosed building or structure. 
(2)  The council, through its agents or employees, may remove any such inoperative motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers whenever the owner of the premises, after 15 days' notice, has failed to do so. 
(3)  If the council, through its agents or employees, removes any such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers after having given such notice, such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers may be disposed of after giving an additional 15 days' notice to the owner of the vehicle. 
(4)  The cost of any such removal or disposal shall be chargeable to the owner of the vehicle or premises and may be collected as taxes and levies are collected. 
(5)  Every cost authorized by this section with which the owner of the premises shall have been assessed shall constitute a lien against the property from which the vehicle was removed, the lien to continue until actual payment of such cost shall have been made. 
(Code 1969, § 15-101.1; Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Sec. 86-265. - Penalties for parking violations. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of a traffic infraction and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in accordance with the following table: 
Table of Parking Offenses and Penalties 
Overtime parking ..... $20.00 
No parking zone ..... $20.00 
Handicapped parking space ..... $100.00 
Fire lane ..... $50.00 
Restricted parking area ..... $20.00 
No city tag or decal ..... $25.00 
No valid state tags ..... $20.00 
No stopping or standing zone ..... $20.00 
Blocking traffic ..... $20.00 
Parking within 15 ft. of a fire hydrant ..... $20.00 
Parking on a crosswalk ..... $20.00 
Parking within 20 ft. of a crosswalk at an intersection ..... $20.00 
Parking within a tow away zone ..... $20.00 
Blocking public or private driveway ..... $20.00 
Parking in wrong direction ..... $20.00 
No valid state inspection decal ..... $20.00 
Parking in designated space on city property ..... $20.00 
Other violation not specified ..... $20.00 
(Ord. of 4-11-2011(1)) 
Secs. 86-266-86-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL PERMIT 

Sec. 86-276. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Resident means any person who owns and occupies any dwelling along with the members of his household, or any person who rents on a predetermined basis any apartment or room within the area outlined in section 86-277. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.5) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-277. - Residential permit parking. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle without a valid permit parking sticker, except emergency or commercial vehicles loading or unloading, on the west side of North Market Street from its intersection with Clay Street northward to its intersection with McClung Street. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.1) 
Sec. 86-278. - Issuance of permits. 
    Residential parking permits shall be issued to those residents of the area designated in section 86-277 wishing to park motor vehicles at curbside on the streets within such area. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.2) 
Sec. 86-279. - Permits issued by city treasurer; expiration. 
    Residential parking permits shall be issued by the city treasurer. Such permits shall be valid and shall expire on the same annual basis as city license decals. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.3) 
Sec. 86-280. - Sale or transfer of vehicle; issuance of duplicate permit. 
    Upon the sale or transfer of the motor vehicle for which a parking permit has been issued, the owner shall remove such permit. Upon application for a permit to replace the one so removed, such owner shall present the original permit, or enough of the mutilated permit to identify it, and a duplicate permit shall be issued by the treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.4) 
Sec. 86-281. - Proof of residency. 
    Any person who is not a permanent resident of the city shall show to the treasurer a receipt for rent paid for an apartment or room within the area outlined in section 86-277 or a signed statement from his landlord that he is a tenant within such area. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.6) 
Sec. 86-282. - Guest cards. 
    Each dwelling house or apartment in which there is a household living on a yearround basis shall be issued three guest cards at the time of the issuance of the parking permit to be used by visitors at such household, and no more than two guest cards shall be in use at any one time. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.7) 
Sec. 86-283. - Placement of stickers and guest cards. 
    The stickers issued under section 86-278 shall be affixed to the inside of the windshield of the vehicle in the lower righthand corner next to the city decal. Guest cards when in use shall be placed in the same position. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.9) 
Sec. 86-284. - Penalty for violation of division. 
    Any person convicted of violating the terms of this division shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each day a vehicle is parked in violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. Any vehicle parked in violation of this division for more than three days will be subject to being towed away at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1969, § 15-94.8) 
Secs. 86-285-86-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FLARES AND OTHER SIGNALS WHEN VEHICLE IS DISABLED ON STREET AFTER DARK 

Sec. 86-301. - Required generally. 
    Whenever any bus, truck, trailer, house trailer or mobile home is disabled and stops on any portion of any interstate highway at any time during which lights are required on motor vehicles by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1030, the operator of such vehicle shall place or cause to be placed on the roadway three red flares or torches of a type approved by the superintendent of state police. One of the flares or torches shall be placed in the center of the lane of traffic occupied by the disabled vehicle and not less than 100 feet therefrom in the direction of traffic approaching in that lane, a second not less than 100 feet from such vehicle in the opposite direction, and a third at the traffic side of such vehicle not closer than ten feet from its front or rear. However, if such vehicle is disabled within 500 feet of a curve or crest of a hill or other obstruction to view, the flares or torches in that direction shall be so placed as to afford ample warning to other users of the highway, but in no case less than 500 feet from the disabled vehicle. Red reflectorized triangular warning devices of a type approved by the superintendent of state police may be used in lieu of flares or torches. 
(Code 1969, § 15-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-111(A). 
Sec. 86-302. - When red reflector flares or red lanterns required. 
    If any vehicle referred to in section 86-301 is used for the transportation of inflammable liquids in bulk, whether loaded or empty, or for transporting inflammable gases, red reflector flares or red electric lanterns of a type approved by the superintendent of state police shall be used. Such reflectors or lanterns shall be lighted and placed upon the roadway in the manner provided in section 86-301. 
(Code 1969, § 15-104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-111(B). 
Sec. 86-303. - When red flags required. 
    During such time as lights on motor vehicles are not required, red flags not less than 12 inches both in length and width shall be used in the place of flares, torches or lanterns. The flags shall be placed on the roadway in the manner prescribed in sections 86-301 and 86-302 for flares, torches and lanterns; except that no flag shall be required to be placed at the side of such vehicle. If the disablement of such vehicle continues into the period when lights on motor vehicles are required, flares, torches, reflectors or lanterns shall be placed as required by sections 86-301 and 86-302. Red reflectorized triangular warning devices of a type approved by the superintendent may be used in lieu of flags. 
(Code 1969, § 15-105) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-111(C). 
Secs. 86-304-86-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDESTRIANS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-321. - How and where pedestrians to cross highways. 
    When crossing highways, pedestrians shall not carelessly or maliciously interfere with the orderly passage of vehicles. They shall cross, wherever possible, only at intersections or marked crosswalks. Where intersections contain no marked crosswalks, pedestrians shall not be guilty of negligence as a matter of law for crossing at any such intersection or between intersections when crossing by the most direct route. Pedestrians may cross an intersection diagonally when all traffic entering the intersection has been halted by lights, other traffic control devices, or by a law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1969, § 15-106) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-923. 
Sec. 86-322. - Right-of-way of pedestrians. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle on a highway shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian crossing such highway: 
(1)  At any clearly marked crosswalk, whether at midblock or at the end of any block. 
(2)  At any regular pedestrian crossing included in the prolongation of the lateral boundary lines of the adjacent sidewalk at the end of a block. 
(3)  At any intersection when the driver is approaching on a highway or street where the legal maximum speed does not exceed 35 miles per hour. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, at intersections or crosswalks where the movement of traffic is being regulated by law enforcement officers or traffic control devices, the driver shall yield according to the direction of the law enforcement officer or device. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall enter or cross an intersection in disregard of approaching traffic. 
(c)  The drivers of vehicles entering, crossing or turning at intersections shall change their course, slow down, or stop if necessary to permit pedestrians to cross such intersections safely and expeditiously. 
(d)  Pedestrians crossing highways at intersections shall at all times have the right-of-way over vehicles making turns into the highways being crossed by the pedestrians. 
(Code 1969, § 15-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-924. 
Sec. 86-323. - Pedestrians stepping into highway where they cannot be seen. 
    No pedestrian shall step into a highway open to moving vehicular traffic at any point between intersections where his presence would be obscured from the vision of drivers of approaching vehicles by a vehicle or other obstruction at the curb or side. The foregoing prohibition shall not apply to a pedestrian stepping into a highway to board a bus or to enter a safety zone, in which event he shall cross the highway only at right angles. 
(Code 1969, § 15-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-926. 
Sec. 86-324. - Boarding or alighting from buses. 
    When actually boarding or alighting from buses, pedestrians shall have the right-of-way over vehicles, but shall not, in order to board or alight from buses, step into the highway sooner or remain there longer than is absolutely necessary. 
(Code 1969, § 15-109) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-927. 
Sec. 86-325. - Pedestrians not to use roadway except when necessary; keeping to left. 
    Pedestrians shall not use the roadways for travel, except when necessary to do so because of the absence of sidewalks which are reasonably suitable and passable for their use. If they walk on the hard surface or the main travelled portion of the roadway, they shall keep to the extreme left side or edge thereof, or where the shoulders of the highway are of sufficient width to permit, they may walk on either shoulder thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 15-110) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-928. 
Sec. 86-326. - Playing on highways; roller skates, skateboards, toys or other devices on wheels or runners; persons riding bicycles, mopeds, etc., not to attach to vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall play on a highway, other than on the sidewalks thereof. No person shall use roller skates, skateboards, toys or other devices on wheels or runners, except bicycles, mopeds and motorcycles, on highways where play is prohibited. The council may designate areas on highways under its control where play is permitted and may impose reasonable restrictions on play on such highways. If the highways have only two traffic lanes, persons using such devices, except bicycles, mopeds and motorcycles, shall keep as near as reasonably possible to the extreme left side or edge of the left traffic lane so that they will be facing oncoming traffic at all times. 
(b)  No person riding on any bicycle, moped, roller skates, skateboards, toys or other devices on wheels or runners shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle on a roadway. 
(Code 1969, § 15-111) 
State Law reference- Playing on highways, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-932. 
Sec. 86-327. - Penalty for violating division. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this division shall be fined not more than $200.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1969, § 15-112) 
State Law reference- Localities imposing penalties for certain offenses not to exceed penalty for traffic infraction, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-935. 
Sec. 86-328. - Solicitation of transportation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while upon any street or the right-of-way of any street, to endeavor by words, gestures or otherwise to beg, invite or secure transportation in any motor vehicle not engaged in passenger carrying for hire, unless such person knows the driver thereof or any passenger therein; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prohibit the solicitation of aid in the event of accidents or by persons who are sick or seeking assistance for the sick in cases of bona fide sickness in which an emergency exists. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1969, § 15-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-929. 
Secs. 86-329-86-345. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BLIND OR INCAPACITATED PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 86-346. - When vehicles to stop for pedestrian guided by dog or carrying white, red-tipped white, or metallic cane. 
(a)  Whenever a totally or partially blind pedestrian crossing or attempting to cross a highway in accordance with the provisions of section 86-321 is guided by a guide dog or carrying a cane which is predominantly metallic or white in color, with or without a red tip, the driver of every vehicle approaching the intersection or place of crossing shall bring his vehicle to a full stop before arriving at such intersection or place of crossing, unless such intersection or place of crossing is controlled by a law enforcement officer or traffic light. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 15-113) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-933. 
Sec. 86-347. - Construction of preceding section; failure to use cane or guide dog not contributory negligence. 
    Nothing contained in section 86-346 shall be construed to deprive any totally or partially blind or otherwise incapacitated person not carrying such a cane or walking stick or not being guided by a dog of the rights and privileges conferred by law upon pedestrians crossing streets. Nor shall the failure of such totally or partially blind or otherwise incapacitated person to carry a cane or walking stick or to be guided by a guide dog upon the streets or sidewalks of the city be held to constitute or be evidence of contributory negligence. 
(Code 1969, § 15-116) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-934. 
Sec. 86-348. - Unlawful for person not blind or incapacitated to carry white, white tipped with red or metallic cane. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, unless totally or partially blind or otherwise incapacitated, while on any public street or highway to carry in a raised or extended position a cane or walking stick which is metallic or white in color or white tipped with red. 
(b)  Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 15-114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-212.1. 
Secs. 86-349-86-365. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 86-366. - Duty of driver to stop, etc., in event of accident involving injury or death, or damage to attended property. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident in which a person is killed or injured or in which an attended vehicle or other attended property is damaged shall immediately stop as close to the scene of the accident as possible without obstructing traffic and report his name, address, driver's license number and vehicle registration number forthwith to the state police or local law enforcement agency, to the person struck and injured if such person appears to be capable of understanding and retaining the information, to the driver or some other occupant of the vehicle collided with, or to the custodian of other damaged property. The driver shall also render reasonable assistance to any person injured in such accident, including taking such injured person to a physician, surgeon or hospital if it is apparent that medical treatment is necessary or is requested by the injured person. 
(b)  Where, because of injuries sustained in the accident, the driver is prevented from complying with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the driver shall, as soon as reasonably possible, make the required report to the state police or local law enforcement agency and make a reasonable effort to locate the person struck, or the driver or some other occupant of the vehicle collided with, or the custodian of the damaged property, and report to such person his name, address, driver's license number and vehicle registration number. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-894. 
Sec. 86-367. - Duty of certain persons accompanying driver to report accidents involving injury or death, or damage to attended property. 
    If the driver fails to stop and make the report required by section 86-366, every person 16 years of age or older in the vehicle with the driver at the time of the accident who has knowledge of the accident shall have a duty to ensure that a report is made within 24 hours from the time of the accident to the police department. The report shall include his name, address, and such other information within his knowledge as the driver is required to report pursuant to section 86-366. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-895. 
Sec. 86-368. - Duties of driver in event of accident involving damage only to unattended property. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident in which no person is killed or injured, but in which an unattended vehicle or other unattended property is damaged, shall make a reasonable effort to find the owner or custodian of such property and shall report to the owner or custodian the information which the driver is required to report pursuant to section 86-366 if such owner or custodian is found. If the owner or custodian of such damaged vehicle or property cannot be found, the driver shall leave a note in a conspicuous place at the scene of the accident and shall report the accident in writing within 24 hours to the police department. Such note and written report shall contain the information which the driver is required to report pursuant to section 86-366 and such written report shall state in addition the date, time and place of the accident and the driver's estimate of the property damage. 
(b)  Where, as a result of injuries sustained in the accident, the driver is prevented from complying with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the driver shall, as soon as reasonably possible, make the required report to the police department and make a reasonable effort to find the owner or custodian of the unattended vehicle or property and report to such person such information as is required to be reported pursuant to section 86-366. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-896. 
Sec. 86-369. - Duty of certain persons accompanying driver to report accidents involving damage only to unattended property. 
    If the driver fails to stop and make a reasonable search for the owner or custodian of an unattended vehicle or property or to leave a note for such owner or custodian as required by section 86-368, every person 16 years of age or older in the vehicle with the driver at the time of the accident who has knowledge of the accident shall have a duty to ensure that a report is made within 24 hours from the time of the accident to the police department. The report shall include his name, address, and such other facts within his knowledge as are required by section 86-368 to be reported by the driver. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(d)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-897. 
Sec. 86-370. - Reports are in addition to others. 
    The reports required by sections 86-366-86-369 are in addition to other accident reports required by Code of Virginia, title 46.2, and shall be made irrespective of the amount of property damage involved. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(e)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-898. 
Sec. 86-371. - Article applies to accidents on private or public property. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply irrespective of whether such accident occurs on the public streets or highways or on private property. 
(Code 1969, § 15-118(f)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-899. 
Sec. 86-372. - Penalty for violation of sections 86-366-86-369. 
    Any person convicted of violating the provisions of sections 86-366-86-369 shall, if such accident results in injury to or the death of any person, be guilty of a class 6 felony. If such accident results only in damage to property, the person so convicted shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor; however, if the vehicle or other property struck is unattended and such damage is less than $250.00, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. A motor vehicle operator convicted of a class 4 misdemeanor under this section shall be assigned three demerit points by the commissioner of the department of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1969, § 15-119(a)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-900. 
Sec. 86-373. - Suspension of driver's license for failure to report certain accidents. 
    Any person convicted of violating the provisions of sections 18-366 to 18-369 may be punished, in addition to the penalties provided in section 86-372, if such accident resulted only in damage to property and such damage exceeded $500.00, by suspension of his license or privilege to operate a motor vehicle on the highways of the state for a period not to exceed six months by the court. This section shall in no case be construed to limit the authority or duty of the commissioner of the department of motor vehicles with respect to revocation of licenses for violation of Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-894-46.2-897, as provided in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-364 et seq. Any license revoked under the provisions of this section shall be surrendered to the court to be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-398. 
(Code 1969, § 15-119(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-901. 
Sec. 86-374. - Leaving scene of accident when directed to do so by officer. 
    A person shall leave the scene of a traffic accident when directed to do so by a law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1969, § 15-120) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-902. 
Sec. 86-375. - Temporary removal and disposition of vehicles involved in accidents. 
    Whenever a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer involved in an accident is so located as to impede the orderly flow of traffic, the police may: 
(1)  At no cost to the owner or operator remove the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer to some point in the vicinity where it will not impede the flow of traffic; or 
(2)  Have the vehicle removed to a storage area for safekeeping and shall report the removal to the department of motor vehicles and to the owner of the vehicle as promptly as possible. If the vehicle is removed to a storage area under this subsection, the owner shall pay to the parties entitled thereto all costs incidental to its removal and storage. 
(Code 1969, § 15-121; Ord. of 4-26-93(1)) 
Cross reference- Removal of glass, etc., of damaged vehicle from street, § 70-4. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt provisions relative to temporary removal and disposition of vehicles involved in accidents, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1212. 
Secs. 86-376-86-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 86-391. - Tire chains or snow tires required under certain conditions. 
(a)  Whenever snow, sleet, hail or freezing rain has caused slippery or hazardous conditions on any of the public streets of the city, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to obstruct or impede other vehicular traffic on any such street by reason of failure to have the driving wheels of the vehicle operated by him equipped by tire chains or snow tires. 
(b)  Every person violating this section shall be fined not exceeding $25.00. 
(Code 1969, § 15-122) 
State Law reference- Regulation of operation of vehicles in snow, sleet, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1302. 
Sec. 86-392. - Illegal sirens, whistles, etc.; unlawful use of warning devices; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be equipped with or for any person to use on any vehicle any siren or exhaust, compression or spark plug whistle, or horn, except as may be authorized in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle operated on a public highway to be equipped with any warning device that is not of a type that has been approved by the superintendent. It shall further be unlawful for any person at any time to use a horn otherwise than as a reasonable warning or to make any unnecessary or unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of a horn or other warning device. However, vehicles of common carriers or extraordinarily large and heavy vehicles may be equipped with such type of warning device as the superintendent may require or permit. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, a siren, bell or supplemental horn may be used on a vehicle as a noisemaker for an alarm system if the device is installed so as to prohibit actuation of the system by the driver while the vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1969, § 15-123) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1060. 
Sec. 86-393. - Exhaust system in good working order. 
(a)  No person shall drive and no owner of a motor vehicle shall permit or allow the operation of any vehicle on a highway unless it is equipped with an exhaust system of a type installed as standard factory equipment, or comparable to that designed for use on the particular vehicle as standard factory equipment, in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noise. An exhaust system shall not be deemed to prevent excessive or unusual noise if it permits the escape of noise in excess of that permitted by the standard factory equipment exhaust system of private passenger motor vehicles or trucks of standard make. 
(b)  The term "exhaust system," as used in this section, means all the parts of a motor vehicle through which the exhaust passes after leaving the engine block. 
(c)  Chambered pipes are not an effective muffling device to prevent excessive or unusual noise. 
(Code 1969, § 15-124(a), (b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1049. 
Sec. 86-394. - Mufflers on motorcycles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any motorcycle not equipped with a muffler or other sound dissipative device in good working order and in constant operation. 
(b)  No person shall remove or render inoperative, or cause to be removed or rendered inoperative, other than for purposes of maintenance, repair or replacement, any muffler or sound dissipative device on a motorcycle. 
(Code 1969, § 15-124(c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1050. 
Sec. 86-395. - Muffler cutouts, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale a muffler without interior baffle plates or other effective muffling device or any gutted muffler, muffler cutout or straight exhaust. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate on the streets of the city a motor vehicle equipped with a gutted muffler, muffler cutout or straight exhaust. 
(Code 1969, § 15-125) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1047. 
Sec. 86-396. - Construction, maintenance and loading must prevent escape of contents; exemptions. 
    No vehicle shall be operated or moved on any highway unless it is so constructed, maintained, and loaded as to prevent its contents from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping. No provision of this section, however, shall apply to any: 
(1)  Motor vehicle which is used exclusively for agricultural purposes and which is not operated on any public highway for any purpose other than moving it across a highway or along a highway from one part of the owner's land to another, irrespective of whether the tracts adjoin; 
(2)  Agricultural vehicle, tractor, or other vehicle exempted from registration and licensing requirements pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 46.2-662 et seq.; or 
(3)  Motor vehicle transporting poultry or livestock. 
(Code 1969, § 15-126) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1156. 
Sec. 86-397. - Fastening load of logs, barrels, etc. 
(a)  No vehicle which is designed or used for the purpose of hauling logs, poles, lumber, barrels, hogsheads, or other materials or containers which by their nature may shift or roll shall be operated or moved on any highway unless its load is securely fastened by adequate log chains, metal cables, nylon webbing, steel straps or other restraining devices so as to prevent the load from shifting or falling from the vehicle. Tobacco hogsheads may, however, be secured by manila or hemp rope, at least five-eighths inch in diameter, of sufficient strength securely to fasten the hogshead against shifting, falling or rolling. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall release the owner or operator of any vehicle as described in subsection (a) from liability for failure to use reasonable care to prevent its load from shifting or falling. 
(Code 1969, § 15-127) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1155. 
Sec. 86-398. - Flag or light at end of load. 
    Whenever the load on any vehicle extends more than four feet beyond the rear of the bed or body thereof, there shall be displayed at the end of the load, in such a position as to be clearly visible at all times from the rear of the load, a red flag, not less than 12 inches, both in length and width. Between sunset and sunrise, however, there shall be displayed at the end of the load a red light plainly visible in clear weather at least 500 feet to the sides and rear of the vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 15-128) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1121. 
Secs. 86-399-86-415. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - LICENSE FEE FOR MOTOR VEHICLES, TRAILERS, AND SEMITRAILERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-25-2013 changed the title of Art. IX from "License Tax for Motor Vehicles and Carriers" to read as set out herein. 
Cross reference- Payment for motor vehicle decals, § 82-5. 

Sec. 86-416. - Ambulances, hearses, etc. 
    On every ambulance, hearse or other like conveyance used in connection with the conducting of funeral services, the license fee shall be $25.00 per year for each vehicle, which shall be in addition to the automobile license fee as prescribed and required by section 86-417. 
(Code 1969, § 15-129; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-417. - Automobiles. 
    On every passenger automobile, the license fee shall be $20.00. 
(Code 1969, § 15-130; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-418. - Automobiles for hire. 
    On every public vehicle, taxicab or for-hire car, there shall be a license fee of $25.00 on each vehicle, in addition to the automobile license fee as prescribed and as required by section 86-417. 
(Code 1969, § 15-131; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-419. - Baggage transportation and trucks for hire. 
    On every vehicle used in transporting baggage, merchandise or material of any kind or character on a for-hire basis, the license fee shall be $25.00 for each vehicle, in addition to the license fee as prescribed and as required by section 86-417. This license fee shall apply to all vehicles whether the owner thereof maintains a place of business in the city or not or whether the owner thereof makes a regular business of transporting baggage, material or merchandise or not, so long as such vehicle uses the streets of the city for the transportation of baggage, merchandise or other material of any kind or character. 
(Code 1969, § 15-132; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-420. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 6-10-02(2), repealed § 86-240 in its entirety. Formerly said section pertained to buses and common carriers. See the Code Disposition Table. 
Sec. 86-421. - Motorcycles. 
    On every motorcycle, there shall be a license fee of $16.00. 
(Code 1969, § 15-134; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-422. - Automobile trailers. 
(a)  On every one- or two-wheel trailer with a body length of not more than nine feet and width not greater than the width of the motor vehicle to which it is attached at any time of operation, which trailer is to be attached to the owner's own motor vehicle and used only for carrying property belonging to the owner of such trailer, not to exceed 1,000 pounds at any one time, the license fee shall be $3.00. 
(b)  On every one- or two-wheel trailer of a cradle flatbed or open pickup type, which has a body width not greater than the width of the motor vehicle to which it is attached at any time of operation, which is pulled or towed by a passenger car or station wagon or a pickup or panel truck, having an actual gross weight not exceeding 5,000 pounds at any one time, the license fee shall be $6.00. On all other trailers and semitrailers, the license fee shall be $12.00. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful, however, to operate any trailer so registered and licensed contrary to any restriction prescribed in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 15-135; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-423. - Trailers for hire. 
(a)  On every one- or two-wheel trailer for hire with a body length of not more than nine feet and a width not greater than the width of the motor vehicle to which it is attached at any time of operation, and used for carrying property not to exceed 1,000 pounds at any one time, there shall be a license fee of $5.00, in addition to the regular automobile trailer license fee required by section 86-422. This license fee shall apply to all vehicles whether the owner thereof maintains a place of business in the city or not or whether the owner thereof makes a regular business of transporting baggage, material or merchandise or not, so long as such vehicles use the streets of the city for such transportation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate any trailer so registered and licensed contrary to any restriction prescribed in this section. 
(Code 1969, § 15-136; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-424. - Trucks, tractors and tractor-trucks, etc. 
    On every truck, tractor and tractor-truck or other motor vehicle not licensed under any other provision of this chapter and not designed and used for the transportation of passengers, the license fee shall be determined by the combined gross weight of the vehicle when loaded to the maximum capacity for which it is registered and licensed, according to the schedule of fees set forth in this section; provided that the fee for a pickup or panel truck shall be $20.00 if the gross weight is 6,500 pounds or less, and in no case shall the fee be less than $24.00 for a motor vehicle with a gross weight of 6,501 pounds through 8,000 pounds. 
Gross Weight Groups 
(pounds) Fee 8,000 and less $24.00 8,001 to 11,500 32.00 11,501 to 15,500 40.00 15,501 to 19,500 56.00 19,501 to 29,500 80.00 29,501 to 39,500 100.00 Over 39,500 120.00  
(Code 1969, § 15-137; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-425. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Sections 86-417, 86-421, 86-422 and 86-424 shall not apply to any person not a resident of the city owning or operating a motor vehicle when the motor vehicle is used exclusively for pleasure or personal transportation. 
(b)  No person shall be required to obtain a license under this article on a vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer upon which the city is prohibited from imposing a vehicle license fee by Section 46.2-755 and Section 46.2-752(H) of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(c)  Local licenses shall be issued free of charge for the following: 
(1)  Vehicles owned by volunteer rescue squads; 
(2)  One vehicle owned by an active member or a life member of a voluntary rescue squad; 
(3)  One vehicle owned by persons qualified to receive special license plates under Section 46.2-739 of the Code of Virginia, as amended; 
(4)  One vehicle owned by an active member of the armed forces of the United States of America; and 
(5)  An "antique motor vehicle" as defined and licensed in Title 46.2 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1969, § 15-138; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-426. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-25-2013 repealed § 86-426, which pertained to license to be displayed and derived from Code 1969, § 15-139. 
Sec. 86-427. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-25-2013 repealed § 86-427, which pertained to prorating motor vehicle licenses and derived from Code 1969, § 15-140. 
Sec. 86-428. - Levy and reissuance of vehicle license. 
    There is hereby levied an annual license fee, as provided in this article, on every motor vehicle, trailer, and semitrailer required to be licensed hereunder. The annual vehicle license fee imposed by this article shall be in addition to any other city license tax or fees including personal property tax. A license fee shall be waived for a license for a vehicle which replaces a vehicle currently licensed in the city which has been sold or disposed of within 30 days of the application for such new license upon presentation of adequate written proof of sale or disposal of the currently licensed vehicle. 
(Code 1969, § 15-141; Ord. of 2-10-92; Ord. of 6-10-02(2); Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-429. - When tax payable. 
    When any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, upon which an annual license fee is imposed pursuant to this article, has its situs in the city on January 1 of any year, the license fee imposed by this article shall be paid on or before May 31 of the same year. When any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, upon which an annual license fee is imposed, acquires its situs in the city after January 1 of any year, the license fee imposed hereunder shall be paid within 30 days of acquisition of situs or by May 31 of the same year, whichever shall occur later. For purposes of this article, "situs" shall be determined pursuant to Section 46.2-752 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of the article, any vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer acquiring its situs in the city after January 15 of any year, shall be subject to a vehicle license fee in a sum equal to the pro-rated monthly amount of that license fee ordinarily required on an annual basis. 
(Code 1969, § 15-142; Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-430. - Payment of personal property tax as a prerequisite to issuance of a motor vehicle license. 
    No certificate of registration and license to operate a motor vehicle shall be issued for any motor vehicle unless and until the applicant for such certificate of registration and license shall have first produced satisfactory evidence that all personal property taxes upon the vehicle to be licensed which have been properly assessed or are assessable against the applicant by the city have been paid. 
(Code 1969, § 15-143; Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-431. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of having committed a class 4 misdemeanor. Each day any such person violates or fails to conform to such provision or requirement shall constitute a separate offense. Such conviction shall not relieve any such person from the payment, collection and remittance of such tax as provided in this article. Unless otherwise ordered by the judge in whose court this violation is tried, or in which the same is cognizable, all fines and penalties arising under this section shall be paid unto the city treasurer. 
(Code 1969, § 15-144; Ord. of 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 86-432. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-25-2013 repealed § 86-432, which pertained to regional enforcement of motor vehicle license requirements and derived from Ord. of 4-25-94; Ord. of 3-10-97(4). 
Secs. 86-433-86-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 86-451. - Blowing whistles or horns. 
    All blowing of whistles or horns attached or fixed to railroad engines and trains standing or passing within the city shall be unlawful, except the sounding of whistles or horns as may be reasonably necessary to signal trains and trainmen. 
(Code 1969, § 23-1) 
Cross reference- Noise prohibited generally, § 30-1. 
State Law reference- Bell and whistle or horn, when sounded, Code of Virginia, § 56-414 et seq. 
Sec. 86-452. - Bell to be rung upon approach of locomotive to street crossing. 
(a)  Upon the approach of any locomotive to any street crossing, it shall be the duty of every railway company, receiver or trustee operating such locomotive, as well as any person then having control, conduct and management of any such locomotive, to cause the engine bell to be rung. This section shall apply whether gates have been erected or not. 
(b)  Every officer or employee of any railway company whose duty it shall be to carry out the provisions of subsection (a) of this section and shall fail to do so shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $10.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1969, § 23-2) 
Cross reference- Noise prohibited generally, § 30-1. 
State Law reference- Bell and whistle or horn, when sounded, Code of Virginia, § 56-414 et seq. 
Sec. 86-453. - Railroad cars obstructing street or road; standing vehicle on railroad track. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, or any receiver or trustee operating a railroad, to obstruct for a longer period than five minutes the free passage on any street or road by standing cars or trains across such street or road, except a passenger train while receiving or discharging passengers, but a passway shall be kept open to allow normal flow of traffic. It shall be unlawful to stand any wagon or other vehicle on the track of any railroad which will hinder or endanger a moving train. Provided, that when a train has been uncoupled so as to make a passway, the time necessarily required, not exceeding three minutes, to pump up the air after the train has been recoupled shall not be included in considering the time such cars or trains were standing across such street or road. Any such railroad company, receiver or trustee violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00; provided that the fine may be $100.00 for each minute beyond the permitted time but the total fine shall not exceed $500.00. 
(b)  This section shall not apply when the train is stopped due to breakdown, mechanical failure or emergency. 
(Code 1969, § 23-4) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 56-412.1. 
Sec. 86-454. - Flying switches and cars not attached to or ahead of engine. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, receiver or trustee operating a railroad, or any person then having control, conduct and management of any locomotive or railway car to make flying switches over or upon any street, or to move any railway car over or upon any street without having an engine attached thereto, or to move any railway car over or upon any street when such car is moving ahead of the engine or locomotive, unless some employee of the receiver, trustee or railroad company shall be stationed thereat to give warnings of the approach of such car or cars. 
(Code 1969, § 23-5) 
Secs. 86-455-86-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - AUTOMOBILE GRAVEYARDS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- License of junk dealers, § 22-79. 
State Law reference- Ordinances taxing and regulating automobile graveyards and junkyards, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-28; junkyards, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-348. 

Sec. 86-471. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile graveyard means any lot or place which is exposed to the weather and upon which more than five motor vehicles of any kind, incapable of being operated, and which it would not be economically practical to make operative, are placed, located or found. 
(Code 1969, § 5-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-348. 
Sec. 86-472. - Certificate of approval-Generally. 
    No automobile graveyard shall be established and operated unless a certificate of approval shall first have been procured from the city manager. Any person proposing to establish and operate an automobile graveyard shall first make application to the city manager for a hearing thereon, who shall within ten days mail to such applicant notice of the time and place of hearing. The applicant shall, at his own expense, prior to making application, publish notice of proposal to file application, together with his name, address and proposed location of the automobile graveyard, once a week for two successive weeks in some newspaper published or having general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1969, § 5-2) 
Sec. 86-473. - Issuance or refusal of certificate-Generally. 
    At the hearing provided for in section 86-472, the city manager shall determine whether or not a certificate of approval shall be issued. In considering the application in question, the city manager shall take into account the nature and development of the surrounding property, the proximity of churches, schools, hospitals, public buildings or other places of public gathering and the health, safety and general welfare of the public. The applicant shall be notified within ten days from time of completion of the hearing as to the granting or refusal of the certificate of approval. 
(Code 1969, § 5-3) 
Sec. 86-474. - Same-Appeal to circuit court. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action taken pursuant to section 86-473 may, within 30 days from the date of the notice of the refusal or issuance of the certificate of approval, appeal by petition to the circuit court of the city. Upon any such appeal, such court shall enter such order in relation to the action appealed from as it may deem proper under all circumstances obtaining. 
(Code 1969, § 5-4) 
Sec. 86-475. - License tax; transfer of license. 
    Upon the grant of a certificate of approval, as provided in section 86-472, the person receiving the certificate of approval shall pay a license tax to the city in the amount of $500.00, which license tax shall thenceforth be paid on a per annum basis. The license in question shall be nontransferable. 
(Code 1969, § 5-5) 
Cross reference- Licensing, § 22-36 et seq. 
Sec. 86-476. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1969, § 5-6) 
Chapter 90 - UTILITIES[1]

ARTICLE II. - CITY ELECTRIC SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Power to provide electric energy (Code of Virginia, § 15.2-877) adopted, § 2.2. 
Cross reference- Electricity, § 18-166 et seq.; discontinuance of electrical service for failure to comply with electrical regulations, § 18-196; electricity in mobile home parks, § 54-47; signs, ch. 66; polls and wires, § 74-136 et seq. 

Sec. 90-26. - Supervision of electric department. 
    The electric department shall be under the supervision of the city manager, who shall exercise immediate control of the electric department, which shall be taken to include the entire city electrical system, including the street lighting system and all lands, buildings, fixtures, wires, meters, poles, apparatus and equipment belonging and appertaining thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 16-1) 
Sec. 90-27. - Connecting wires with city electrical system-Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to connect any wires with the city electrical system, whether within or without the limits of the city, without first having obtained a permit from the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1969, § 16-2) 
Sec. 90-28. - Same-Supervision. 
    All connections as referred to in section 90-27 shall be made only under the supervision of the city manager or duly authorized agent or employee of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-3) 
Sec. 90-29. - Same-Connection fee. 
    No charge shall be made as a prerequisite to any service connection as referred to in section 90-27. 
(Code 1969, § 16-4) 
Sec. 90-30. - Permit for cutting on electricity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut on electric current, whether within or without the limits of the city, without first having obtained a permit from the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1969, § 16-5) 
Sec. 90-31. - Injuring, etc., poles, wires, lamps, transformers, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to break, mark, deface, remove, injure or destroy any pole, wire, lamp, transformer, meter, or other apparatus or equipment belonging to the city or used by it in connection with its electrical system. 
(Code 1969, § 16-6) 
Cross reference- Injuring property generally, § 58-19. 
Sec. 90-32. - Tampering with meter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with any city electric meter so as to injure such meter or to prevent or interrupt the proper and accurate registration by it of the quantity of electricity used by the consumer or supplied by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-7) 
Cross reference- Injuring property generally, § 58-19. 
Sec. 90-33. - Diversion, etc., of electric current. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to divert electric current from any wire connected with the electric system of the city. No person shall otherwise unlawfully use or cause to be used without the consent of the city any electricity manufactured or distributed by the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-8) 
Sec. 90-34. - Doing of act tending to obstruct or impair intended use of part of electric system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act tending to obstruct or impair the intended use of any building, machinery, apparatus, wires, poles, meters, fixtures, attachments or appurtenances of the electric system or any part thereof without permission of the city manager, except as otherwise provided for by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-9) 
Sec. 90-35. - Duty of city manager as to placing, etc., of wires, etc. 
    The city manager, or any duly authorized representative, shall regulate and determine the placing of electric wires or other appliances for electric light, heat or power in the city, and shall cause all such wires or appliances to be placed, constructed and guarded so as not to cause fires or accidents endangering life or property. 
(Code 1969, § 16-10) 
Secs. 90-36-90-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Powers as to municipal water supplies and facilities (Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-854, 15.2-875) adopted, § 2.2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-51. - Supervision of water and sewer department; what included in water and sewer department. 
    The city water and sewer department shall be under the supervision of the city manager, who shall exercise immediate control over the water and sewer department, which shall be taken to include: 
(1)  The entire water supply system consisting of all plants, systems, facilities or properties used or useful or having the present capacity for future use in connection with the supply or distribution of water, and any integral part thereof, including water supply systems, water distribution systems, reservoirs, wells, intakes, mains, laterals, pumping stations, standpipes, filtration plants, purification plants, hydrants, meters, valves and equipment, appurtenances, and all properties, rights, easements and franchises relating thereto and deemed necessary or convenient by the council for the operation thereof. 
(2)  The entire sewage disposal system consisting of all sewers, pipelines, conduits, pumping stations, force-mains, treatment plants and works, and all other plants or structures necessary or suitable for the collection and disposal of sewage and waterborne wastes, and all properties, rights, easements and franchises relating thereto and deemed necessary or convenient by the council for the operation thereof. 
(Code 1969, § 16-11) 
Sec. 90-52. - Right of entry of water and sewer director to premises receiving city water. 
    Every person occupying a lot or tenement into which water is conveyed from the city water system shall permit the water and sewer director to enter such lot or tenement, at reasonable hours, to inspect the work therein, or to see if the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city pertaining to the water or sewer system are being, or have been, violated. 
(Code 1969, § 16-12) 
Secs. 90-53-90-70. - Reserved.

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 90-71. - Permit prerequisite to alteration, etc., of fixtures used in connection with waterworks system. 
    No person shall make any addition to, or alteration of, fixtures used in connection with the waterworks system of the city without having first received a written permit from the city manager so to do. 
(Code 1969, § 16-13) 
Sec. 90-72. - Connections to city mains to be made under supervision of city manager or by authorized agent or employee of city. 
    All connections to the city water mains for supplying water for any purpose whatsoever shall be made only under the supervision of the city manager or a duly authorized agent or employee of the city. No person other than one duly authorized by the city manager shall introduce into any lot or tenement water from the city pipes, introduce any ferrule or other fixture into any of such pipes, construct or lay down or have constructed or laid down any pipes or other works for the purpose of introducing water into a lot or tenement, or break up any street, lane, alley or road for the purpose of constructing or laying down any such pipes or works. 
(Code 1969, § 16-14) 
Sec. 90-73. - Connection to city water mains-Approval. 
    All service connections to the city water mains shall be made only upon order of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 16-15)

Sec. 90-75. - Turning on water in house, etc. 
    Water shall not be turned on in any house or private water service except by order of the city manager or his duly authorized representative; provided, however, that this shall not be construed to prohibit a registered plumber from turning water into such pipes to test such pipes or for purposes of testing the plumbing connected thereto. 
(Code 1969, § 16-17) 
Sec. 90-76. - Cross connections. 
(1)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to eliminate cross- connections and protect the public health. This article provides for establishment and enforcement of a program of cross-connection control and backflow prevention program (the program) in accordance with the Commonwealth of Virginia, State Board of Health, Waterworks Regulations 1991, as amended. This article is directed at total cross-connection control through service line protection (containment) and point of use protection or area confinement protection (isolation). 
(2)  Authority. The authority for this chapter is found in Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Health "Waterworks Regulations" Part II; Article 3, "Cross-Connection Control and Backflow Prevention in Waterworks;" Uniform Statewide Building Code, Volume I, and Uniform Statewide Building Code, Volume II, Note 1. 
(3)  Administration. 
(a)  The building official or his or her designated deputy shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section under the direction of the city manager. 
(b)  The building official shall cause inspections to be made of properties served by the waterworks where cross-connection with the waterworks is deemed possible. The method of determining potential cross-connection with the waterworks and the administrative procedures shall be established by the city manager in a cross-connection control and backflow prevention program approved by the Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Health, Division of Water Supply Engineering; and the city manager is authorized to prepare, implement, and amend the program. 
(c)  The responsibility to carry out the program lies with the building official. The program shall be carried out in accordance with the Uniform Statewide Building Code and the Commonwealth of Virginia, State Board of Health, "Waterworks Regulations" and shall be a continuing program. 
(4)  Enforcement. 
(a)  The building official shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time premises served by a connection to the waterworks for the purpose of inspecting, observing, sampling, and testing the water supply system of systems for a cross-connection. Upon request, the water supply system owner or occupants of property served shall furnish to the building official pertinent information regarding the water supply system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of a cross-connection. 
(b)  Notice of violation. Any water supply system owner/consumer found to be in violation of any provision of this ordinance shall be served a written notice of violation, to be sent by certified mail, to the water supply system owner's/consumer's last known address. This notice shall describe the nature of the violation, corrective action that is required and shall provide a feasible time limit for corrective action, not to exceed 20 days, from the sending date of the notice of violation. The owner/consumer shall bring the water supply system into compliance with this section, within the designated time limit or have the water service terminated. 
(c)  Penalties. Any owner of properties served by a connection to the waterworks, or any water supply system owner, found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article, or any written order of the building official, in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 for each violation. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this article shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purposes of this article. 
(5)  Water purveyor. The water purveyor has primary responsibility to prevent water from unapproved sources, or any other substance, entering the public water supply system. The water purveyor is prohibited by these regulations or rules from installing or maintaining a water service connection to consumer's water system within its jurisdiction where a health, system, plumbing or pollutional hazard exists, or will probably exist, unless the public potable water supply is protected against backflow by an approved backflow prevention assembly(s) installed at the service connection(s) (i.e., point of delivery). 
    The water purveyor's responsibility begins at the source and includes all of the public water distribution system, including the service connection, and ends at the point of delivery to the consumer's water system(s). In addition, the water purveyor shall exercise reasonable vigilance to insure that the consumer has taken the proper steps to protect the public potable water system. To insure that the proper precautions are taken the water purveyor is required to determine the degree of hazard to the public potable water system. When it is determined that a backflow prevention assembly is required for the protection of the public system the water purveyor shall require the consumer, at the consumer's expense, to install an approved backflow prevention assembly at each service connection, to test immediately upon installation and annually, or more often, to properly repair and maintain such assembly or assemblies and to keep adequate records of each test and subsequent maintenance and repair, including materials or replacement parts. 
(6)  Building official. The building official has the responsibility to not only review building plans and inspect plumbing as it is installed; but, he has the explicit responsibility of preventing cross-connections from being designed and built into the structures within the city. Where the review of building plans suggests or detects the potential for cross-connections being made as an integral part of the plumbing system the building official has the responsibility for requiring that such cross-connection practices be either eliminated or provided with approved backflow prevention equipment. 
    The building official's responsibility begins at the point of service (i.e., the downstream side of the water meter or service connection) and carries throughout the entire length of the consumer's water system. The building official should inquire about the intended use of water at any point where it is suspect that a cross-connection might be made or where one is actually called for by the plans. When such is discovered, a suitable approved backflow prevention assembly shall be required and be properly installed. 
(7)  Consumer. The consumer has the responsibility of preventing pollutants and contaminants from entering his/her potable water system(s) or the public potable water system. The consumer's responsibility starts at the point of delivery from the public potable water system and includes all of his/her water systems. The consumer, at his/her own expense, shall install, operate, test and maintain approved backflow prevention assemblies as directed by the building official. The consumer shall maintain accurate records of tests and repairs made to backflow prevention assemblies and provide the administrative authority having jurisdiction with copies of such records. The records shall be on forms approved by the building official and shall include the list of materials or replacement parts used. Following any repair, overhaul, repiping or relocation of an assembly the consumer shall have it tested to insure that it is in good operating condition and will prevent backflow. Tests, maintenance and repairs of backflow prevention assemblies shall be made by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester. 
    When requested by the water purveyor or health department, the consumer shall appoint a water supervisor who shall be responsible for conformance with all applicable laws, rules and regulations pertaining to cross-connection control; for the installation, operation and use of all water piping systems, backflow prevention assemblies and water-using equipment on the premises; and for the avoidance of unprotected cross-connections. The water supervisor should be the consumer or any full-time employee appointed by the consumer who has a thorough knowledge of the installation, operation and maintenance of all water systems and backflow prevention assemblies on the consumer's premises. In the event of pollution or contamination of the public or the consumer's potable water system due to backflow on or from the consumer's premises, the owner or water supervisor shall promptly take steps to confine further spread of the pollution or contamination within the system and should notify the local health officer and the water purveyor of the condition. The person responsible for the consumer's water system(s) (consumer or water supervisor) shall take appropriate measures to free the water system(s) of any pollutants or contaminants. 
(8)  Certified backflow prevention assembly tester. When directed to test, repair, overhaul or maintain backflow prevention assemblies, a certified backflow prevention assembly tester will have the following responsibilities: 
    The tester will be responsible for performing accurate field tests and for repairing or overhauling backflow prevention assemblies and making reports of such repair to the consumer and responsible authorities on forms approved by the administrative authority having jurisdiction. The tester shall include the list of materials or replacement parts used. The tester shall be equipped with and be capable of using all the necessary tools, gages, and other equipment necessary to properly test, repair and maintain backflow prevention assemblies. It will be the tester's further responsibly not to change the design, material or operational characteristics of an assembly during repair or maintenance without prior approval of the approving authority. A certified tester shall perform the work and be responsible for the accuracy of all tests and reports. 
(9)  Responsibilities. 
(a)  General. Effective cross-connection control requires the cooperation of the water purveyor, the building official, the consumer, the Virginia Department of Health, and backflow prevention device tester. 
(b)  Water purveyor. 
1.  The purveyor shall establish or cause to be established and operate a cross-connection control and backflow prevention program consistent with the extent of the system and the type of consumer served. This program shall include at least one designated individual who shall be responsible for the inspection of the waterworks for cross- connection and backflow prevention control. This program shall be carried out in accordance with the Uniform Statewide Building Code and shall be a continuing program. 
2.  The purveyor has full responsibility for water quality for the construction, maintenance, and operation of the waterworks beginning at the water source and ending at the service connection. The purveyor's responsibly ends at the point of delivery to a consecutive waterworks. 
3.  The purveyor shall have thorough inspections and operational tests made at least annually of backflow prevention devices which are required and installed at the service connection. The purveyor has the option to require a containment device. 
4.  In the event of backflow of pollution or contamination into the waterworks, the purveyor shall promptly take or cause corrective action to confine and eliminate the pollution or contamination. The purveyor shall immediately notify the VDH-Office of Water Programs when backflow occurs. 
5.  The purveyor shall take positive action to ensure that the waterworks is adequately protected at all times. If a cross- connection exists or backflow occurs into a consumer's water system or if the pressure in the waterworks is lowered below ten psi gauge, the purveyor may discontinue the water service to the consumer and the water service shall not be restored until the deficiencies have been corrected or eliminated to the satisfaction of the purveyor. 
(10)  Determination or degree of hazard. Premises with one or more of the following conditions shall be rated at the corresponding degree of hazard: 
(a)  High hazard. 
1.  The contaminant would be toxic, poisonous, noxious or unhealthy. 
2.  A health hazard would exist. 
3.  A high probability exists of a backflow occurrence either by back pressure or by back siphonage. 
4.  The contaminant would disrupt the service of piped water for drinking or domestic use. 
5.  Examples: Sewage, used water, nonpotable water, auxiliary water systems, toxic or hazardous chemicals, etc. 
(b)  Moderate. 
1.  The contaminant would only degrade the hazard quality of the water aesthetically or impair the usefulness of the water. 
2.  A health hazard would not exist. 
(c)  Low hazard. 
1.  The contaminant would only degrade the quality of the water aesthetically. 
2.  A health hazard would not exist. 
3.  A low probability exists of the occurrence of backflow primarily by back siphonage. 
4.  The contaminant would not disrupt service of piped water. 
5.  Examples: Food stuff, nontoxic chemicals, nonhazardous chemicals, etc. 
(11)  Containment policy. 
(a)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at each service connection to a consumer's water system where, in the judgment of the water purveyor or the VDH-Office of Water Programs, a health, pollution, or system hazard to the waterworks exists. 
(b)  When, as a matter of practicality, the backflow prevention device cannot be installed at the service connection, the device may be located downstream of the service connection but prior to any unprotected takeoffs. 
(c)  A backflow prevention device shall be installed at each service connection to a consumer's water system serving premises where the following conditions exist: 
1.  Premises on which any substance is handled in such a manner as to create an actual or potential hazard to a waterworks (this shall include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters originating from a waterworks which are no longer under the control of the water purveyor);
