Sec. 90-258. - Rates, etc., outside city. 
    The rates for all water used by consumers of water outside the city shall be the rates prevailing within the city and applicable to users of water residing within the city. In all other respects the provisions of this Code applicable to the city municipal water system and methods of metering the water, collecting therefor, rate scales, advance deposits for water consumers under certain conditions, water connection charges, penalties, etc., shall be and are hereby made applicable to consumers of water outside the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-48) 
Sec. 90-259. - Credits for leakage. 
    A user of water may be entitled to a credit for leakage against the user's water/sewer bill upon the following conditions: 
(a)  The leak is in a waterline on the property of the user; and 
(b)  The average cost of water and/or sewer to such user, during one monthly billing period of such leakage, shall be at least double the monthly average cost of such water/sewer for the preceding 12 months; and 
(c)  No such credit shall be allotted to the user until the leak is repaired by a plumbing contractor and said plumbing contractor certifies, in writing, such repair to the utility billing department; and 
(d)  The amount of such credit for the benefit of a user shall be one-half of such excess over and above the average water/sewer charge for the 12 preceding months and the remaining one-half of such excess shall be paid by the user; and 
(e)  Such credit shall be made no more than once to a user during a 12-month period. 
    Should the certification required in subsection (c) above not be submitted, such credit as hereinabove provided shall not be made until the fourth monthly billing period thereafter upon the determination by the city that the leakage repair has been completed. 
(Code 1969, § 16-49; Ord. of 2-27-2012, eff. 3-8-2012) 
Secs. 90-260-90-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERS AND RATES FOR ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 90-276. - Use of meter, etc., in taking electricity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take any electricity from the city electric system except through a meter or as otherwise provided for, or from any premises not owned by him, without the permission of the city manager. 
(Code 1969, § 16-50) 
Sec. 90-277. - Separate connection and meter for each residence. 
    With reference to the supply of electricity by the city, each individual residence shall have a separate connection and meter. 
(Code 1969, § 16-51) 
Sec. 90-278. - Metering of electricity. 
    All electricity furnished by the electric department shall be measured by meters furnished, located, and installed by the city for that purpose, and shall remain the property of the city; provided, however, that no meters shall be required, in the judgment of the city manager, as to windows, outside decorative lighting or transient consumers, when the wiring furnishing such service is equipped with a proper device, or other methods are used, whereby a true measure can be taken of the electricity so sold, or when a special contract is entered into with the consumer for a temporary period that would make the installation of meters impracticable. 
    Whenever any metering installation loses its effectiveness or accuracy, as determined by the city, due to equipment condition or damage, it shall be reworked or replaced. The city shall provide the metering equipment and the owner of such premises shall bear the cost of any service reconfiguration that is required to comply with city standards as determined from time to time. 
(Code 1969, § 16-52; Ord. of 2-26-2018(1)) 
Sec. 90-279. - Rates for electricity. 
    The rates for electricity sold by the city to consumers, as may be shown by the meter or as otherwise provided, shall be as provided by the council by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1969, § 16-53) 
Sec. 90-280. - Modifications to metering. 
    Upon application for an electrical permit under section 18-192 herein, the city shall review the existing metering at the premises to determine whether modifications to that metering shall be required. Any metering modifications so required shall be completed pursuant to the requirements of the electrical permit and the applicant shall bear the costs of such modifications. 
(Ord. of 2-26-2018(1)) 
Secs. 90-281-90-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SEWER SERVICE CHARGES IN CITY; PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 90-296. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD means biochemical oxygen demand. 
    Domestic sewage means sewage or wastes of a character not in excess of 300 parts per million (ppm) of BOD or not in excess of 300 ppm of suspended solids, either or both. 
    Individual residential domestic consumer means a domestic consumer of water residing in a private residence. 
    Industrial sewage means sewage or wastes of a character in excess of 300 ppm of BOD or in excess of 300 ppm of suspended solids, either or both. 
    ppm means parts per million gallons. 
    Regular customer or regular consumer means a consumer in the city who purchases from the city all water used by him. 
(Code 1969, § 16-54) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-297. - Application of division. 
    This division shall be construed to apply to persons inside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1969, § 16-55) 
Sec. 90-298. - Establishment and imposition of charges generally. 
    Upon every person inside the city discharging water, sewage or other effluent into the city's sanitary sewer system through facilities owned or controlled by such person, or permitting others so to do, the charges set forth in this division for the collection, treatment and disposal of such sewage are hereby fixed and imposed. 
(Code 1969, § 16-56) 
Sec. 90-299. - Installation of metering station in lieu of water meter. 
    Any person who discharges domestic sewage or industrial sewage into the sanitary sewer system of the city may, in lieu of installing water meters of a type currently used by the city's water and sewer department, install a metering station, in accordance with plans and specifications submitted to and approved by the city, for the purpose of determining the volume of the sewage or effluent so discharged into the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1969, § 16-57) 
Sec. 90-300. - When charges payable; penalty for late payment. 
    All charges imposed under this division upon persons shall be due and payable on the same day as their respective water bills are due and payable and shall be an integral part thereof, and if not paid when such persons' water bills are payable or would be payable if such persons purchased from the city all or a portion of the water used by them, then the same penalty shall be added as is provided for upon persons delinquent in the payment of their water bills, as set forth and provided for in section 90-238. Every person shall pay the combined charges for water purchased, and the sewer charges and surcharges, as provided for in this division, at one and the same time; and further, the city treasurer is instructed not to receive payment of any water charges unless the sewer charges and surcharges are paid at the same time, or vice versa. 
(Code 1969, § 16-58) 
Sec. 90-301. - Prohibited discharges generally. 
    No person shall discharge into the city's sanitary sewer system any sewage, waste or effluent containing oils, hair from tanneries, paunch contents, grit from packing plants, chrome-plating wastes or other substances not normally regarded as sewage, in such quantities and concentrations as would adversely affect the operations of the sewage treatment plant of the City of Roanoke, the discharge of which, into the city's sanitary sewer system, is expressly forbidden and prohibited by subsection A of section III of the contract entered into by and between the City of Roanoke and the City of Salem under date of February 29, 1972. Any person so discharging into the city's sanitary sewer system any substance, as set out and referred to in this section, shall be liable in damages to the city for the full amount, inclusive of principal, interest and costs, that the city in turn may have to pay to the City of Roanoke, as provided in subsection C of section III of such contract. 
(Code 1969, § 16-59) 
Sec. 90-302. - Further limitation on discharge of sewage, etc., into city's sanitary sewer system. 
    No person shall, at any time, discharge into the sanitary sewer system of the city any sewage, waste or effluent of such a character or strength as would cause the average strength of the city's general sewage effluence to exceed 300 ppm of BOD, or suspended solids to exceed 300 ppm, either or both, based on any 24-hour composite sample. Any person discharging sewage, waste or other effluent into the city's sanitary sewer system, of an average BOD in excess of 300 ppm, or of an average suspended solids in excess of 300 ppm, either or both, based on any 24-hour composite sample, shall, if the city's general sewage effluence exceeds an average BOD of 300 ppm, or an average suspended solids in excess of 300 ppm, either or both, be conclusively presumed to be discharging sewage, waste or other effluence into the city's sanitary sewer system, which causes the same to exceed the maximum BOD content and the maximum suspended solids content prohibited in the contract entered into by and between the City of Roanoke, of the first part, and the City of Salem, of the second part, under date of February 29, 1972, by virtue of which contract the City of Roanoke has agreed to treat the sewage or waste originating within the city, which maximum is a BOD content not in excess of 300 ppm, and suspended solids content not in excess of 300 ppm, based on any 24-hour composite sample. 
(Code 1969, § 16-60) 
Sec. 90-303. - Domestic and industrial sewage; charges for disposal. 
(a)  There are hereby established the following customer classes and rates for the consumption of sewer utility services within the City of Salem effective July 1, 2010: 
Residential -Generally characterized as serving single-family residential households regardless of the level of consumption; 
Small commercial -A business entity that utilizes less than 75,000 gallons per month; 
Large commercial -Businesses entities both commercial or industrial using in excess of 75,000 gallons per month; 
Multi-unit -Those customers both residential and small commercial with more than one housing unit or business location served by a single meter. 
    The following base charges are hereby established and effective as noted:
